sent_raw: 0,Sixty million and more
1,"I will call them my people, which were not my people; and her beloved, which was not beloved."
2,ROMANS :
3,WAS SPITEFUL.
4,Full of a baby's venom.
5,The women in the house knew it and so did the children.
6,"For years each put up with the spite in his own way, but by Sethe and her daughter Denver were its only victims."

7,"The grandmother, Baby Suggs, was dead, and the sons, Howard and Buglar, had run away by the time they were thirteen years old--as soon as merely looking in a mirror shattered it (that was the signal for Buglar); as soon as two tiny hand prints appeared in the cake (that was it for Howard). Neither boy waited to see more; another kettleful of chickpeas smoking in a heap on the floor; soda crackers crumbled and strewn in a line next to the door sill. Nor did they wait for one of the relief periods: the weeks, months even, when nothing was disturbed. No. Each one fled at once--the moment the house committed what was for him the one insult not to be borne or witnessed a second time."

8,"Within two months, in the dead of winter, leaving their grandmother, Baby Suggs; Sethe, their mother; and their little sister, Denver, all by themselves in the gray and white house on Bluestone Road."
9,"It didn't have a number then, because Cincinnati didn't stretch that far."

10,"In fact, Ohio had been calling itself a state only seventy years when first one brother and then the next stuffed quilt packing into his hat, snatched up his shoes, and crept away from the lively spite the house felt for them."
11,Baby Suggs didn't even raise her head.
12,From her sickbed she heard them go but that wasn't the reason she lay still.
13,It was a wonder to her that her grandsons had taken so long to realize that every house wasn't like the one on Bluestone Road.
14,"Suspended between the nas tiness of life and the meanness of the dead, she couldn't get interested in leaving life or living it, let alone the fright of two creeping-off boys."
15,"Her past had been like her present-- intolerable--and since she knew death was anything but forgetfulness, she used the little energy left her for pondering color."
16,"""Bring a little lavender in, if you got any. Pink, if you don't."""
17,And Sethe would oblige her with anything from fabric to her own tongue.
18,Winter in Ohio was especially rough if you had an appetite for color.
19,Sky
20,"provided the only drama, and counting on a Cincinnati horizon for life's principal joy was reckless indeed."
21,"So Sethe and the girl Denver did what they could, and what the house permitted, for her."
22,"Together they waged a perfunctory battle against the outrageous behavior of that place; against turned-over slop jars, smacks on the behind, and gusts of sour air."
23,For they understood the source of the outrage as well as they knew the source of light.

24,"Baby Suggs died shortly after the brothers left, with no interest whatsoever in their leave-taking or hers, and right afterward Sethe and Denver decided to end the persecution by calling forth the ghost that tried them so."
25,"Perhaps a conversation, they thought, an exchange of views or something would help."
26,"So they held hands and said, ""Come on. Come on. You may as well just come on."""
27,The sideboard took a step forward but nothing else did.
28,"""Grandma Baby must be stopping it,"" said Denver."
29,She was ten and still mad at Baby Suggs for dying.
30,Sethe opened her eyes.
31,"""I doubt that,"" she said."
32,"""Then why don't it come?"""
33,"""You forgetting how little it is,"" said her mother."
34,"""She wasn't even two years old when she died. Too little to understand. Too little to talk much even."""
35,"""Maybe she don't want to understand,"" said Denver."
36,"""Maybe. But if she'd only come, I could make it clear to her."""
37,Sethe released her daughter's hand and together they pushed the sideboard back against the wall.
38,Outside a driver whipped his horse into the gallop local people felt necessary when they passed .
39,"""For a baby she throws a powerful spell,"" said Denver."
40,"""No more powerful than the way I loved her,"" Sethe answered and there it was again."
41,"The welcoming cool of unchiseled headstones; the one she selected to lean against on tiptoe, her knees wide open as any grave."
42,Pink as a
43,"fingernail it was, and sprinkled with glittering chips."
44,"Ten minutes, he said."
45,You got ten minutes I'll do it for free.
46,Ten minutes for seven letters.
47,"With another ten could she have gotten ""Dearly"" too?"

48,"She had not thought to ask him and it bothered her still that it might have been possible--that for twenty minutes, a half hour, say, she could have had the whole thing, every word she heard the preacher say at the funeral (and all there was to say, surely) engraved on her baby's headstone: Dearly Beloved."
49,"But what she got, settled for, was the one word that mattered."
50,"She thought it would be enough, rutting among the headstones with the engraver, his young son looking on, the anger in his face so old; the appetite in it quite new."
51,That should certainly be enough.
52,"Enough to answer one more preacher, one more abolitionist and a town full of disgust."
53,"Counting on the stillness of her own soul, she had forgotten the other one: the soul of her baby girl."
54,Who would have thought that a little old baby could harbor so much rage?
55,Rutting among the stones under the eyes of the engraver's son was not enough.

56,"Not only did she have to live out her years in a house palsied by the baby's fury at having its throat cut, but those ten minutes she spent pressed up against dawn-colored stone studded with star chips, her knees wide open as the grave, were longer than life, more alive, more pulsating than the baby blood that soaked her fingers like oil."
57,"""We could move,"" she suggested once to her mother-in-law."
58,"""What'd be the point?"" asked Baby Suggs."
59,"""Not a house in the country ain't packed to its rafters with some dead Negro's grief."
60,We lucky this ghost is a baby.
61,My husband's spirit was to come back in here?
62,or yours?
63,Don't talk to me.
64,You lucky.
65,You got three left.
66,Three pulling at your skirts and just one raising hell from the other side.
67,"Be thankful, why don't you?"
68,I had eight.
69,Every one of them gone away from me.
70,"Four taken, four chased, and all, I expect, worrying somebody's house into evil."
71,""" Baby Suggs rubbed her eyebrows."
72,"""My first-born. All I can remember of her is how she loved the burned bottom of bread. Can you beat that? Eight children and that's all I remember."""
73,"""That's all you let yourself remember,"" Sethe had told her, but she was down to one herself--one alive, that is--the boys chased off by the dead one, and her memory of Buglar was fading fast."
74,Howard at least had a head shape nobody could forget.
75,"As for the rest, she worked hard to remember as close to nothing as was safe."
76,Unfortunately her brain was devious.
77,"She might be hurrying across a field, running practically, to get to the pump quickly and rinse the chamomile sap from her legs."
78,Nothing else would be in her mind.
79,The picture of the men coming to nurse her was as lifeless as the nerves in her back where the skin buckled like a washboard.
80,Nor was there the faintest scent of ink or the cherry gum and oak bark from which it was made.
81,Nothing.
82,Just the breeze cooling her face as she rushed toward water.

83,"And then sopping the chamomile away with pump water and rags, her mind fixed on getting every last bit of sap off--on her carelessness in taking a shortcut across the field just to save a half mile, and not noticing how high the weeds had grown until the itching was all the way to her knees. Then something. The plash of water, the sight of her shoes and stockings awry on the path where she had flung them; or Here Boy lapping in the puddle near her feet, and suddenly there was Sweet Home rolling, rolling, rolling out before her eyes, and although there was not a leaf on that farm that did not make her want to scream, it rolled itself out before her in shameless beauty. It never looked as terrible as it was and it made her wonder if hell was a pretty place too. Fire and brimstone all right, but hidden in lacy groves. Boys hanging from the most beautiful sycamores in the world. It shamed her--remembering the wonderful soughing trees rather than the boys."
84,"Try as she might to make it otherwise, the sycamores beat out the children every time and she could not forgive her memory for that."
85,"When the last of the chamomile was gone, she went around to the front of the house, collecting her shoes and stockings on the way."
86,"As if to punish her further for her terrible memory, sitting on the porch not forty feet away was Paul D, the last of the Sweet Home men."
87,"And although she she said, ""Is that you?"""
88,"""What's left."""
89,He stood up and smiled.
90,"""How you been, girl, besides barefoot?"""
91,When she laughed it came out loose and young.
92,"""Messed up my legs back"
93,yonder.
94,Chamomile.
95,He made a face as though tasting a teaspoon of something bitter.
96,"""I don't want to even hear 'bout it. Always did hate that stuff."""
97,Sethe balled up her stockings and jammed them into her pocket.
98,"""Come on in."""
99,"""Porch is fine, Sethe. Cool out here."""
100,"He sat back down and looked at the meadow on the other side of the road, knowing the eagerness he felt would be in his eyes."
101,"""Eighteen years,"" she said softly."
102,"""Eighteen,"" he repeated."
103,"""And I swear I been walking every one of em. Mind if I join you?"""
104,He nodded toward her feet and began unlacing his shoes.
105,"""You want to soak them? Let me get you a basin of water."""
106,She moved closer to him to enter the house.
107,"""No, uh uh. Can't baby feet. A whole lot more tramping they got to do yet."""
108,"""You can't leave right away, Paul D. You got to stay awhile."""
109,"""Well, long enough to see Baby Suggs, anyway. Where is she?"""
111,"""Aw no. When?"""
112,"""Eight years now. Almost nine."""
113,"""Was it hard? I hope she didn't die hard."""
114,Sethe shook her head.
115,"""Soft as cream. Being alive was the hard part. Sorry you missed her though. Is that what you came by for?"""
116,"""That's some of what I came for. The rest is you. But if all the truth be known, I go anywhere these days. Anywhere they let me sit down."""
117,"""You looking good."""
118,"""Devil's confusion. He lets me look good long as I feel bad."""
119,"He looked at her and the word ""bad"" took on another meaning."
120,Sethe smiled.
121,This is the way they were--had been.
122,"All of the Sweet Home men, before and after Halle, treated her to a mild brotherly flirtation, so subtle you had to scratch for it."
123,"Except for a heap more hair and some waiting in his eyes, he looked the way he had in Kentucky."
124,Peachstone skin; straight-backed.
125,"For a man with an immobile face it was amazing how ready it was to smile, or blaze or be sorry with you."
126,As though all you had to do was get his attention and right away he produced the feeling you were feeling.
127,"With less than a blink, his face seemed to change--underneath it lay the activity."
128,"""I wouldn't have to ask about him, would I? You'd tell me if there was anything to tell, wouldn't you?"""
129,Sethe looked down at her feet and saw again the sycamores.
130,"""I'd tell you. Sure I'd tell you. I don't know any more now than I did then."""
131,"Except for the churn, he thought, and you don't need to know that."
132,"""You must think he's still alive."""
133,"""No. I think he's dead. It's not being sure that keeps him alive."""
134,"""What did Baby Suggs think?"""
135,"""Same, but to listen to her, all her children is dead. Claimed she felt each one go the very day and hour."""
136,"""When she say Halle went?"""
137,"""Eighteen fifty-five. The day my baby was born."""
138,"""You had that baby, did you? Never thought you'd make it."""
139,He chuckled.
140,"""Running off pregnant."""
141,"""Had to. Couldn't be no waiting."""
142,"She lowered her head and thought, as he did, how unlikely it was that she had made it."
143,"And if it hadn't been for that girl looking for velvet, she never would have."
144,"""All by yourself too."""
145,He was proud of her and annoyed by her.
146,Proud she had done it; annoyed that she had not needed Halle or him in the doing.
147,"""Almost by myself. Not all by myself. A whitegirl helped me."""
148,"""Then she helped herself too, God bless her."""
149,"""You could stay the night, Paul D."""
150,"""You don't sound too steady in the offer."""
151,Sethe glanced beyond his shoulder toward the closed door.
152,"""Oh it's truly meant."
153,I just hope you'll pardon my house.
154,Come on in.
155,Talk to Denver while I cook you something.
156,"Paul D tied his shoes together, hung them over his shoulder and followed her through the door straight into a pool of red and undulating light that locked him where he stood."
157,"""You got company?"" he whispered, frowning."
158,"""Off and on,"" said Sethe."
160,He backed out the door onto the porch.
161,"""What kind of evil you got in here?"""
162,"""It's not evil, just sad. Come on. Just step through."""
163,"He looked at her then, closely."
164,"Closer than he had when she first rounded the house on wet and shining legs, holding her shoes and stockings up in one hand, her skirts in the other."
165,Halle's girl--the one with iron eyes and backbone to match.
166,He had never seen her hair in Kentucky.
167,"And though her face was eighteen years older than when last he saw her, it was softer now."
168,Because of the hair.
169,"A face too still for comfort; irises the same color as her skin, which, in that still face, used to make him think of a mask with mercifully punched out eyes."
170,Halle's woman.
171,Pregnant every year including the year she sat by the fire telling him she was going to run.
172,Her three children she had already packed into a wagonload of others in a caravan of Negroes crossing the river.
173,They were to be left with Halle's mother near Cincinnati.
174,"Even in that tiny shack, leaning so close to the fire you could smell the heat in her dress, her eyes did not pick up a flicker of light."
175,They were like two wells into which he had trouble gazing.
176,"Even punched out they needed to be covered, lidded, marked with some sign to warn folks of what that emptiness held."
177,"So he looked instead at the fire while she told him, because her husband was not there for the telling."
178,Mr. Garner was dead and his wife had a lump in her neck the size of a sweet potato and unable to speak to anyone.
179,"She leaned as close to the fire as her pregnant belly allowed and told him, Paul D, the last of the Sweet Home men."
180,"There had been six of them who belonged to the farm, Sethe the only female."
181,"Mrs. Garner, crying like a baby, had sold his brother to pay off the debts that surfaced the minute she was widowed."
182,Then schoolteacher arrived to put things in order.
183,"But what he did broke three more Sweet Home men and punched the glittering iron out of Sethe's eyes, leaving two open wells that did not reflect firelight."
184,"Now the iron was back but the face, softened by hair, made him trust her enough to step inside her door smack into a pool of pulsing red light."
185,She was right.
186,It was sad.
187,"Walking through it, a wave of grief soaked him so thoroughly he wanted to cry."
188,"It seemed a long way to the normal light surrounding the table, but he made it--dry-eyed and lucky."
189,"""You said she died soft. Soft as cream,"" he reminded her."
190,"""That's not Baby Suggs,"" she said."
192,"""She didn't live?"""
193,"""My daughter. The one I sent ahead with the boys."""
194,The one I was carrying when I run away is all I got left.
195,Boys gone too.
196,Both of em walked off just before Baby Suggs died.
197,Paul D looked at the spot where the grief had soaked him.
198,The red was gone but a kind of weeping clung to the air where it had been.
199,"Probably best, he thought."
200,If a Negro got legs he ought to use them.
201,"Sit down too long, somebody will figure out a way to tie them up."
202,Still... if her boys were gone...
203,"""No man? You here by yourself?"""
204,"""Me and Denver,"" she said."
205,"""That all right by you?"""
206,"""That's all right by me."""
207,She saw his skepticism and went on.
208,"""I cook at a restaurant in town. And I sew a little on the sly."""
209,"Paul D smiled then, remembering the bedding dress."
210,Sethe was thirteen when she came to Sweet Home and already iron-eyed.
211,She was a timely present for Mrs. Garner who had lost Baby Suggs to her husband's high principles.
212,The five Sweet Home men looked at the new girl and decided to let her be.
213,They were young and so sick with the absence of women they had taken to calves.
214,"Yet they let the iron-eyed girl be, so she could choose in spite of the fact that each one would have beaten the others to mush to have her."

215,"It took her a year to choose--a long, tough year of thrashing on pallets eaten up with dreams of her. A year of yearning, when rape seemed the solitary gift of life. The restraint they had exercised possible only because they were Sweet Home men--the ones Mr. Garner bragged about while other farmers shook their"
216,heads in warning at the phrase.
217,"""Y'all got boys,"" he told them."
218,"""Young boys, old boys, picky boys, stroppin boys. Now at Sweet Home, my niggers is men every one of em. Bought em thataway, raised em thataway. Men every one."""
219,"""Beg to differ, Garner. Ain't no nigger men."""
220,"""Not if you scared, they ain't."""
221,Garner's smile was wide.
222,"""But if you a man yourself, you'll want your niggers to be men too."""
223,"""I wouldn't have no nigger men round my wife."""
224,It was the reaction Garner loved and waited for.
225,"""Neither would I,"" he said."
226,"""Neither would I,"" and there was always a pause before the neighbor, or stranger, or peddler, or brother-in-law or whoever it was got the meaning."

227,"Then a fierce argument, sometimes a fight, and Garner came home bruised and pleased, having demonstrated one more time what a real Kentuckian was: one tough enough and smart enough to make and call his own niggers men."
228,"And so they were: Paul D Garner, Paul F Garner, Paul A Garner, Halle Suggs and Sixo, the wild man."

229,"All in their twenties, minus women, fucking cows, dreaming of rape, thrashing on pallets, rubbing their thighs and waiting for the new girl--the one who took Baby Suggs' place after Halle bought her with five years of Sundays."
230,Maybe that was why she chose him.
231,A twenty-year-old man so in love with his mother he gave up five years of Sabbaths just to see her sit down for a change was a serious recommendation.
232,She waited a year.
233,And the Sweet Home men abused cows while they waited with her.
234,She chose Halle and for their first bedding she sewed herself a dress on the sly.
235,"""Won't you stay on awhile? Can't nobody catch up on eighteen years in a day."""
236,"Out of the dimness of the room in which they sat, a white staircase climbed"
237,toward the blue-and-white wallpaper of the second floor.
238,Paul D could see just the beginning of the paper; discreet flecks of yellow sprinkled among a blizzard of snowdrops all backed by blue.
239,The luminous white of the railing and steps kept him glancing toward it.
240,Every sense he had told him the air above the stairwell was charmed and very thin.
241,But the girl who walked down out of that air was round and brown with the face of an alert doll.
242,"Paul D looked at the girl and then at Sethe who smiled saying, ""Here she is my Denver. This is Paul D, honey, from Sweet Home."""
243,"""Good morning, Mr. D."""
244,"""Garner, baby. Paul D Garner."""
246,"""Glad to get a look at you. Last time I saw your mama, you were pushing out the front of her dress."""
247,"""Still is,"" Sethe smiled, ""provided she can get in it."""
248,Denver stood on the bottom step and was suddenly hot and shy.
249,"It had been a long time since anybody (good-willed whitewoman, preacher, speaker or newspaperman) sat at their table, their sympathetic voices called liar by the revulsion in their eyes."
250,"For twelve years, long before Grandma Baby died, there had been no visitors of any sort and certainly no friends."
251,No coloredpeople.
252,"Certainly no hazelnut man with too long hair and no notebook, no charcoal, no oranges, no questions."
253,Someone her mother wanted to talk to and would even consider talking to while barefoot.
254,"Looking, in fact acting, like a girl instead of the quiet, queenly woman Denver had known all her life."

255,"The one who never looked away, who when a man got stomped to death by a mare right in front of Sawyer's restaurant did not look away; and when a sow began eating her own litter did not look away then either."
256,And when the baby's spirit picked up Here Boy and slammed him into
257,"the wall hard enough to break two of his legs and dislocate his eye, so hard he went into convulsions and chewed up his tongue, still her mother had not looked away."
258,"She had taken a hammer, knocked the dog unconscious, wiped away the blood and saliva, pushed his eye back in his head and set his leg bones."
259,"He recovered, mute and off-balance, more because of his untrustworthy eye than his bent legs, and winter, summer, drizzle or dry, nothing could persuade him to enter the house again."
260,Now here was this woman with the presence of mind to repair a dog gone savage with pain rocking her crossed ankles and looking away from her own daughter's body.
261,As though the size of it was more than vision could bear.
262,And neither she nor he had on shoes.
263,"Hot, shy, now Denver was lonely."
264,"All that leaving: first her brothers, then her grandmother--serious losses since there were no children willing to circle her in a game or hang by their knees from her porch railing."
265,"None of that had mattered as long as her mother did not look away as she was doing now, making Denver long, downright long, for a sign of spite from the baby ghost."
266,"""She's a fine-looking young lady,"" said Paul D. ""Fine-looking."
267,Got her daddy's sweet face.
268,"""You know my father?"""
269,"""Knew him. Knew him well."""
270,"""Did he, Ma'am?"""
271,Denver fought an urge to realign her affection.
272,"""Of course he knew your daddy. I told you, he's from Sweet Home."""
273,Denver sat down on the bottom step.
274,There was nowhere else gracefully to go.
275,"They were a twosome, saying ""Your daddy"" and ""Sweet Home"" in a way that made it clear both belonged to them and not to her."
276,That her own father's absence was not hers.
277,"Once the absence had belonged to Grandma Baby--a son, deeply mourned because he was the one who had bought her out of there."
278,Then it was her mother's absent husband.
279,Now it was this hazelnut stranger's absent friend.
280,"Only those who knew him (""knew him well"") could"
281,claim his absence for themselves.
282,"Just as only those who lived in Sweet Home could remember it, whisper it and glance sideways at one another while they did."
283,Again she wished for the baby ghost--its anger thrilling her now where it used to wear her out.
284,Wear her out.
285,"""We have a ghost in here,"" she said, and it worked."
286,They were not a twosome anymore.
287,Her mother left off swinging her feet and being girlish.
288,Memory of Sweet Home dropped away from the eyes of the man she was being girlish for.
289,He looked quickly up the lightning-white stairs behind her.
290,"""So I hear,"" he said."
291,"""But sad, your mama said. Not evil."""
292,"""No sir,"" said Denver, ""not evil. But not sad either."""
293,"""What then?"""
294,"""Rebuked. Lonely and rebuked."""
295,"""Is that right?"""
296,Paul D turned to Sethe.
297,"""I don't know about lonely,"" said Denver's mother."
298,"""Mad, maybe, but I don't see how it could be lonely spending every minute with us like it does."""
299,"""Must be something you got it wants."""
300,Sethe shrugged.
301,"""It's just a baby."""
302,"""My sister,"" said Denver."
303,"""She died in this house."""
304,Paul D scratched the hair under his jaw.
305,"""Reminds me of that headless bride back behind Sweet Home. Remember that, Sethe? Used to roam them woods regular."""
306,"""How could I forget? Worrisome..."""
307,"""How come everybody run off from Sweet Home can't stop talking about it? Look like if it was so sweet you would have stayed."""
308,"""Girl, who you talking to?"""
309,Paul D laughed.
310,"""True, true. She's right, Sethe. It wasn't sweet and it sure wasn't home."""
311,He shook his head.
312,"""But it's where we were,"" said Sethe."
313,"""All together. Comes back whether we want it to or not."""
314,She shivered a little.
315,"A light ripple of skin on her arm, which she caressed back into sleep."
316,"""Denver,"" she said, ""start up that stove. Can't have a friend stop by and don't feed him."""
317,"""Don't go to any trouble on my account,"" Paul D said."
318,"""Bread ain't trouble."
319,The rest I brought back from where I work.
320,"Least I can do, cooking from dawn to noon, is bring dinner home."
321,"You got any objections to pike?"""
322,"""If he don't object to me I don't object to him."""
323,"At it again, thought Denver."
324,"Her back to them, she jostled the kindlin and almost lost the fire."
325,"""Why don't you spend the night, Mr. Garner? You and Ma'am can talk about Sweet Home all night long."""
326,"Sethe took two swift steps to the stove, but before she could yank Denver's collar, the girl leaned forward and began to cry."
327,"""What is the matter with you? I never knew you to behave this way."""
328,"""Leave her be,"" said Paul D. ""I'm a stranger to her."""
329,"""That's just it. She got no cause to act up with a stranger. Oh baby, what is it? Did something happen?"""
330,But Denver was shaking now and sobbing so she could not speak.
331,The tears she had not shed for nine years wetting her far too womanly breasts.
332,"""I can't no more. I can't no more."""
333,"""Can't what? What can't you?"""
334,"""I can't live here. I don't know where to go or what to do, but I can't live here. Nobody speaks to us. Nobody comes by. Boys don't like me. Girls don't either."""
335,"""Honey, honey."""
336,"""What's she talking 'bout nobody speaks to you?"" asked Paul D."
337,"""It's the house. People don't--"""
338,"""It's not! It's not the house. It's us! And it's you!"""
340,"""Leave off, Sethe. It's hard for a young girl living in a haunted house. That can't be easy."""
341,"""It's easier than some other things."""
342,"""Think, Sethe."
343,I'm a grown man with nothing new left to see or do and I'm telling you it ain't easy.
344,Maybe you all ought to move.
345,Over Denver's shoulder Sethe shot Paul D a look of snow.
346,"""What you care?"""
347,"Who owns this house?"""
348,"""They won't let you leave?"""
350,"""No moving. No leaving. It's all right the way it is."""
351,"""You going to tell me it's all right with this child half out of her mind?"""
352,"Something in the house braced, and in the listening quiet that followed Sethe"
353,spoke.
354,"""I got a tree on my back and a haint in my house, and nothing in between but the daughter I am holding in my arms."
355,No more running--from nothing.
356,I will never run from another thing on this earth.
357,"I took one journey and I paid for the ticket, but let me tell you something, Paul D Garner: it cost too much!"
358,Do you hear me?
359,It cost too much.
360,Now sit down and eat with us or leave us be.

361,Paul D fished in his vest for a little pouch of tobacco--concentrating on its contents and the knot of its string while Sethe led Denver into the keeping room that opened off the large room he was sitting in.
362,"He had no smoking papers, so he fiddled with the pouch and listened through the open door to Sethe quieting her daughter."
363,When she came back she avoided his look and went straight to a small table next to the stove.
364,Her back was to him and he could see all the hair he wanted without the distraction of her face.
365,"""What tree on your back?"""
367,Sethe put a bowl on the table and reached under it for flour.
368,"""What tree on your back?"
369,Is something growing on your back?
370,I don't see nothing growing on your back.
371,"""It's there all the same."""
372,"""Who told you that?"""
373,"""Whitegirl."
374,That's what she called it.
375,I've never seen it and never will.
376,But that's what she said it looked like.
377,A chokecherry tree.
378,"Trunk, branches, and even leaves."
379,Tiny little chokecherry leaves.
380,But that was eighteen years ago.
381,Could have cherries too now for all I know.
382,Sethe took a little spit from the tip of her tongue with her forefinger.
383,"Quickly, lightly she touched the stove."
384,Then she trailed her fingers through
385,"the flour, parting, separating small hills and ridges of it, looking for mites."
386,"Finding none, she poured soda and salt into the crease of her folded hand and tossed both into the flour."
387,Then she reached into a can and scooped half a handful of lard.
388,"Deftly she squeezed the flour through it, then with her left hand sprinkling water, she formed the dough."
389,"""I had milk,"" she said."
390,"""I was pregnant with Denver but I had milk for my baby girl. I hadn't stopped nursing her when I sent her on ahead with Howard and Buglar."""
391,Now she rolled the dough out with a wooden pin.

392,"""Anybody could smell me long before he saw me. And when he saw me he'd see the drops of it on the front of my dress. Nothing I could do about that. All I knew was I had to get my milk to my baby girl. Nobody was going to nurse her like me. Nobody was going to get it to her fast enough, or take it away when she had enough and didn't know it. Nobody knew that she couldn't pass her air if you held her up on your shoulder, only if she was lying on my knees. Nobody knew that but me and nobody had her milk but me. I told that to the women in the wagon. Told them to put sugar water in cloth to suck from so when I got there in a few days she wouldn't have forgot me. The milk would be there and I would be there with it."""
393,"""Men don't know nothing much,"" said Paul D, tucking his pouch back into his vest pocket, ""but they do know a suckling can't be away from its mother for long."""
394,"""Then they know what it's like to send your children off when your breasts are full."""
395,"""We was talking 'bout a tree, Sethe."""
396,"""After I left you, those boys came in there and took my milk."
397,That's what they came in there for.
398,Held me down and took it.
399,I told Mrs. Garner on em.
400,She had that lump and couldn't speak but her eyes rolled out tears.
401,Them boys found out I told on em.
402,"Schoolteacher made one open up my back, and when it closed it made a tree."
403,It grows there still.
404,"""They used cowhide on you?"""
405,"""And they took my milk."""
406,"""They beat you and you was pregnant?"""
407,"""And they took my milk!"""
408,The fat white circles of dough lined the pan in rows.
409,Once more Sethe touched a wet forefinger to the stove.
410,She opened the oven door and slid the pan of biscuits in.
411,As she raised up from the heat she felt Paul D behind her and his hands under her breasts.
412,"She straightened up and knew, but could not feel, that his cheek was pressing into the branches of her chokecherry tree."
413,"Not even trying, he had become the kind of man who could walk into a house and make the women cry."
414,"Because with him, in his presence, they could."
415,There was something blessed in his manner.

416,"Women saw him and wanted to weep--to tell him that their chest hurt and their knees did too. Strong women and wise saw him and told him things they only told each other: that way past the Change of Life, desire in them had suddenly become enormous, greedy, more savage than when they were fifteen, and that it embarrassed them and made them sad; that secretly they longed to die--to be quit of it--that sleep was more precious to them than any waking day."
417,Young girls sidled up to him to confess or describe how well- dressed the visitations were that had followed them straight from their dreams.
418,"Therefore, although he did not understand why this was so, he was not surprised when Denver dripped tears into the stovefire."
419,"Nor, fifteen minutes later, after telling him about her stolen milk, her mother wept as well."
420,"Behind her, bending down, his body an arc of kindness, he held her breasts in the palms of his hands."
421,"He rubbed his cheek on her back and learned that way her sorrow, the roots of it; its wide trunk and intricate branches."
422,"Raising his fingers to the hooks of her dress, he knew without seeing them or hearing any sigh that the tears were coming fast."
423,"And when the top of her dress was around her hips and he saw the sculpture her back had become, like the decorative work of an ironsmith too passionate for display, he could think but"
424,"not say, ""Aw, Lord, girl."""
425,"And he would tolerate no peace until he had touched every ridge and leaf of it with his mouth, none of which Sethe could feel because her back skin had been dead for years."
426,"What she knew was that the responsibility for her breasts, at last, was in somebody else's hands."

427,"Would there be a little space, she wondered, a little time, some way to hold off eventfulness, to push busyness into the corners of the room and just stand there a minute or two, naked from shoulder blade to waist, relieved of the weight of her breasts, smelling the stolen milk again and the pleasure of baking bread?"
428,Maybe this one time she could stop dead still in the middle of a cooking meal--not even leave the stove--and feel the hurt her back ought to.
429,Trust things and remember things because the last of the Sweet Home men was there to catch her if she sank?
430,The stove didn't shudder as it adjusted to its heat.
431,Denver wasn't stirring in the next room.
432,The pulse of red light hadn't come back and Paul D had not trembled since and then for eighty-three days in a row.
433,"Locked up and chained down, his hands shook so bad he couldn't smoke or even scratch properly."
434,Now he was trembling again but in the legs this time.
435,"It took him a while to realize that his legs were not shaking because of worry, but because the floorboards were and the grinding, shoving floor was only part of it."
436,The house itself was pitching.
437,Sethe slid to the floor and struggled to get back into her dress.
438,"While down on all fours, as though she were holding her house down on the ground, Denver burst from the keeping room, terror in her eyes, a vague smile on her lips."
439,"""God damn it! Hush up!"""
440,"Paul D was shouting, falling, reaching for anchor."
441,"""Leave the place alone! Get the hell out!"""
442,A table rushed toward him and he grabbed its leg.
443,"Somehow he managed to stand at an angle and, holding the table by two legs, he bashed it about, wrecking everything, screaming back at the screaming house."
444,"""You want to fight, come on!"
445,God damn it!
446,She got enough without you.
447,"She got enough!"""
448,"The quaking slowed to an occasional lurch, but Paul D did not stop whipping the table around until everything was rock quiet."
449,"Sweating and breathing hard, he leaned against the wall in the space the sideboard left."
450,"Sethe was still crouched next to the stove, clutching her salvaged shoes to her chest."
451,"The three of them, Sethe, Denver, and Paul D, breathed to the same beat, like one tired person."
452,Another breathing was just as tired.
453,It was gone.
454,Denver wandered through the silence to the stove.
455,She ashed over the fire and pulled the pan of biscuits from the oven.
456,"The jelly cupboard was on its back, its contents lying in a heap in the corner of the bottom shelf."
457,"She took out a jar, and, looking around for a plate, found half of one by the door."
458,"These things she carried out to the porch steps, where she sat down."
459,The two of them had gone up there.
460,"Stepping lightly, easy-footed, they had climbed the white stairs, leaving her down below."
461,She pried the wire from the top of the jar and then the lid.
462,Under it was cloth and under that a thin cake of wax.
463,She removed it all and coaxed the jelly onto one half of the half a plate.
464,She took a biscuit and pulled off its black top.
465,Smoke curled from the soft white insides.
466,She missed her brothers.
467,Buglar and Howard would be twenty two and twenty-three now.

468,"Although they had been polite to her during the quiet time and gave her the whole top of the bed, she remembered how it was before: the pleasure they had sitting clustered on the white stairs--she between the knees of Howard or Buglar--while they made up die-witch! stories with proven ways of killing her dead."
469,And Baby Suggs telling her things in the keeping room.
470,"She smelled like bark in the day and leaves at night, for Denver would not sleep in her old room after her brothers ran away."
471,Now her mother was upstairs with the man who had gotten rid of the only other company she had.
472,Denver dipped a bit of bread into the jelly.
473,"Slowly, methodically, miserably she ate it."
474,"NOT QUITE in a hurry, but losing no time, Sethe and Paul D climbed the white stairs."
475,"Overwhelmed as much by the downright luck of finding her house and her in it as by the certainty of giving her his sex, Paul D dropped twenty-five years from his recent memory."
476,"A stair step before him was Baby Suggs' replacement, the new girl they dreamed of at night and fucked cows for at dawn while waiting for her to choose."
477,"Merely kissing the wrought iron on her back had shook the house, had made it necessary for him to beat it to pieces."
478,Now he would do more.
479,"She led him to the top of the stairs, where light came straight from the sky because the second-story windows of that house had been placed in the pitched ceiling and not the walls."

480,"There were two rooms and she took him into one of them, hoping he wouldn't mind the fact that she was not prepared; that though she could remember desire, she had forgotten how it worked; the clutch and helplessness that resided in the hands; how blindness was altered so that what leapt to the eye were places to lie down, and all else--door knobs, straps, hooks, the sadness that crouched in corners, and the passing of time--was interference."
481,It was over before they could get their clothes off.
482,"Half-dressed and short of breath, they lay side by side resentful of one another and the skylight above them."
483,His dreaming of her had been too long and too long ago.
484,Her deprivation had been not having any dreams of her own at all.
485,Now they were sorry and too shy to make talk.
486,"Sethe lay on her back, her head turned from him."

487,"Out of the corner of his eye, Paul D saw the float of her breasts and disliked it, the spread-away, flat roundness of them that he could definitely live without, never mind that downstairs he had held them as though they were the most expensive part of himself."
488,And the wrought-iron maze he had explored in the kitchen like a gold miner pawing through pay dirt was in fact a revolting clump of scars.
489,"Not a tree, as she said."
490,"Maybe shaped like one, but nothing like any tree he"
491,knew because trees were inviting; things you could trust and be near; talk to if you wanted to as he frequently did since way back when he took the midday meal in the fields of Sweet Home.
492,"Always in the same place if he could, and choosing the place had been hard because Sweet Home had more pretty trees than any farm around."
493,"His choice he called Brother, and sat under it, alone sometimes, sometimes with Halle or the other Pauls, but more often with Sixo, who was gentle then and still speaking English."

494,"Indigo with a flame-red tongue, Sixo experimented with night-cooked potatoes, trying to pin down exactly when to put smoking-hot rocks in a hole, potatoes on top, and cover the whole thing with twigs so that by the time they broke for the meal, hitched the animals, left the field and got to Brother, the potatoes would be at the peak of perfection."

495,"He might get up in the middle of the night, go all the way out there, start the earth-over by starlight; or he would make the stones less hot and put the next day's potatoes on them right after the meal."
496,"He never got it right, but they ate those undercooked, overcooked, dried-out or raw potatoes anyway, laughing, spitting and giving him advice."
497,"Time never worked the way Sixo thought, so of course he never got it right."
498,Once he plotted down to the minute a thirty-mile trip to see a woman.

499,"He left on a Saturday when the moon was in the place he wanted it to be, arrived at her cabin before church on Sunday and had just enough time to say good morning before he had to start back again so he'd make the field call on time Monday morning."
500,"He had walked for seventeen hours, sat down for one, turned around and walked seventeen more."
501,Halle and the Pauls spent the whole day covering Sixo's fatigue from Mr. Garner.
502,"They ate no potatoes that day, sweet or white."
503,"Sprawled near Brother, his flame-red tongue hidden from them, his indigo face closed, Sixo slept through dinner like a corpse."
504,"Now there was a man, and that was a tree."
505,"Himself lying in the bed and the ""tree"" lying next to him didn't compare."
506,Paul D looked through the window above his feet and folded his hands behind his head.
507,An elbow grazed Sethe's shoulder.
508,The touch of cloth on her skin startled her.
509,She had forgotten he had not taken off his shirt.
510,"Dog, she thought, and then remembered that she had not allowed him the time for taking it off."

511,"Nor herself time to take off her petticoat, and considering she had begun undressing before she saw him on the porch, that her shoes and stockings were already in her hand and she had never put them back on; that"

512,"he had looked at her wet bare feet and asked to join her; that when she rose to cook he had undressed her further; considering how quickly they had started getting naked, you'd think by now they would be."
513,"But maybe a man was nothing but a man, which is what Baby Suggs always said."

514,"They encouraged you to put some of your weight in their hands and soon as you felt how light and lovely that was, they studied your scars and tribulations, after which they did what he had done: ran her children out and tore up the house."
515,"She needed to get up from there, go downstairs and piece it all back together."
516,This house he told her to leave as though a house was a little thing--a shirtwaist or a sewing basket you could walk off from or give away any old time.

517,"She who had never had one but this one; she who left a dirt floor to come to this one; she who had to bring a fistful of salsify into Mrs. Garner's kitchen every day just to be able to work in it, feel like some part of it was hers, because she wanted to love the work she did, to take the ugly out of it, and the only way she could feel at home on Sweet Home was if she picked some pretty growing thing and took it with her."
518,The day she forgot was the day butter wouldn't come or the brine in the barrel blistered her arms.
519,At least it seemed so.

520,"A few yellow flowers on the table, some myrtle tied around the handle of the flatiron holding the door open for a breeze calmed her, and when Mrs. Garner and she sat down to sort bristle, or make ink, she felt fine."
521,Fine.
522,Not scared of the men beyond.
523,"The five who slept in quarters near her, but never came in the night."
524,Just touched their raggedy hats when they saw her and stared.
525,"And if she brought food to them in the fields, bacon and bread wrapped in a piece of clean sheeting, they never took it from her hands."
526,They stood back and waited for her to put it on the ground (at the foot of a tree) and leave.
527,"Either they did not want to take anything from her, or did not want her to see them eat."
528,Twice or three times she lingered.
529,Hidden behind honeysuckle she watched them.
530,"How different they were without her, how they laughed and played and urinated and sang."
531,"All but Sixo, who laughed once--at the very end."
532,"Halle, of course, was the nicest."
533,"Baby Suggs' eighth and last child, who rented himself out all over the county to buy her away from there."
534,"But he too, as it turned out, was nothing but a man."
535,"""A man ain't nothing but a man,"" said Baby Suggs."
536,"""But a son?"
537,"Well now, that's somebody."
538,"It made sense for a lot of reasons because in all of Baby's life, as well as Sethe's own, men and women were moved around like checkers."
539,"Anybody Baby Suggs knew, let alone loved, who hadn't run off or been hanged, got rented out, loaned out, bought up, brought back, stored up, mortgaged, won, stolen or seized."
540,So Baby's eight children had six fathers.
541,What she called the nastiness of life was the shock she received upon learning that nobody stopped playing checkers just because the pieces included her children.
542,Halle she was able to keep the longest.
543,Twenty years.
544,A lifetime.
545,"Given to her, no doubt, to make up for hearing that her two girls, neither of whom had their adult teeth, were sold and gone and she had not been able to wave goodbye."

546,"To make up for coupling with a straw boss for four months in exchange for keeping her third child, a boy, with her--only to have him traded for lumber in the spring of the next year and to find herself pregnant by the man who promised not to and did."
547,That child she could not love and the rest she would not.
548,"""God take what He would,"" she said."
549,"And He did, and He did, and He did and then gave her Halle who gave her freedom when it didn't mean a thing."
550,"Sethe had the amazing luck of six whole years of marriage to that ""somebody"" son who had fathered every one of her children."
551,"A blessing she was reckless enough to take for granted, lean on, as though Sweet Home really was one."
552,As though a handful of myrtle stuck in the handle of a pressing iron propped against the door in a whitewoman's kitchen could make it hers.
553,As though mint sprig in the mouth changed the breath as well as its odor.
554,A bigger fool never lived.
555,Sethe started to turn over on her stomach but changed her mind.
556,"She did not want to call Paul D's attention back to her, so she settled for crossing her ankles."
557,But Paul D noticed the movement as well as the change in her breathing.
558,"He felt obliged to try again, slower this time, but the appetite was gone."
559,Actually it was a good feeling--not wanting her.
560,Twenty-five years and blip!
561,The kind of thing Sixo would do--like the time
562,he arranged a meeting with Patsy the Thirty-Mile Woman.
563,It took three months and two thirty-four-mile round trips to do it.
564,"To persuade her to walk one-third of the way toward him, to a place he knew."
565,A deserted stone structure that Redmen used way back when they thought the land was theirs.
566,"Sixo discovered it on one of his night creeps, and asked its permission to enter."
567,"Inside, having felt what it felt like, he asked the Redmen's Presence if he could bring his woman there."
568,"It said yes and Sixo painstakingly instructed her how to get there, exactly when to start out, how his welcoming or warning whistles would sound."
569,"Since neither could go anywhere on business of their own, and since the Thirty-Mile Woman was already fourteen and scheduled for somebody's arms, the danger was real."
570,"When he arrived, she had not."
571,He whistled and got no answer.
572,He went into the Redmen's deserted lodge.
573,She was not there.
574,He returned to the meeting spot.
575,She was not there.
576,He waited longer.
577,She still did not come.
578,He grew frightened for her and walked down the road in the direction she should be coming from.
579,"Three or four miles, and he stopped."
580,"It was hopeless to go on that way, so he stood in the wind and asked for help."
581,"Listening close for some sign, he heard a whimper."
582,"He turned toward it, waited and heard it again."
583,"Uncautious now, he hollered her name."
584,She answered in a voice that sounded like life to him--not death.
585,"""Not move!"" he shouted."
586,"""Breathe hard I can find you."""
587,He did.
588,She believed she was already at the meeting place and was crying because she thought he had not kept his promise.
589,"Now it was too late for the rendezvous to happen at the Redmen's house, so they dropped where they were."
590,Later he punctured her calf to simulate snakebite so she could use it in some way as an excuse for not being on time to shake worms from tobacco leaves.
591,"He gave her detailed directions about following the stream as a shortcut back, and saw her off."
592,When he got to the road it was very light and he had his clothes in his hands.
593,Suddenly from around a bend a wagon trundled toward him.
594,"Its driver, wide-eyed, raised a whip while the woman seated beside him covered her face."
595,But Sixo had already melted into the woods before the lash could unfurl itself on his indigo behind.
596,"He told the story to Paul F, Halle, Paul A and Paul D in the peculiar way that"
597,made them cry-laugh.
598,Sixo went among trees at night.
599,"For dancing, he said, to keep his bloodlines open, he said."
600,"Privately, alone, he did it."
601,"None of the rest of them had seen him at it, but they could imagine it, and the picture they pictured made them eager to laugh at him--in daylight, that is, when it was safe."
602,But that was before he stopped speaking English because there was no future in it.
603,Because of the Thirty-Mile Woman Sixo was the only one not paralyzed by yearning for Sethe.
604,Nothing could be as good as the sex with her Paul D had been imagining off and on for twenty-five years.
605,"His foolishness made him smile and think fondly of himself as he turned over on his side, facing her."
606,"Sethe's eyes were closed, her hair a mess."
607,"Looked at this way, minus the polished eyes, her face was not so attractive."
608,So it must have been her eyes that kept him both guarded and stirred up.
609,Without them her face was manageable--a face he could handle.
610,Maybe if she would keep them closed like that...
611,"But no, there was her mouth."
612,Nice.
613,Halle never knew what he had.
614,"Although her eyes were closed, Sethe knew his gaze was on her face, and a paper picture of just how bad she must look raised itself up before her mind's eye."
615,"Still, there was no mockery coming from his gaze."
616,Soft.
617,It felt soft in a waiting kind of way.
618,He was not judging her--or rather he was judging but not comparing her.
619,"Not since Halle had a man looked at her that way: not loving or passionate, but interested, as though he were examining an ear of corn for quality."
620,Halle was more like a brother than a husband.
621,His care suggested a family relationship rather than a man's laying claim.
622,For years they saw each other in full daylight only on Sundays.
623,The rest of the time they spoke or touched or ate in darkness.
624,Predawn darkness and the afterlight of sunset.
625,So looking at each other intently was a Sunday morning pleasure and Halle examined her as though storing up what he saw in sunlight for the shadow he saw the rest of the week.
626,And he had so little time.
627,After his Sweet Home work and on Sunday afternoons was the debt work he owed for his mother.
628,"When he asked her to be his wife, Sethe happily agreed and then was stuck not knowing the next step."
629,"There should be a ceremony, shouldn't there?"
630,"A preacher, some dancing, a party, a something."
631,She and Mrs.
632,"Garner were the only women there, so she decided to ask her."
633,"""Halle and me want to be married, Mrs. Garner."""
634,"""So I heard."""
635,She smiled.
636,"""He talked to Mr. Garner about it. Are you already expecting?"""
639,"""Well, you will be. You know that, don't you?"""
640,"""Halle's nice, Sethe. He'll be good to you."""
641,"""But I mean we want to get married."""
642,"""You just said so. And I said all right."""
643,"""Is there a wedding?"""
644,Mrs. Garner put down her cooking spoon.
645,"Laughing a little, she touched Sethe on the head, saying, ""You are one sweet child."""
646,And then no more.
647,Sethe made a dress on the sly and Halle hung his hitching rope from a nail on the wall of her cabin.

648,"And there on top of a mattress on top of the dirt floor of the cabin they coupled for the third time, the first two having been in the tiny cornfield Mr. Garner kept because it was a crop animals could use as well as humans."
649,Both Halle and Sethe were under the impression that they were hidden.
650,"Scrunched down among the stalks they couldn't see anything, including the corn tops waving over their heads and visible to everyone else."
651,Sethe smiled at her and Halle's stupidity.
652,Even the crows knew and came to look.
653,"Uncrossing her ankles, she managed not to laugh aloud."
654,"The jump, thought Paul D, from a calf to a girl wasn't all that mighty."
655,Not the leap Halle believed it would be.
656,"And taking her in the corn rather than her quarters, a yard away from the cabins of the others who had lost out, was a gesture of tenderness."
657,Halle wanted privacy for her and got public display.
658,Who could miss a ripple in a cornfield on a quiet cloudless day?

659,"He, Sixo and both of the Pauls sat under Brother pouring water from a gourd over their heads, and through eyes streaming with well water, they watched the confusion of tassels in the field below."
660,"It had been hard, hard, hard sitting there erect as dogs, watching corn stalks dance at noon."
661,The water running over their heads made it worse.
662,Paul D sighed and turned over.
663,Sethe took the opportunity afforded by his movement to shift as well.
664,"Looking at Paul D's back, she remembered that some of the corn stalks broke, folded down over Halle's back, and among the things her fingers clutched were husk and cornsilk hair."
665,How loose the silk.
666,How jailed down the juice.
667,The jealous admiration of the watching men melted with the feast of new corn they allowed themselves that night.
668,Plucked from the broken stalks that Mr. Garner could not doubt was the fault of the raccoon.
669,Paul F wanted his roasted; Paul A wanted his boiled and now Paul D couldn't remember how finally they'd cooked those ears too young to eat.
670,"What he did remember was parting the hair to get to the tip, the edge of his fingernail just under, so as not to graze a single kernel."
671,"The pulling down of the tight sheath, the ripping sound always convinced her it hurt."
672,"As soon as one strip of husk was down, the rest obeyed and the ear yielded up to him its shy rows, exposed at last."
673,How loose the silk.
674,How quick the jailed- up flavor ran free.
675,"No matter what all your teeth and wet fingers anticipated, there was no accounting for the way that simple joy could shake you."
676,How loose the silk.
677,How fine and loose and free.
678,DENVER'S SECRETS were sweet.
679,Accompanied every time by wild veronica until she discovered cologne.
680,"The first bottle was a gift, the next she stole from her mother and hid among boxwood until it froze and cracked."
681,That was the year winter came in a hurry at suppertime and stayed eight months.
682,"One of the War years when Miss Bodwin, the whitewoman, brought Christmas cologne for her mother and herself, oranges for the boys and another good wool shawl for Baby Suggs."

683,"Talking of a war full of dead people, she looked happy--flush-faced, and although her voice was heavy as a man's, she smelled like a roomful of flowers--excitement that Denver could have all for herself in the boxwood."
684,Back beyond x was a narrow field that stopped itself at a wood.
685,"On the yonder side of these woods, a stream."

686,"In these woods, between the field and the stream, hidden by post oaks, five boxwood bushes, planted in a ring, had started stretching toward each other four feet off the ground to form a round, empty room seven feet high, its walls fifty inches of murmuring leaves."
687,"Bent low, Denver could crawl into this room, and once there she could stand all the way up in emerald light."
688,"It began as a little girl's houseplay, but as her desires changed, so did the play."
689,"Quiet, primate and completely secret except for the noisome cologne signal that thrilled the rabbits before it confused them."
690,"First a playroom (where the silence was softer), then a refuge (from her brothers' fright), soon the place became the point."
691,"In that bower, closed off from the hurt of the hurt world, Denver's imagination produced its own hunger and its own food, which she badly needed because loneliness wore her out."
692,Wore her out.
693,"Veiled and protected by the live green walls, she felt ripe and clear, and salvation was as easy as a wish."
694,"Once when she was in the boxwood, an autumn long before Paul D moved into the house with her mother, she was made suddenly cold by a combination of wind and the perfume on her skin."

695,"She dressed herself, bent down to leave and stood up in snowfall: a thin and whipping snow very like the picture her mother had painted as she described the circumstances of Denver's birth in a canoe straddled by a whitegirl for whom she was named."
696,"Shivering, Denver approached the house, regarding it, as she always did, as a person rather than a structure."
697,"A person that wept, sighed, trembled and fell into fits."
698,"Her steps and her gaze were the cautious ones of a child approaching a nervous, idle relative (someone dependent but proud)."
699,A breastplate of darkness hid all the windows except one.
700,Its dim glow came from Baby Suggs' room.
701,"When Denver looked in, she saw her mother on her knees in prayer, which was not unusual."

702,What was unusual (even for a girl who had lived all her life in a house peopled by the living activity of the dead) was that a white dress knelt down next to her mother and had its sleeve around her mother's waist.
703,"And it was the tender embrace of the dress sleeve that made Denver remember the details of her birth--that and the thin, whipping snow she was standing in, like the fruit of common flowers."
704,The dress and her mother together looked like two friendly grown-up women--one (the dress) helping out the other.
705,"And the magic of her birth, its miracle in fact, testified to that friendliness as did her own name."
706,Easily she stepped into the told story that lay before her eyes on the path she followed away from the window.

707,"There was only one door to the house and to get to it from the back you had to walk all the way around to the front of , past the storeroom, past the cold house, the privy, the shed, on around to the porch."

708,"And to get to the part of the story she liked best, she had to start way back: hear the birds in the thick woods, the crunch of leaves underfoot; see her mother making her way up into the hills where no houses were likely to be."
709,How Sethe was walking on two feet meant for standing still.
710,How they were so swollen she could not see her arch or feel her ankles.
711,Her leg shaft ended in a loaf of flesh scalloped by five toenails.
712,"But she could not, would not, stop, for when she did the little antelope rammed her with horns and pawed the ground of her womb with impatient hooves."
713,"While she was walking, it seemed to graze, quietly--so she walked, on two feet meant, in this sixth month of pregnancy, for standing still."
714,"Still, near a kettle; still, at the churn; still, at the tub and ironing board."
715,"Milk, sticky and sour on her dress, attracted every small flying thing from gnats to grasshoppers."
716,By the time she reached the hill skirt she had long ago stopped waving them off.
717,"The clanging in her head, begun as a churchbell heard from a distance,"
718,was by then a tight cap of pealing bells around her ears.
719,She sank and had to look down to see whether she was in a hole or kneeling.
720,Nothing was alive but her nipples and the little antelope.
721,"Finally, she was horizontal--or must have been because blades of wild onion were scratching her temple and her cheek."
722,"Concerned as she was for the life of her children's mother, Sethe told Denver, she remembered thinking: ""Well, at least I don't have to take another step."""
723,"A dying thought if ever there was one, and she waited for the little antelope to protest, and why she thought of an antelope Sethe could not imagine since she had never seen one."
724,"She guessed it must have been an invention held on to from before Sweet Home, when she was very young."
725,Of that place where she was born (Carolina maybe? or was it Louisiana?) she remembered only song and dance.

726,"Not even her own mother, who was pointed out to her by the eight-year-old child who watched over the young ones--pointed out as the one among many backs turned away from her, stooping in a watery field."
727,Patiently Sethe waited for this particular back to gain the row's end and stand.
728,"What she saw was a cloth hat as opposed to a straw one, singularity enough in that world of cooing women each of whom was called Ma'am."
729,"""Hold on to the baby."""
735,"""Get some kindlin in here."""
737,Oh but when they sang.
738,And oh but when they danced and sometimes they danced the antelope.
739,"The men as well as the ma'ams, one of whom was certainly her own."
740,They shifted shapes and became something other.
741,Some
742,"unchained, demanding other whose feet knew her pulse better than she did."
743,Just like this one in her stomach.
744,"""I believe this baby's ma'am is gonna die in wild onions on the bloody side of the Ohio River."""
745,That's what was on her mind and what she told Denver.
746,Her exact words.

747,"And it didn't seem such a bad idea, all in all, in view of the step she would not have to take, but the thought of herself stretched out dead while the little antelope lived on--an hour? a day? a day and a night?--in her lifeless body grieved her so she made the groan that made the person walking on a path not ten yards away halt and stand right still."
748,"Sethe had not heard the walking, but suddenly she heard the standing still and then she smelled the hair."
749,"The voice, saying, ""Who's in there?"" was all she needed to know that she was about to be discovered by a white boy."
750,"That he too had mossy teeth, an appetite."

751,"That on a ridge of pine near the Ohio River, trying to get to her three children, one of whom was starving for the food she carried; that after her husband had disappeared; that after her milk had been stolen, her back pulped, her children orphaned, she was not to have an easeful death."
752,"She told Denver that a something came up out of the earth into her--like a freezing, but moving too, like jaws inside."
753,"""Look like I was just cold jaws grinding,"" she said."
754,"Suddenly she was eager for his eyes, to bite into them; to gnaw his cheek."
755,"""I was hungry,"" she told Denver, ""just as hungry as I could be for his eyes. I couldn't wait."""
756,"So she raised up on her elbow and dragged herself, one pull, two, three, four, toward the young white voice talking about ""Who that back in there?"""
757,""" 'Come see,' I was thinking."
758,"'Be the last thing you behold,' and sure enough here come the feet so I thought well that's where I'll have to start God do what He would, I'm gonna eat his feet off."
759,"I'm laughing now, but it's true."
760,I wasn't just set to do it.
761,I was hungry to do it.
762,Like a snake.
763,All jaws and hungry.
764,"""It wasn't no whiteboy at all. Was a girl. The raggediest-looking trash you ever saw saying, 'Look there. A nigger. If that don't beat all.' """
765,And now the part Denver loved the best: Her name was Amy and she needed beef and pot liquor like nobody in this world.
766,Arms like cane stalks and enough hair for four or five heads.
767,Slow-moving eyes.
768,She didn't look at anything quick.
769,Talked so much it wasn't clear how she could breathe at the same time.
770,"And those cane-stalk arms, as it turned out, were as strong as iron."
771,"""You 'bout the scariest-looking something I ever seen. What you doing back up in here?"""
772,"Down in the grass, like the snake she believed she was, Sethe opened her mouth, and instead of fangs and a split tongue, out shot the truth."
773,"""Running,"" Sethe told her."
774,It was the first word she had spoken all day and it came out thick because of her tender tongue.
775,"""Them the feet you running on? My Jesus my."""
776,She squatted down and stared at Sethe's feet.
777,"""You got anything on you, gal, pass for food?"""
778,Sethe tried to shift to a sitting position but couldn t.
779,"""I like to die I'm so hungry."""
780,"The girl moved her eyes slowly, examining the greenery around her."
781,"""Thought there'd be huckleberries."
782,Look like it.
783,That's why I come up in here.
784,Didn't expect to find no nigger woman.
785,"If they was any, birds ate em."
786,"You like huckleberries?"""
787,"""I'm having a baby, miss."""
788,Amy looked at her.
789,"""That mean you don't have no appetite? Well I got to eat me something."""
790,"Combing her hair with her fingers, she carefully surveyed the landscape once more."
791,"Satisfied nothing edible was around, she stood up to go and Sethe's heart stood up too at the thought of being left alone in the grass without a fang in her head."
792,"""Where you on your way to, miss?"""
793,She turned and looked at Sethe with freshly lit eyes.
794,"""Boston. Get me some velvet. It's a store there called Wilson. I seen the pictures of it and they have the prettiest velvet. They don't believe I'm a get it, but I am."""
795,Sethe nodded and shifted her elbow.
796,"""Your ma'am know you on the lookout for velvet?"""
797,The girl shook her hair out of her face.

798,"""My mama worked for these here people to pay for her passage. But then she had me and since she died right after, well, they said I had to work for em to pay it off. I did, but now I want me some velvet."""
799,"They did not look directly at each other, not straight into the eyes anyway."
800,Yet they slipped effortlessly into yard chat about nothing in particular--except one lay on the ground.
801,"""Boston,"" said Sethe."
802,"""Is that far?"""
803,"""Ooooh, yeah. A hundred miles. Maybe more."""
804,"""Must be velvet closer by."""
805,"""Not like in Boston."
806,Boston got the best.
807,Be so pretty on me.
808,"You ever touch it?"""
809,"""No, miss. I never touched no velvet."""
810,"Sethe didn't know if it was the voice, or Boston or velvet, but while the whitegirl talked, the baby slept."
811,"Not one butt or kick, so she guessed her luck had turned."
812,"""Ever see any?"" she asked Sethe."
813,"""I bet you never even seen any."""
814,"""If I did I didn't know it. What's it like, velvet?"""
815,Amy dragged her eyes over Sethe's face as though she would never give out so confidential a piece of information as that to a perfect stranger.
816,"""What they call you?"" she asked."
817,"However far she was from Sweet Home, there was no point in giving out her real name to the first person she saw."
818,"""Lu,"" said Sethe."
819,"""They call me Lu."""

820,"""Well, Lu, velvet is like the world was just born. Clean and new and so smooth. The velvet I seen was brown, but in Boston they got all colors. Carmine. That means red but when you talk about velvet you got to say 'carmine.' """
821,"She raised her eyes to the sky and then, as though she had wasted enough time away from Boston, she moved off saying, ""I gotta go."""
822,"Picking her way through the brush she hollered back to Sethe, ""What you gonna do, just lay there and foal?"""
823,"""I can't get up from here,"" said Sethe."
825,She stopped and turned to hear.
826,"""I said I can't get up."""
827,Amy drew her arm across her nose and came slowly back to where Sethe lay.
828,"""It's a house back yonder,"" she said."
831,"""Mmmmm. I passed it. Ain't no regular house with people in it though. A lean-to, kinda."""
832,"""Make a difference, does it? You stay the night here snake get you."""
833,"""Well he may as well come on. I can't stand up let alone walk and God help me, miss, I can't crawl."""
834,"""Sure you can, Lu. Come on,"" said Amy and, with a toss of hair enough for five heads, she moved toward the path."
835,"So she crawled and Amy walked alongside her, and when Sethe needed to"
836,"rest, Amy stopped too and talked some more about Boston and velvet and good things to eat."
837,"The sound of that voice, like a sixteen-year-old boy's, going on and on and on, kept the little antelope quiet and grazing."
838,"During the whole hateful crawl to the lean to, it never bucked once."
839,Nothing of Sethe's was intact by the time they reached it except the cloth that covered her hair.
840,"Below her bloody knees, there was no feeling at all; her chest was two cushions of pins."

841,"It was the voice full of velvet and Boston and good things to eat that urged her along and made her think that maybe she wasn't, after all, just a crawling graveyard for a six-month baby's last hours."
842,"The lean-to was full of leaves, which Amy pushed into a pile for Sethe to lie on."
843,"Then she gathered rocks, covered them with more leaves and made Sethe put her feet on them, saying: ""I know a woman had her feet cut off they was so swole."""
844,And she made sawing gestures with the blade of her hand across Sethe's ankles.
845,"""Zzz Zzz Zzz Zzz."""
846,"""I used to be a good size."
847,Nice arms and everything.
848,"Wouldn't think it, would you?"
849,That was before they put me in the root cellar.
850,I was fishing off the Beaver once.
851,Catfish in Beaver River sweet as chicken.
852,"Well I was just fishing there and a nigger floated right by me. I don't like drowned people, you?"
853,Your feet remind me of him.
854,All swole like.
855,Then she did the magic: lifted Sethe's feet and legs and massaged them until she cried salt tears.
856,"""It's gonna hurt, now,"" said Amy."
857,"""Anything dead coming back to life hurts."""
858,"A truth for all times, thought Denver."
859,Maybe the white dress holding its arm around her mother's waist was in pain.
860,"If so, it could mean the baby ghost had plans."
861,"When she opened the door, Sethe was just leaving the keeping room."
862,"""I saw a white dress holding on to you,"" Denver said."
863,"""White? Maybe it was my bedding dress. Describe it to me."""
864,"""Had a high neck. Whole mess of buttons coming down the back."""
865,"""Buttons. Well, that lets out my bedding dress. I never had a button on nothing."""
866,"""Did Grandma Baby?"""
867,Sethe shook her head.
868,"""She couldn't handle them. Even on her shoes. What else?"""
869,"""A bunch at the back. On the sit-down part."""
870,"""A bustle? It had a bustle?"""
871,"""I don't know what it's called."""
872,"""Sort of gathered-like? Below the waist in the back?"""
874,"""A rich lady's dress. Silk?"""
875,"""Cotton, look like."""
876,"""Lisle probably. White cotton lisle. You say it was holding on to me. How?"""
877,"""Like you. It looked just like you. Kneeling next to you while you were praying. Had its arm around your waist."""
878,"""Well, I'll be."""
879,"""What were you praying for, Ma'am?"""
880,"""Not for anything. I don't pray anymore. I just talk."""
881,"""What were you talking about?"""
882,"""You won't understand, baby."""
883,"""Yes, I will."""
884,"""I was talking about time."
885,It's so hard for me to believe in it.
886,Some things go.
887,Pass on.
888,Some things just stay.
889,I used to think it was my rememory.
890,You know.
891,Some things you forget.
892,Other things you never do.
893,But it's not.
894,"Places, places are still there."
895,"If a house burns down, it's gone, but the place--the picture of it--stays, and not just in my rememory, but out there, in the world."
896,What I remember is a picture floating around out there outside my head.
897,"I mean, even if I don't think it, even if I die, the picture of what I did, or knew, or saw is still out there."
898,Right in the place where it happened.
899,"""Can other people see it?"" asked Denver."
901,"Oh, yes, yes, yes."
902,Someday you be walking down the road and you hear something or see something going on.
903,So clear.
904,And you think it's you thinking it up.
905,A thought picture.
906,But no.
907,It's when you bump into a rememory that belongs to somebody else.
908,"Where I was before I came here, that place is real."
909,It's never going away.
910,Even if the whole farm--every tree and grass blade of it dies.

911,"The picture is still there and what's more, if you go there--you who never was there--if you go there and stand in the place where it was, it will happen again; it will be there for you, waiting for you."
912,"So, Denver, you can't never go there."
913,Never.
914,Because even though it's all over--over and done with--it's going to always be there waiting for you.
915,That's how come I had to get all my children out.
916,No matter what.
917,Denver picked at her fingernails.
918,"""If it's still there, waiting, that must mean that nothing ever dies."""
919,Sethe looked right in Denver's face.
920,"""Nothing ever does,"" she said."
921,"""You never told me all what happened. Just that they whipped you and you run off, pregnant. With me."""
922,"""Nothing to tell except schoolteacher."
923,He was a little man.
924,Short.
925,"Always wore a collar, even in the fields."
926,"A schoolteacher, she said."
927,That made her feel good that her husband's sister's husband had book learning and was willing to come farm Sweet Home after Mr.
928,Garner passed.
929,"The men could have done it, even with Paul F sold."
930,But it was like Halle said.
931,She didn't want to be the only white person on the farm and a woman too.
932,So she was satisfied when the schoolteacher agreed to come.
933,He brought two boys with him.
934,Sons or nephews.
935,I don't know.
936,"They called him Onka and had pretty man ners, all of em."
937,Talked soft and spit in handkerchiefs.
938,Gentle in a lot of ways.
939,"You know, the kind who know Jesus by His first name, but out of politeness never use it even to His face."
940,"A pretty good farmer, Halle said."
941,Not strong as Mr. Garner but smart enough.
942,He liked the ink I made.
943,"It was her recipe, but he preferred how I mixed it and it was important to him because at night he sat down to write in his book."
944,It was a book about us but we didn't know that right away.
945,We just thought it was his manner to ask us questions.
946,He commenced to carry round a notebook and write down what we said.
947,I still think it was them questions that tore Sixo up.
948,Tore him up for all time.
949,She stopped.

950,"Denver knew that her mother was through with it--for now anyway. The single slow blink of her eyes; the bottom lip sliding up slowly to cover the top; and then a nostril sigh, like the snuff of a candle flame--signs that Sethe had reached the point beyond which she would not go."
951,"""Well, I think the baby got plans,"" said Denver."
952,"""What plans?"""
953,"""I don't know, but the dress holding on to you got to mean something."""
954,"""Maybe,"" said Sethe."
955,"""Maybe it does have plans."""
956,"Whatever they were or might have been, Paul D messed them up for good."
957,With a table and a loud male voice he had rid of its claim to local fame.
958,Denver had taught herself to take pride in the condemnation Negroes heaped on them; the assumption that the haunting was done by an evil thing looking for more.
959,"None of them knew the downright pleasure of enchantment, of not suspecting but knowing the things behind things."
960,"Her brothers had known, but it scared them; Grandma Baby knew, but it saddened her."
961,None could appreciate the safety of ghost company.
962,Even Sethe didn't love it.
963,She just took it for granted--like a sudden change in the weather.
964,But it was gone now.
965,"Whooshed away in the blast of a hazelnut man's shout, leaving Denver's world flat, mostly, with the exception of an emerald closet standing seven feet high in the woods."
966,Her mother had secrets--things she wouldn't tell; things she halfway told.
967,"Well, Denver had them too."
968,And hers were sweet--sweet as lily-of-the-valley cologne.
969,"Sethe had given little thought to the white dress until Paul D came, and then she remembered Denver's interpretation: plans."
970,"The morning after the first night with Paul D, Sethe smiled just thinking about what the word could mean."
971,It was a luxury she had not had in eighteen years and only that once.
972,"Before and since, all her effort was directed not on avoiding pain but on getting through it as quickly as possible."
973,The one set of plans she had made-- getting away from Sweet Home--went awry so completely she never dared life by making more.

974,"Yet the morning she woke up next to Paul D, the word her daughter had used a few years ago did cross her mind and she thought about what Denver had seen kneeling next to her, and thought also of the temptation to trust and remember that gripped her as she stood before the cooking stove in his arms."
975,Would it be all right?
976,Would it be all right to go ahead and feel?
977,Go ahead and count on something?
978,"She couldn't think clearly, lying next to him listening to his breathing, so carefully, carefully, she had left the bed."
979,Kneeling in the keeping room where she usually went to talk-think it was clear why Baby Suggs was so starved for color.
980,There wasn't any except for
981,two orange squares in a quilt that made the absence shout.

982,"The walls of the room were slate-colored, the floor earth-brown, the wooden dresser the color of itself, curtains white, and the dominating feature, the quilt over an iron cot, was made up of scraps of blue serge, black, brown and gray wool--the full range of the dark and the muted that thrift and modesty allowed. In that sober field, two patches of orange looked wild--like life in the raw."
983,"Sethe looked at her hands, her bottle-green sleeves, and thought how little color there was in the house and how strange that she had not missed it the way Baby did."
984,"Deliberate, she thought, it must be deliberate, because the last color she remembered was the pink chips in the headstone of her baby girl."
985,After that she became as color conscious as a hen.
986,"Every dawn she worked at fruit pies, potato dishes and vegetables while the cook did the soup, meat and all the rest."
987,And she could not remember remembering a molly apple or a yellow squash.
988,"Every dawn she saw the dawn, but never acknowledged or remarked its color."
989,There was something wrong with that.
990,"It was as though one day she saw red baby blood, another day the pink gravestone chips, and that was the last of it."
991,was so full of strong feeling perhaps she was oblivious to the loss of anything at all.
