992,There was a time when she scanned the fields every morning and every evening for her boys.
993,"When she stood at the open window, unmindful of flies, her head cocked to her left shoulder, her eyes searching to the right for them."
994,"Cloud shadow on the road, an old woman, a wandering goat untethered and gnawing bramble--each one looked at first like Howard-- no, Buglar."
995,"Little by little she stopped and their thirteen-year-old faces faded completely into their baby ones, which came to her only in sleep."
996,"When her dreams roamed outside , anywhere they wished, she saw them sometimes in beautiful trees, their little legs barely visible in the leaves."
997,"Sometimes they ran along the railroad track laughing, too loud, apparently, to hear her because they never did turn around."

998,"When she woke the house crowded in on her: there was the door where the soda crackers were lined up in a row; the white stairs her baby girl loved to climb; the corner where Baby Suggs mended shoes, a pile of which were still in the cold room; the exact place on the stove where Denver burned her fingers."
999,And of course the spite of the house itself.
1000,There was no room for any other thing or body until Paul
1001,"D arrived and broke up the place, making room, shifting it, moving it over to someplace else, then standing in the place he had made."
1002,"So, kneeling in the keeping room the morning after Paul D came, she was distracted by the two orange squares that signaled how barren really was."
1003,He was responsible for that.
1004,Emotions sped to the surface in his company.
1005,Things became what they were: drabness looked drab; heat was hot.
1006,Windows suddenly had view.
1007,And wouldn't you know he'd be a singing man.
1008,"Little rice, little bean,"
1009,No meat in between.
1010,"Hard work ain't easy,"
1011,Dry bread ain't greasy.
1012,He was up now and singing as he mended things he had broken the day before.
1013,Some old pieces of song he'd learned on the prison farm or in the War afterward.
1014,"Nothing like what they sang at Sweet Home, where yearning fashioned every note."
1015,The songs he knew from Georgia were flat-headed nails for pounding and pounding and pounding.
1016,"Lay my bead on the railroad line,"
1017,"Train come along, pacify my mind."
1018,"If I had my weight in lime,"
1019,I'd whip my captain till he went stone blind.
1020,"Five-cent nickel, Ten-cent dime,"
1021,Busting rocks is busting time.
1022,"But they didn't fit, these songs."
1023,"They were too loud, had too much power for the little house chores he was engaged in--resetting table legs; glazing."

1024,"He couldn't go back to ""Storm upon the Waters"" that they sang under the trees of Sweet Home, so he contented himself with mmmmmmmmm, throwing in a line if one occurred to him, and what occurred over and over was ""Bare feet and chamomile sap,/ Took off my shoes; took off my hat."""
1025,"It was tempting to change the words (Gimme back my shoes; gimme back my hat), because he didn't believe he could live with a woman--any woman--for over two out of three months."
1026,That was about as long as he could abide one place.

1027,"After Delaware and before that Alfred, Georgia, where he slept underground and crawled into sunlight for the sole purpose of breaking rock, walking off when he got ready was the only way he could convince himself that he would no longer have to sleep, pee, eat or swing a sledge hammer in chains."
1028,But this was not a normal woman in a normal house.
1029,"As soon as he had stepped through the red light he knew that, compared to , the rest of the world was bald."
1030,"After Alfred he had shut down a generous portion of his head, operating on the part that helped him walk, eat, sleep, sing."
1031,"If he could do those things--with a little work and a little sex thrown in--he asked for no more, for more required him to dwell on Halle's face and Sixo laughing."
1032,To recall trembling in a box built into the ground.
1033,Grateful for the daylight spent doing mule work in a quarry because he did not tremble when he had a hammer in his hands.
1034,"The box had done what Sweet Home had not, what working like an ass and living like a dog had not: drove him crazy so he would not lose his mind."
1035,"By the time he got to Ohio, then to Cincinnati, then to Halle Suggs' mother's house, he thought he had seen and felt it all."
1036,"Even now as he put back the window frame he had smashed, he could not account for the pleasure in his"
1037,"surprise at seeing Halle's wife alive, barefoot with uncovered hair--walking around the corner of the house with her shoes and stockings in her hands."
1038,The closed portion of his head opened like a greased lock.
1039,"""I was thinking of looking for work around here. What you think?"""
1040,"""Ain't much. River mostly. And hogs."""
1041,"""Well, I never worked on water, but I can pick up anything heavy as me, hogs included."""
1042,"""Whitepeople better here than Kentucky but you may have to scramble some."""
1043,"""It ain't whether I scramble; it's where. You saying it's all right to scramble here?"""
1044,"""Better than all right."""
1045,"""Why you say that?"""
1046,"""Your girl, Denver. Seems to me she's of a different mind."""
1047,"""She's got a waiting way about her. Something she's expecting and it ain't me."""
1048,"""I don't know what it could be."""
1049,"""Well, whatever it is, she believes I'm interrupting it."""
1050,"""Don't worry about her. She's a charmed child. From the beginning."""
1051,"""Is that right?"""
1053,Nothing bad can happen to her.
1054,Look at it.
1055,Everybody I knew dead or gone or dead and gone.
1056,Not her.
1057,Not my Denver.
1058,"Even when I was carrying her, when it got clear that I wasn't going to make it--which meant she wasn't going to make it either--she pulled a whitegirl out"
1059,of the hill.
1060,The last thing you'd expect to help.
1061,"And when the schoolteacher found us and came busting in here with the law and a shotgun--"""
1062,"""Schoolteacher found you?"""
1063,"""Took a while, but he did. Finally."""
1064,"""And he didn't take you back?"""
1066,I wasn't going back there.
1067,I don't care who found who.
1068,Any life but not that one.
1069,I went to jail instead.
1070,Denver was just a baby so she went right along with me.
1071,Rats bit everything in there but her.
1072,Paul D turned away.
1073,"He wanted to know more about it, but jail talk put him back in Alfred, Georgia."
1074,"""I need some nails. Anybody around here I can borrow from or should I go to town?"""
1075,"""May as well go to town. You'll need other things."""
1076,One night and they were talking like a couple.
1077,"They had skipped love and promise and went directly to ""You saying it's all right to scramble here?"""
1078,"To Sethe, the future was a matter of keeping the past at bay."
1079,"The ""better life"" she believed she and Denver were living was simply not that other one."
1080,"The fact that Paul D had come out of ""that other one"" into her bed was better too; and the notion of a future with him, or for that matter without him, was beginning to stroke her mind."
1081,"As for Denver, the job Sethe had of keeping her from the past that was still waiting for her was all that mattered."
1082,"PLEASANTLY TROUBLED, Sethe avoided the keeping room and Denver's sidelong looks."
1083,"As she expected, since life was like that--it didn't do any good."
1084,Denver ran a mighty interference and on the third day flat-out asked Paul D how long he was going to hang around.
1085,The phrase hurt him so much he missed the table.
1086,The coffee cup hit the floor and rolled down the sloping boards toward the front door.
1087,"""Hang around?"""
1088,Paul D didn't even look at the mess he had made.
1089,"""Denver! What's got into you?"""
1090,"Sethe looked at her daughter, feeling more embarrassed than angry."
1091,Paul D scratched the hair on his chin.
1092,"""Maybe I should make tracks."""
1093,Sethe was surprised by how loud she said it.
1094,"""He know what he needs,"" said Denver."
1095,"""Well, you don't,"" Sethe told her, ""and you must not know what you need either. I don't want to hear another word out of you."""
1096,"""I just asked if--"""
1097,"""Hush! You make tracks. Go somewhere and sit down."""
1098,Denver picked up her plate and left the table but not before adding a chicken back and more bread to the heap she was carrying away.
1099,Paul D leaned over to wipe the spilled coffee with his blue handkerchief.
1100,"""I'll get that."""
1101,Sethe jumped up and went to the stove.
1102,"Behind it various cloths hung, each in some stage of drying."
1103,In silence she wiped the floor and retrieved the cup.
1104,"Then she poured him another cupful, and set it carefully before him."
1105,"Paul D touched its rim but didn't say anything--as though even ""thank you"" was an obligation he could not meet and the coffee itself a gift he could not take."
1106,Sethe resumed her chair and the silence continued.
1107,Finally she realized that if it was going to be broken she would have to do it.
1108,"""I didn't train her like that."""
1109,Paul D stroked the rim of the cup.
1110,"""And I'm as surprised by her manners as you are hurt by em."""
1111,Paul D looked at Sethe.
1112,"""Is there history to her question?"""
1113,"""History? What you mean?"""
1114,"""I mean, did she have to ask that, or want to ask it, of anybody else before me?"""
1115,Sethe made two fists and placed them on her hips.
1116,"""You as bad as she is."""
1117,"""Come on, Sethe."""
1118,"""Oh, I am coming on. I am!"""
1119,"""You know what I mean."""
1120,"""I do and I don't like it."""
1121,"""Jesus,"" he whispered."
1123,Sethe was getting loud again.
1124,"""Jesus! I said Jesus! All I did was sit down for supper! and I get cussed out twice. Once for being here and once for asking why I was cussed in the first place!"""
1125,"""She didn't cuss."""
1126,"""No? Felt like it."""
1127,"""Look here. I apologize for her. I'm real--"""
1128,"""You can't do that. You can't apologize for nobody. She got to do that."""
1129,"""Then I'll see that she does."""
1130,Sethe sighed.
1131,"""What I want to know is, is she asking a question that's on your mind too?"""
1132,"""Oh no. No, Paul D. Oh no."""
1133,"""Then she's of one mind and you another? If you can call what ever's in her head a mind, that is."""
1134,"""Excuse me, but I can't hear a word against her."
1135,I'll chastise her.
1136,You leave her alone.
1137,"Risky, thought Paul D, very risky."
1138,"For a used-to-be-slave woman to love anything that much was dangerous, especially if it was her children she had settled on to love."

1139,"The best thing, he knew, was to love just a little bit; everything, just a little bit, so when they broke its back, or shoved it in a croaker sack, well, maybe you'd have a little love left over for the next one."
1140,"""Why?"" he asked her."
1141,"""Why you think you have to take up for her? Apologize for her? She's grown."""
1142,"""I don't care what she is."
1143,Grown don't mean nothing to a mother.
1144,A child is a child.
1145,"They get bigger, older, but grown?"
1146,What's that supposed to mean?
1147,In my heart it don't mean a thing.
1148,"""It means she has to take it if she acts up. You can't protect her every minute. What's going to happen when you die?"""
1149,"""Nothing! I'll protect her while I'm live and I'll protect her when I ain't."""
1150,"""Oh well, I'm through,"" he said."
1152,"""That's the way it is, Paul D. I can't explain it to you no better than that, but that's the way it is. If I have to choose--well, it's not even a choice."""
1153,"""That's the point."
1154,The whole point.
1155,I'm not asking you to choose.
1156,Nobody would.
1157,"I thought--well, I thought you could--there was some space for me."
1158,"""She's asking me."""

1159,"""You can't go by that. You got to say it to her. Tell her it's not about choosing somebody over her--it's making space for somebody along with her. You got to say it. And if you say it and mean it, then you also got to know you can't gag me. There's no way I'm going to hurt her or not take care of what she need if I can, but I can't be told to keep my mouth shut if she's acting ugly. You want me here, don't put no gag on me."""
1160,"""Maybe I should leave things the way they are,"" she said."
1161,"""How are they?"""
1162,"""We get along."""
1163,"""What about inside?"""
1164,"""I don't go inside."""
1165,"""Sethe, if I'm here with you, with Denver, you can go anywhere you want. Jump, if you want to, 'cause I'll catch you, girl. I'll catch you ""fore you fall."
1166,"Go as far inside as you need to, I'll hold your ankles."
1167,Make sure you get back out.
1168,I'm not saying this because I need a place to stay.
1169,That's the last thing I need.
1170,"I told you, I'm a walking man, but I been heading in this direction for seven years."
1171,Walking all around this place.
1172,"Upstate, downstate, east, west; I been in territory ain't got no name, never staying nowhere long."
1173,"But when I got here and sat out there on the porch, waiting for you, well, I knew it wasn't the place I was heading toward; it was you."
1174,"We can make a life, girl."
1175,A life.
1176,"""I don't know. I don't know."""
1177,"""Leave it to me. See how it goes. No promises, if you don't want to make any. Just see how it goes. All right?"""
1178,"""All right."""
1179,"""You willing to leave it to me?"""
1180,"""Well--some of it."""
1181,"""Some?"" he smiled."
1183,Here's some.
1184,There's a carnival in town.
1185,"Thursday, tomorrow, is for coloreds and I got two dollars."
1186,Me and you and Denver gonna spend every penny of it.
1187,"What you say?"""
1188,"""No"" is what she said."
1189,"At least what she started out saying (what would her boss say if she took a day off?), but even when she said it she was thinking how much her eyes enjoyed looking in his face."
1190,"The crickets were screaming on Thursday and the sky, stripped of blue, was white hot at eleven in the morning."
1191,"Sethe was badly dressed for the heat, but this being her first social outing in eighteen years, she felt obliged to wear her one good dress, heavy as it was, and a hat."
1192,Certainly a hat.
1193,She didn't want to meet Lady Jones or Ella with her head wrapped like she was going to work.
1194,"The dress, a good-wool castoff, was a Christmas present to Baby Suggs from Miss Bodwin, the whitewoman who loved her."
1195,Denver and Paul D fared better in the heat since neither felt the occasion required special clothing.
1196,"Denver's bonnet knocked against her shoulder blades; Paul D wore his vest open, no jacket and his shirt sleeves rolled above his elbows."
1197,"They were not holding hands, but their shadows were."
1198,Sethe looked to her left and all three of them were gliding over the dust holding hands.
1199,Maybe he was right.
1200,A life.
1201,"Watching their hand holding shadows, she was embarrassed at being dressed for church."

1202,"The others, ahead and behind them, would think she was putting on airs, letting them know that she was different because she lived in a house with two stories; tougher, because she could do and survive things they believed she should neither do nor survive."
1203,She was glad Denver had resisted her urgings to dress up--rebraid her hair at least.
1204,But Denver was not doing anything to make this trip a pleasure.
1205,"She agreed to go--sullenly--but her attitude was ""Go 'head. Try and make me happy."""
1206,The happy one was Paul D. He said howdy to everybody within twenty feet.
1207,"Made fun of the weather and what it was doing to him, yelled back at the crows, and was the first to smell the doomed roses."

1208,"All the time, no matter what they were doing-- whether Denver wiped perspiration from her forehead or stooped to retie her shoes; whether Paul D kicked a stone or reached over to meddle a child's face leaning on its mother's shoulder--all the time the three shadows that shot out of their feet to the left held hands."
1209,Nobody noticed but Sethe and she stopped looking after she decided that it was a good sign.
1210,A life.
1211,Could be.
1212,Up and down the lumberyard fence old roses were dying.

1213,"The sawyer who had planted them twelve years ago to give his workplace a friendly feel-- something to take the sin out of slicing trees for a living--was amazed by their abundance; how rapidly they crawled all over the stake-and-post fence that separated the lumberyard from the open field next to it where homeless men slept, children ran and, once a year, carnival people pitched tents."
1214,"The closer the roses got to death, the louder their scent, and everybody who attended the carnival associated it with the stench of the rotten roses."
1215,It made them a little dizzy and very thirsty but did nothing to extinguish the eagerness of the coloredpeople filing down the road.
1216,"Some walked on the grassy shoulders, others dodged the wagons creaking down the road's dusty center."
1217,"All, like Paul D, were in high spirits, which the smell of dying roses (that Paul D called to everybody's attention) could not dampen."
1218,As they pressed to get to the rope entrance they were lit like lamps.

1219,"Breathless with the excitement of seeing white people loose: doing magic, clowning, without heads or with two heads, twenty feet tall or two feet tall, weighing a ton, completely tattooed, eating glass, swallowing fire, spitting ribbons, twisted into knots, forming pyramids, playing with snakes and beating each other up."
1220,"All of this was advertisement, read by those who could and heard by those who could not, and the fact that none of it was true did not extinguish their appetite a bit."
1221,"The barker called them and their children names (""Pickaninnies free!"") but the food on his vest and the hole in his pants rendered it fairly harmless."
1222,In any case it was a small price to pay for the fun they might not ever have again.
1223,Two pennies and an insult were well spent if it meant seeing the spectacle of whitefolks making a spectacle of themselves.
1224,"So, although"
1225,"the carnival was a lot less than mediocre (which is why it agreed to a Colored Thursday), it gave the four hundred black people in its audience thrill upon thrill upon thrill."
1226,"One-Ton Lady spit at them, but her bulk shortened her aim and they got a big kick out of the helpless meanness in her little eyes."

1227,"Arabian Nights Dancer cut her performance to three minutes instead of the usual fifteen she normally did-earning the gratitude of the children, who could hardly wait for Abu Snake Charmer, who followed her."
1228,"Denver bought horehound, licorice, peppermint and lemonade at a table manned by a little whitegirl in ladies' high-topped shoes."

1229,"Soothed by sugar, surrounded by a crowd of people who did not find her the main attraction, who, in fact, said, ""Hey, Denver,"" every now and then, pleased her enough to consider the possibility that Paul D wasn't all that bad."

1230,"In fact there was something about him-- when the three of them stood together watching Midget dance--that made the stares of other Negroes kind, gentle, something Denver did not remember seeing in their faces."
1231,"Several even nodded and smiled at her mother, no one, apparently, able to withstand sharing the pleasure Paul D. was having."
1232,He slapped his knees when Giant danced with Midget; when Two-Headed Man talked to himself.
1233,He bought everything Denver asked for and much she did not.
1234,He teased Sethe into tents she was reluctant to enter.
1235,Stuck pieces of candy she didn't want between her lips.
1236,"When Wild African Savage shook his bars and said wa wa, Paul D told everybody he knew him back in Roanoke."
1237,Paul D made a few acquaintances; spoke to them about what work he might find.
1238,Sethe returned the smiles she got.
1239,Denver was swaying with delight.
1240,"And on the way home, although leading them now, the shadows of three people still held hands."
1241,A FULLY DRESSED woman walked out of the water.
1242,She barely gained the
1243,dry bank of the stream before she sat down and leaned against a mulberry tree.
1244,"All day and all night she sat there, her head resting on the trunk in a position abandoned enough to crack the brim in her straw hat."
1245,Everything hurt but her lungs most of all.
1246,Sopping wet and breathing shallow she spent those hours trying to negotiate the weight of her eyelids.
1247,The day breeze blew her dress dry; the night wind wrinkled it.
1248,Nobody saw her emerge or came accidentally by.
1249,"If they had, chances are they would have hesitated before approaching her."
1250,"Not because she was wet, or dozing or had what sounded like asthma, but because amid all that she was smiling."

1251,It took her the whole of the next morning to lift herself from the ground and make her way through the woods past a giant temple of boxwood to the field and then the yard of the slate-gray house.
1252,"Exhausted again, she sat down on the first handy place--a stump not far from the steps of ."
1253,By then keeping her eyes open was less of an effort.
1254,She could manage it for a full two minutes or more.
1255,"Her neck, its circumference no wider than a parlor-service saucer, kept bending and her chin brushed the bit of lace edging her dress."
1256,Women who drink champagne when there is nothing to celebrate can look like that: their straw hats with broken brims are often askew; they nod in public places; their shoes are undone.
1257,But their skin is not like that of the woman breathing near the steps of .
1258,"She had new skin, lineless and smooth, including the knuckles of her hands."
1259,"By late afternoon when the carnival was over, and the Negroes were hitching rides home if they were lucky--walking if they were not--the woman had fallen asleep again."

1260,"The rays of the sun struck her full in the face, so that when Sethe, Denver and Paul D rounded the curve in the road all they saw was a black dress, two unlaced shoes below it, and Here Boy nowhere in sight."
1261,"""Look,"" said Denver."
1262,"""What is that?"""
1263,"And, for some reason she could not immediately account for, the moment she got close enough to see the face, Sethe's bladder filled to capacity."
1264,"She said, ""Oh, excuse me,"" and ran around to the back of ."
1265,"Not since she was a baby girl, being cared for by the eight year-old girl who pointed out her mother to her, had she had an emergency that unmanageable."
1266,She never made the outhouse.
1267,"Right in front of its door she had to lift her skirts, and the water she voided was endless."
1268,"Like a horse, she thought, but as it went on and on she thought, No, more like flooding the boat when Denver was born."
1269,"So much water Amy said, ""Hold on, Lu. You going to sink us you keep that up."""
1270,But there was no stopping water breaking from a breaking womb and there was no stopping now.
1271,She hoped Paul D wouldn't take it upon himself to come looking for her and be obliged to see her squatting in front of her own privy making a mudhole too deep to be witnessed without shame.
1272,"Just about the time she started wondering if the carnival would accept another freak, it stopped."
1273,She tidied herself and ran around to the porch.
1274,No one was there.
1275,"All three were insidePaul D and Denver standing before the stranger, watching her drink cup after cup of water."
1276,"""She said she was thirsty,"" said Paul D. He took off his cap."
1277,"""Mighty thirsty look like."""
1278,The woman gulped water from a speckled tin cup and held it out for more.
1279,"Four times Denver filled it, and four times the woman drank as though she had crossed a desert."
1280,"When she was finished a little water was on her chin, but she did not wipe it away."
1281,Instead she gazed at Sethe with sleepy eyes.
1282,"Poorly fed, thought Sethe, and younger than her clothes suggested--good lace at the throat, and a rich woman's hat."

1283,"Her skin was flawless except for three vertical scratches on her forehead so fine and thin they seemed at first like hair, baby hair before it bloomed and roped into the masses of black yarn under her hat."
1284,"""You from around here?"""
1285,Sethe asked her.
1286,She shook her head no and reached down to take off her shoes.
1287,She pulled her dress up to the knees and rolled down her stockings.
1288,"When the hosiery was tucked into the shoes, Sethe saw that her feet were like her hands, soft and new."
1289,"She must have hitched a wagon ride, thought Sethe."
1290,Probably one of those West Virginia girls looking for something to beat a life of tobacco and sorghum.
1291,Sethe bent to pick up the shoes.
1292,"""What might your name be?"" asked Paul D."
1293,"""Beloved,"" she said, and her voice was so low and rough each one looked at the other two."
1294,They heard the voice first--later the name.
1295,"""Beloved. You use a last name, Beloved?"""
1296,Paul D asked her.
1298,She seemed puzzled.
1299,"Then ""No,"" and she spelled it for them, slowly as though the letters were being formed as she spoke them."
1300,Sethe dropped the shoes; Denver sat down and Paul D smiled.
1301,"He recognized the careful enunciation of letters by those, like himself, who could not read but had memorized the letters of their name."
1302,He was about to ask who her people were but thought better of it.
1303,A young coloredwoman drifting was drifting from ruin.
1304,He had been in Rochester four years ago and seen five women arriving with fourteen female children.
1305,"All their men-- brothers, uncles, fathers, husbands, sons--had been picked off one by one by one."
1306,They had a single piece of paper directing them to a preacher on DeVore Street.
1307,"The War had been over four or five years then, but nobody white or black seemed to know it."
1308,Odd clusters and strays of Negroes wandered the back roads and cowpaths from Schenectady to Jackson.
1309,"Dazed but insistent, they searched each other out for word of a cousin, an aunt, a friend who once said, ""Call on me. Anytime you get near Chicago, just call on me."""
1310,"Some of them were running from family that could not support them, some to family; some were running from dead crops, dead kin, life threats, and took-over land."
1311,"Boys younger than Buglar and Howard; configurations and blends of families of women and children, while elsewhere, solitary, hunted and hunting for, were men, men, men."
1312,"Forbidden public transportation, chased by debt and filthy ""talking sheets,"" they"
1313,"followed secondary routes, scanned the horizon for signs and counted heavily on each other."
1314,"Silent, except for social courtesies, when they met one another they neither described nor asked about the sorrow that drove them from one place to another."
1315,The whites didn't bear speaking on.
1316,Everybody knew.
1317,So he did not press the young woman with the broken hat about where from or how come.
1318,"If she wanted them to know and was strong enough to get through the telling, she would."
1319,What occupied them at the moment was what it might be that she needed.
1320,"Underneath the major question, each harbored another."
1321,Paul D wondered at the newness of her shoes.
1322,Sethe was deeply touched by her sweet name; the remembrance of glittering headstone made her feel especially kindly toward her.
1323,"Denver, however, was shaking."
1324,She looked at this sleepy beauty and wanted more.
1325,Sethe hung her hat on a peg and turned graciously toward the girl.

1326,"""That's a pretty name, Beloved. Take off your hat, why don't you, and I'll make us something. We just got back from the carnival over near Cincinnati. Everything in there is something to see."""
1327,"Bolt upright in the chair, in the middle of Sethe's welcome, Beloved had fallen asleep again."
1329,Paul D shook her gently.
1330,"""You want to lay down a spell?"""
1331,"She opened her eyes to slits and stood up on her soft new feet which, barely capable of their job, slowly bore her to the keeping room."
1332,"Once there, she collapsed on Baby Suggs' bed."
1333,Denver removed her hat and put the quilt with two squares of color over her feet.
1334,She was breathing like a steam engine.
1335,"""Sounds like croup,"" said Paul D, closing the door."
1336,"""Is she feverish? Denver, could you tell?"""
1337,"""No. She's cold."""
1338,"""Then she is. Fever goes from hot to cold."""
1339,"""Could have the cholera,"" said Paul D."
1341,"""All that water. Sure sign."""
1342,"""Poor thing. And nothing in this house to give her for it. She'll just have to ride it out. That's a hateful sickness if ever there was one."""
1343,"""She's not sick!"" said Denver, and the passion in her voice made them smile."
1344,"Four days she slept, waking and sitting up only for water."

1345,"Denver tended her, watched her sound sleep, listened to her labored breathing and, out of love and a breakneck possessiveness that charged her, hid like a personal blemish Beloved's incontinence."
1346,"She rinsed the sheets secretly, after Sethe went to the restaurant and Paul D went scrounging for barges to help unload."
1347,"She boiled the underwear and soaked it in bluing, praying the fever would pass without damage."
1348,"So intent was her nursing, she forgot to eat or visit the emerald closet."
1350,Denver would whisper.
1351,"""Beloved?"" and when the black eyes opened a slice all she could say was ""I'm here. I'm still here."""
1352,"Sometimes, when Beloved lay dreamy-eyed for a very long time, saying nothing, licking her lips and heaving deep sighs, Denver panicked."
1353,"""What is it?"" she would ask."
1354,"""Heavy,"" murmured Beloved."
1355,"""This place is heavy."""
1356,"""Would you like to sit up?"""
1357,"""No,"" said the raspy voice."
1358,It took three days for Beloved to notice the orange patches in the darkness of the quilt.
1359,Denver was pleased because it kept her patient awake longer.
1360,"She seemed totally taken with those faded scraps of orange, even made the effort to lean on her elbow and stroke them."
1361,"An effort that quickly exhausted her, so Denver rearranged the quilt so its cheeriest part was in the sick girl's sight line."
1362,"Patience, something Denver had never known, overtook her."
1363,"As long as her mother did not interfere, she was a model of compassion, turning waspish, though, when Sethe tried to help."
1364,"""Did she take a spoonful of anything today?"""
1365,Sethe inquired.
1366,"""She shouldn't eat with cholera."""
1367,"""You sure that's it? Was just a hunch of Paul D's."""
1368,"""I don't know, but she shouldn't eat anyway just yet."""
1369,"""I think cholera people puke all the time."""
1370,"""That's even more reason, ain't it?"""
1371,"""Well she shouldn't starve to death either, Denver."""
1372,"""Leave us alone, Ma'am. I'm taking care of her."""
1373,"""She say anything?"""
1374,"""I'd let you know if she did."""
1375,"Sethe looked at her daughter and thought, Yes, she has been lonesome."
1376,Very lonesome.
1377,"""Wonder where Here Boy got off to?"""
1378,Sethe thought a change of subject was needed.
1379,"""He won't be back,"" said Denver."
1380,"""How you know?"""
1381,"""I just know."""
1382,Denver took a square of sweet bread off the plate.
1383,"Back in the keeping room, Denver was about to sit down when Beloved's eyes flew wide open."
1384,Denver felt her heart race.
1385,"It wasn't that she was looking at that face for the first time with no trace of sleep in it, or that the eyes were big and black."
1386,Nor was it that the whites of them were much too white--blue-white.
1387,It was that deep down in those big black eyes there was no expression at all.
1388,"""Can I get you something?"""
1389,Beloved looked at the sweet bread in Denver's hands and Denver held it out to her.
1390,She smiled then and Denver's heart stopped bouncing and sat down--- relieved and easeful like a traveler who had made it home.
1391,"From that moment and through everything that followed, sugar could always be counted on to please her."
1392,It was as though sweet things were what she was born for.
1393,"Honey as well as the wax it came in, sugar sandwiches, the sludgy molasses gone hard and brutal in the can, lemonade, taffy and any type of dessert Sethe brought home from the restaurant."
1394,She gnawed a cane stick to flax and kept the strings in her mouth long after the syrup had been sucked away.
1395,"Denver laughed, Sethe smiled and Paul D said it made him sick to his stomach."
1396,Sethe believed it was a recovering body's need---after an illness-- for quick strength.
1397,But it was a need that went on and on into glowing health because Beloved didn't go anywhere.
1398,There didn't seem anyplace for her to go.
1399,"She didn't mention one, or have much of an idea of what she was doing in that part of the country or where she had been."
1400,They believed the fever had caused her memory to fail just as it kept her slow-moving.

1401,"A young woman, about nineteen or twenty, and slender, she moved like a heavier one or an older one, holding on to furniture, resting her head in the palm of her hand as though it was too heavy for a neck alone."
1402,"""You just gonna feed her? From now on?"""
1403,"Paul D, feeling ungenerous, and surprised by it, heard the irritability in his voice."
1404,"""Denver likes her."
1405,She's no real trouble.
1406,I thought we'd wait till her breath
1407,was better.
1408,She still sounds a little lumbar to me.
1409,"""Something funny 'bout that gal,"" Paul D said, mostly to himself."
1410,"""Funny how?"""
1411,"""Acts sick, sounds sick, but she don't look sick. Good skin, bright eyes and strong as a bull."""
1412,"""She's not strong. She can hardly walk without holding on to something."""
1413,"""That's what I mean. Can't walk, but I seen her pick up the rocker with one hand."""
1415,"""Don't tell me. Ask Denver. She was right there with her."""
1416,"""Denver! Come in here a minute."""
1417,Denver stopped rinsing the porch and stuck her head in the window.
1418,"""Paul D says you and him saw Beloved pick up the rocking chair single- handed. That so?"""
1419,"Long, heavy lashes made Denver's eyes seem busier than they were; deceptive, even when she held a steady gaze as she did now on Paul D. ""No,"" she said."
1420,"""I didn't see no such thing."""
1421,Paul D frowned but said nothing.
1422,"If there had been an open latch between them, it would have closed."
1423,RAINWATER held on to pine needles for dear life and Beloved could not
1424,take her eyes off Sethe.
1425,"Stooping to shake the damper, or snapping sticks for kindlin, Sethe was licked, tasted, eaten by Beloved's eyes."
1426,"Like a familiar, she hovered, never leaving the room Sethe was in unless required and told to."
1427,"She rose early in the dark to be there, waiting, in the kitchen when Sethe came down to make fast bread before she left for work."
1428,"In lamplight, and over the flames of the cooking stove, their two shadows clashed and crossed on the ceiling like black swords."

1429,"She was in the window at two when Sethe returned, or the doorway; then the porch, its steps, the path, the road, till finally, surrendering to the habit, Beloved began inching down Bluestone Road further and further each day to meet Sethe and walk her back to ."
1430,It was as though every afternoon she doubted anew the older woman's return.
1431,"Sethe was flattered by Beloved's open, quiet devotion."
1432,The same adoration from her daughter (had it been forthcoming) would have annoyed her; made her chill at the thought of having raised a ridiculously dependent child.
1433,"But the company of this sweet, if peculiar, guest pleased her the way a zealot pleases his teacher."
1434,Time came when lamps had to be lit early because night arrived sooner and sooner.
1435,Sethe was leaving for work in the dark; Paul D was walking home in it.
1436,"On one such evening dark and cool, Sethe cut a rutabaga into four pieces and left them stewing."
1437,She gave Denver a half peck of peas to sort and soak overnight.
1438,Then she sat herself down to rest.
1439,The heat of the stove made her drowsy and she was sliding into sleep when she felt Beloved touch her.
1440,"A touch no heavier than a feather but loaded, nevertheless, with desire."
1441,Sethe stirred and looked around.
1442,"First at Beloved's soft new hand on her shoulder, then into her eyes."
1443,The longing she saw there was bottomless.
1444,Some plea barely in control.
1445,"Sethe patted Beloved's fingers and glanced at Denver, whose eyes were fixed on her pea-sorting task."
1446,"""Where your diamonds?"""
1447,Beloved searched Sethe's face.
1448,"""Diamonds? What would I be doing with diamonds?"""
1449,"""On your ears."""
1450,"""Wish I did. I had some crystal once. A present from a lady I worked for."""
1451,"""Tell me,"" said Beloved, smiling a wide happy smile."
1452,"""Tell me your diamonds."""
1453,It became a way to feed her.
1454,"Just as Denver discovered and relied on the delightful effect sweet things had on Beloved, Sethe learned the profound satisfaction Beloved got from storytelling."
1455,It amazed Sethe (as much as it pleased Beloved) because every mention of her past life hurt.
1456,Everything in it was painful or lost.
1457,She and Baby Suggs had agreed without saying so that it was unspeakable; to Denver's inquiries Sethe gave short replies or rambling incomplete reveries.

1458,"Even with Paul D, who had shared some of it and to whom she could talk with at least a measure of calm, the hurt was always there-like a tender place in the corner of her mouth that the bit left."
1459,"But, as she began telling about the earrings, she found herself wanting to, liking it."
1460,"Perhaps it was Beloved's distance from the events itself, or her thirst for hearing it--in any case it was an unexpected pleasure."
1461,"Above the patter of the pea sorting and the sharp odor of cooking rutabaga, Sethe explained the crystal that once hung from her ears."

1462,"""That lady I worked for in Kentucky gave them to me when I got married. What they called married hack there and back then. I guess she saw how bad I felt when I found out there wasn't going to be no ceremony, no preacher. Nothing. I thought there should be something--something to say it was right and true. I didn't want it to be just me moving over a bit of pallet full of corn husks. Or just me bringing my night bucket into his cabin. I thought there should be some ceremony. Dancing maybe. A little sweet william in my hair."""
1463,Sethe smiled.
1464,"""I never saw a wedding, but I saw Mrs. Garner's wedding gown in the press, and heard her go on about what it was like."
1465,"Two pounds of currants in the cake, she said, and four whole sheep."
1466,The people were still eating the next day.
1467,That's what I wanted.
1468,"A meal maybe, where me and Halle and all the Sweet Home men sat down and ate something special."
1469,Invite some of the other colored people from over by Covington or High Trees--those places Sixo used to sneak off to.
1470,But it wasn't going to be nothing.
1471,They said it was all right for us to be husband and
1472,wife and that was it.
1473,All of it.
1474,"""Well, I made up my mind to have at the least a dress that wasn't the sacking I worked in."
1475,"So I took to stealing fabric, and wound up with a dress you wouldn't believe."
1476,The top was from two pillow cases in her mending basket.
1477,"The front of the skirt was a dresser scarf a candle fell on and burnt a hole in, and one of her old sashes we used to test the flatiron on."
1478,Now the back was a problem for the longest time.
1479,Seem like I couldn't find a thing that wouldn't be missed right away.
1480,Because I had to take it apart afterwards and put all the pieces back where they were.
1481,"Now Halle was patient, waiting for me to finish it."
1482,He knew I wouldn't go ahead without having it.
1483,Finally I took the mosquito netting from a nail out the barn.
1484,We used it to strain jelly through.
1485,I washed it and soaked it best I could and tacked it on for the back of the skirt.
1486,"And there I was, in the worst-looking gown you could imagine."
1487,Only my wool shawl kept me from looking like a haint peddling.
1488,"I wasn't but fourteen years old, so I reckon that's why I was so proud of myself."
1489,"""Anyhow, Mrs. Garner must have seen me in it."
1490,"I thought I was stealing smart, and she knew everything I did."
1491,Even our honeymoon: going down to the cornfield with Halle.
1492,That's where we went first.
1493,A Saturday afternoon it was.
1494,He begged sick so he wouldn't have to go work in town that day.
1495,Usually he worked Saturdays and Sundays to pay off Baby Suggs' freedom.
1496,But he begged sick and I put on my dress and we walked into the corn holding hands.
1497,I can still smell the ears roasting yonder where the Pauls and Sixo was.
1498,Next day Mrs. Garner crooked her finger at me and took me upstairs to her bedroom.
1499,She opened up a wooden box and took out a pair of crystal earrings.
1500,"She said, 'I want you to have these, Sethe.'"
1501,"I said, 'Yes, ma'am.'"
1502,'Are your ears pierced?' she said.
1503,"I said, 'No, ma'am.'"
1504,"'Well do it,' she said, 'so you can wear them. I want you to have them and I want you and Halle to be happy.'"
1505,I thanked her but I never did put them on till I got away from there.
1506,One day after I walked into this here house Baby Suggs unknotted my underskirt and took em out.
1507,I sat right here by the stove with Denver in my arms and let her punch holes in my ears for to wear them.
1508,"""I never saw you in no earrings,"" said Denver."
1509,"""Where are they now?"""
1510,"""Gone,"" said Sethe."
1511,"""Long gone,"" and she wouldn't say another word."
1512,Until the next time when all three of them ran through the wind back into the house with rainsoaked sheets and petticoats.
1513,"Panting, laughing, they draped the laundry over the chairs and table."
1514,Beloved filled herself with water from the bucket and watched while Sethe rubbed Denver's hair with a piece of toweling.
1515,"""Maybe we should unbraid it?"" asked Sethe."
1516,"""Oh uh. Tomorrow."""
1517,Denver crouched forward at the thought of a fine-tooth comb pulling her hair.
1518,"""Today is always here,"" said Sethe."
1519,"""Tomorrow, never."""
1520,"""It hurts,"" Denver said."
1521,"""Comb it every day, it won't."""
1523,"""Your woman she never fix up your hair?"""
1524,Beloved asked.
1525,Sethe and Denver looked up at her.
1526,After four weeks they still had not got used to the gravelly voice and the song that seemed to lie in it.
1527,"Just outside music it lay, with a cadence not like theirs."
1528,"""Your woman she never fix up your hair?"" was clearly a question for sethe, since that's who she was looking at."
1529,"""My woman?"
1530,You mean my mother?
1531,"If she did, I don't remember."
1532,I didn't see her but a few times out in the fields and once when she was working indigo.
1533,"By the time I woke up in the morning, she was in line."
1534,If the moon was bright they worked by its light.
1535,Sunday she slept like a stick.
1536,She must of nursed me two or three weeks--that's the way the others did.
1537,Then she
1538,went back in rice and I sucked from another woman whose job it was.
1539,"So to answer you, no."
1540,I reckon not.
1541,She never fixed my hair nor nothing.
1542,She didn't even sleep in the same cabin most nights I remember.
1543,"Too far from the line- up, I guess."
1544,One thing she did do.
1545,She picked me up and carried me behind the smokehouse.
1546,Back there she opened up her dress front and lifted her breast and pointed under it.
1547,Right on her rib was a circle and a cross burnt right in the skin.
1548,"She said, 'This is your ma'am. This,' and she pointed."
1549,"'I am the only one got this mark now. The rest dead. If something happens to me and you can't tell me by my face, you can know me by this mark.'"
1550,Scared me so.
1551,"All I could think of was how important this was and how I needed to have something important to say back, but I couldn't think of anything so I just said what I thought."
1552,"'Yes, Ma'am,' I said."
1553,'But how will you know me?
1554,How will you know me?
1555,"Mark me, too,' I said."
1556,"'Mark the mark on me too.'"" Sethe chuckled."
1557,"""Did she?"" asked Denver."
1558,"""She slapped my face."""
1560,"""What happened to her?"""
1561,"""I didn't understand it then. Not till I had a mark of my own."""
1562,"""Hung. By the time they cut her down nobody could tell whether she had a circle and a cross or not, least of all me and I did look."""
1563,Sethe gathered hair from the comb and leaning back tossed it into the fire.
1564,It exploded into stars and the smell infuriated them.
1565,"""Oh, my Jesus,"" she said and stood up so suddenly the comb she had parked in Denver's hair fell to the floor."
1566,"""Ma'am? What's the matter with you, Ma'am?"""
1567,"Sethe walked over to a chair, lifted a sheet and stretched it as wide as her arms would go."
1568,"Then she folded, refolded and double folded it."
1569,She took
1570,another.
1571,Neither was completely dry but the folding felt too fine to stop.
1572,She had to do something with her hands because she was remembering something she had forgotten she knew.
1573,Something privately shameful that had seeped into a slit in her mind right behind the slap on her face and the circled cross.
1574,"""Why they hang your ma'am?"""
1575,Denver asked.
1576,This was the first time she had heard anything about her mother's mother.
1577,Baby Suggs was the only grandmother she knew.

1578,"""I never found out. It was a lot of them,"" she said, but what was getting clear and clearer as she folded and refolded damp laundry was the woman called Nan who took her hand and yanked her away from the pile before she could make out the mark."
1579,"Nan was the one she knew best, who was around all day, who nursed babies, cooked, had one good arm and half of another."
1580,And who used different words.
1581,Words Sethe understood then but could neither recall nor repeat now.
1582,She believed that must be why she remembered so little before Sweet Home except singing and dancing and how crowded it was.
1583,"What Nan told her she had forgotten, along with the language she told it in."
1584,"The same language her ma'am spoke, and which would never come back."
1585,But the message--that was and had been there all along.
1586,"Holding the damp white sheets against her chest, she was picking meaning out of a code she no longer understood."
1587,Nighttime.
1588,"Nan holding her with her good arm, waving the stump of the other in the air."
1589,"""Telling you. I am telling you, small girl Sethe,"" and she did that."
1590,She told Sethe that her mother and Nan were together from the sea.
1591,Both were taken up many times by the crew.
1592,"""She threw them all away but you."
1593,The one from the crew she threw away on the island.
1594,The others from more whites she also threw away.
1595,"Without names, she threw them."
1596,You she gave the name of the black man.
1597,She put her arms around him.
1598,The others she did not put her arms around.
1599,Never.
1600,Never.
1601,Telling you.
1602,"I am telling you, small girl Sethe."
1603,"As small girl Sethe, she was unimpressed."
1604,"As grown-up woman Sethe she was angry, but not certain at what."
1605,A mighty wish for Baby Suggs broke over her like surf.
1606,"In the quiet following its splash, Sethe looked at the two girls sitting by the stove: her sickly, shallow-minded boarder, her irritable, lonely daughter."
1607,They seemed little and far away.
1608,"""Paul D be here in a minute,"" she said."
1609,Denver sighed with relief.
1610,"For a minute there, while her mother stood folding the wash lost in thought, she clamped her teeth and prayed it would stop."
1611,"Denver hated the stories her mother told that did not concern herself, which is why Amy was all she ever asked about."
1612,"The rest was a gleaming, powerful world made more so by Denver's absence from it."
1613,"Not being in it, she hated it and wanted Beloved to hate it too, although there was no chance of that at all."
1614,Beloved took every opportunity to ask some funny question and get Sethe going.
1615,Denver noticed how greedy she was to hear Sethe talk.
1616,Now she noticed something more.
1617,"The questions Beloved asked: ""Where your diamonds?"""
1618,"""Your woman she never fix up your hair?"""
1619,And most perplexing: Tell me your earrings.
1620,How did she know?
1621,strawberry plants did before they shot out their thin vines: the quality of the green changed.
1622,"Then the vine threads came, then the buds."
1623,"By the time the white petals died and the mint-colored berry poked out, the leaf shine was gilded fight and waxy."
1624,That's how Beloved looked-- gilded and shining.
1625,"Paul D took to having Sethe on waking, so that later, when he went down the white stairs where she made bread under Beloved's gaze, his head was clear."
1626,"In the evening when he came home and the three of them were all there fixing the supper table, her shine was so pronounced he wondered why Denver and Sethe didn't see it."
1627,Or maybe they did.
1628,"Certainly women could tell, as men could, when one of their number was"
1629,aroused.
1630,Paul D looked carefully at Beloved to see if she was aware of it but she paid him no attention at all--frequently not even answering a direct question put to her.
1631,She would look at him and not open her mouth.
1632,"Five weeks she had been with them, and they didn't know any more about her than they did when they found her asleep on the stump."
1633,They were seated at the table Paul D had broken the day he arrived at .
1634,Its mended legs stronger than before.
1635,The cabbage was all gone and the shiny ankle bones of smoked pork were pushed in a heap on their plates.

1636,"Sethe was dishing up bread pudding, murmuring her hopes for it, apologizing in advance the way veteran cooks always do, when something in Beloved's face, some petlike adoration that took hold of her as she looked at Sethe, made Paul D speak."
1637,"""Ain't you got no brothers or sisters?"""
1638,Beloved diddled her spoon but did not look at him.
1639,"""I don't have nobody."""
1640,"""What was you looking for when you came here?"" he asked her."
1641,"""This place. I was looking for this place I could be in."""
1642,"""Somebody tell you about this house?"""
1643,"""She told me. When I was at the bridge, she told me."""
1644,"""Must be somebody from the old days,"" Sethe said."
1645,The days when was a way station where messages came and then their senders.
1646,Where bits of news soaked like dried beans in spring water--until they were soft enough to digest.
1647,"""How'd you come? Who brought you?"""
1648,"Now she looked steadily at him, but did not answer."
1649,"He could feel both Sethe and Denver pulling in, holding their stomach muscles, sending out sticky spiderwebs to touch one another."
1650,He decided to force it anyway.
1651,"""I asked you who brought you here?"""
1652,"""I walked here,"" she said."
1653,"""A long, long, long, long way. Nobody bring me. Nobody help me."""
1654,"""You had new shoes. If you walked so long why don't your shoes show it?"""
1655,"""Paul D, stop picking on her."""
1656,"""I want to know,"" he said, holding the knife handle in his fist like a pole."
1657,"""I take the shoes! I take the dress! The shoe strings don't fix!"" she shouted and gave him a look so malevolent Denver touched her arm."
1658,"""I'll teach you,"" said Denver, ""how to tie your shoes,"" and got a smile from Beloved as a reward."
1659,"Paul D had the feeling a large, silver fish had slipped from his hands the minute he grabbed hold of its tail."
1660,"That it was streaming back off into dark water now, gone but for the glistening marking its route."
1661,"But if her shining was not for him, who then?"
1662,"He had never known a woman who lit up for nobody in particular, who just did it as a general announcement."
1663,"Always, in his experience, the light appeared when there was focus."
1664,"Like the Thirty-Mile Woman, dulled to smoke while he waited with her in the ditch, and starlight when Sixo got there."
1665,He never knew himself to mistake it.
1666,"It was there the instant he looked at Sethe's wet legs, otherwise he never would have been bold enough to enclose her in his arms that day and whisper into her back."
1667,"This girl Beloved, homeless and without people, beat all, though he couldn't say exactly why, considering the coloredpeople he had run into during the last twenty years."
1668,"During, before and after the War he had seen Negroes so stunned, or hungry, or tired or bereft it was a wonder they recalled or said anything."

1669,"Who, like him, had hidden in caves and fought owls for food; who, like him, stole from pigs; who, like him, slept in trees in the day and walked by night; who, like him, had buried themselves in slop and jumped in wells to avoid regulators, raiders, paterollers, veterans, hill men, posses and merrymakers."
1670,Once he met a Negro about fourteen years old who lived by himself in the woods and said he couldn't remember living anywhere else.
1671,saw a witless coloredwoman jailed and hanged for stealing ducks she believed were her own babies.
1672,Move.
1673,Walk.
1675,Hide.
1676,Steal and move on.
1677,"Only once had it been possible for him to stay in one spot--with a woman, or a family--for longer than a few months."
1678,"That once was almost two years with a weaver lady in Delaware, the meanest place for Negroes he had ever seen outside Pulaski County, Kentucky, and of course the prison camp in Georgia."
1679,"From all those Negroes, Beloved was different."
1680,"Her shining, her new shoes."
1681,It bothered him.
1682,Maybe it was just the fact that he didn't bother her.
1683,Or it could be timing.
1684,"She had appeared and been taken in on the very day Sethe and he had patched up their quarrel, gone out in public and had a right good time-- like a family."
1685,"Denver had come around, so to speak; Sethe was laughing; he had a promise of steady work, was cleared up from spirits."
1686,It had begun to look like a life.
1687,"And damn! a water-drinking woman fell sick, got took in, healed, and hadn't moved a peg since."
1688,"He wanted her out, but Sethe had let her in and he couldn't put her out of a house that wasn't his."
1689,"It was one thing to beat up a ghost, quite another to throw a helpless coloredgirl out in territory infected by the Klan."
1690,"Desperately thirsty for black blood, without which it could not live, the dragon swam the Ohio at will."
1691,"Sitting at table, chewing on his after-supper broom straw, Paul D decided to place her."
1692,Consult with the Negroes in town and find her her own place.
1693,No sooner did he have the thought than Beloved strangled on one of the raisins she had picked out of the bread pudding.
1694,She fell backward and off the chair and thrashed around holding her throat.
1695,Sethe knocked her on the back while Denver pried her hands away from her neck.
1696,"Beloved, on her hands and knees, vomited up her food and struggled for breath."
1697,"When she was quiet and Denver had wiped up the mess, she said, ""Go to sleep now."""
1698,"""Come in my room,"" said Denver."
1699,"""I can watch out for you up there."""
1700,No moment could have been better.
1701,Denver had worried herself sick trying to think of a way to get Beloved to share her room.
1702,"It was hard sleeping above her, wondering if she was going to be sick again, fall asleep and not wake, or (God, please don't) get up and wander out of the yard just the way she wandered in."
1703,They could have their talks easier there: at night when Sethe and Paul D were asleep; or in the daytime before either came home.
1704,"Sweet, crazy conversations full of half sentences, daydreams and misunderstandings more thrilling than understanding could ever be."
1705,"When the girls left, Sethe began to clear the table."
1706,She stacked the plates near a basin of water.
1707,"""What is it about her vex you so?"""
1708,"Paul D frowned, but said nothing."
1709,"""We had one good fight about Denver. Do we need one about her too?"" asked Sethe."
1710,"""I just don't understand what the hold is. It's clear why she holds on to you, but just can't see why you holding on to her."""
1711,Sethe turned away from the plates toward him.

1712,"""what you care who's holding on to who? Feeding her is no trouble. I pick up a little extra from the restaurant is all. And she's nice girl company for Denver. You know that and I know you know it, so what is it got your teeth on edge?"""
1713,"""I can't place it. It's a feeling in me."""

1714,"""Well, feel this, why don't you? Feel how it feels to have a bed to sleep in and somebody there not worrying you to death about what you got to do each day to deserve it. Feel how that feels. And if that don't get it, feel how it feels to be a coloredwoman roaming the roads with anything God made liable to jump on you. Feel that."""
1715,"""I know every bit of that, Sethe."
1716,I wasn't born yesterday and I never
1717,mistreated a woman in my life.
1718,"""That makes one in the world,"" Sethe answered."
1721,"""What'd he leave then if not me?"""
1722,"""I don't know, but it wasn't you. That's a fact."""
1723,"""Then he did worse; he left his children."""
1724,"""You don't know that."""
1725,"""What Halle ever do to you? Halle stood by you. He never left you."""
1726,"""He wasn't there. He wasn't where he said he would be."""
1727,"""He was there."""
1728,"""Then why didn't he show himself? Why did I have to pack my babies off and stay behind to look for him?"""
1729,"""He couldn't get out the loft."""
1730,"""Loft? What loft?"""
1731,"""The one over your head. In the barn."""
1732,"Slowly, slowly, taking all the time allowed, Sethe moved toward the table."
1735,"""He told you?"""
1736,"""You told me."""

1738,"""The day I came in here. You said they stole your milk. I never knew what it was that messed him up. That was it, I guess. All I knew was that something broke him. Not a one of them years of Saturdays, Sundays and nighttime extra never touched him. But whatever he saw go on in that barn that day broke him like a twig."""
1740,Sethe was gripping her elbows as though to keep them from flying away.
1741,"""He saw. Must have."""
1742,"""He saw them boys do that to me and let them keep on breathing air? He saw? He saw? He saw?"""

1743,"""Hey! Hey! Listen up. Let me tell you something. A man ain't a goddamn ax. Chopping, hacking, busting every goddamn minute of the day. Things get to him. Things he can't chop down because they're inside."""
1744,"Sethe was pacing up and down, up and down in the lamplight."
1745,"""The underground agent said, By Sunday."
1746,They took my milk and he saw it and didn't come down?
1747,Sunday came and he didn't.
1748,Monday came and no Halle.
1749,"I thought he was dead, that's why; then I thought they caught him, that's why."

1750,"Then I thought, No, he's not dead because if he was I'd know it, and then you come here after all this time and you didn't say he was dead, because you didn't know either, so I thought, Well, he just found him another better way to live."
1751,"Because if he was anywhere near here, he'd come to Baby Suggs, if not to me."
1752,But I never knew he saw.
1753,"""What does that matter now?"""
1754,"""If he is alive, and saw that, he won't step foot in my door. Not Halle."""
1755,"""It broke him, Sethe."""
1756,Paul D looked up at her and sighed.
1757,"""You may as well know it all."
1758,Last time I saw him he was sitting by the chum.
1759,He had butter all
1760,"Nothing happened, and she was grateful for that."
1761,Usually she could see the picture right away of what she heard.
1762,But she could not picture what Paul D said.
1763,Nothing came to mind.
1764,"Carefully, carefully, she passed on to a reasonable question."
1765,over his face.
1766,"""What did he say?"""
1768,"""Not a word?"""
1769,"""Not a word."""
1770,"""Did you speak to him? Didn't you say anything to him? Something!"""
1771,"""I couldn't, Sethe. I just.., couldn't."""
1773,"""I had a bit in my mouth."""
1774,Sethe opened the front door and sat down on the porch steps.
1775,"The day had gone blue without its sun, but she could still make out the black silhouettes of trees in the meadow beyond."
1776,"She shook her head from side to side, resigned to her rebellious brain."
1777,Why was there nothing it reused?
1778,"No misery, no regret, no hateful picture too rotten to accept?"
1779,Like a greedy child it snatched up everything.
1780,"Just once, could it say, No thank you?"
1781,I just ate and can't hold another bite?
1782,"I am full God damn it of two boys with mossy teeth, one sucking on my breast the other holding me down, their book-reading teacher watching and writing it up."
1783,"I am still full of that, God damn it, I can't go back and add more."
1784,"Add my husband to it, watching, above me in the loft- -hiding close by--the one place he thought no one would look for him, looking down on what I couldn't look at at all."
1785,"And not stopping them--looking and letting it happen. But my greedy brain says, Oh thanks, I'd love more--so I add more."
1786,"And no sooner than I do, there"
1787,is no stopping.
1788,There is also my husband squatting by the churn smearing the butter as well as its clabber all over his face because the milk they took is on his mind.
1789,"And as far as he is concerned, the world may as well know it."
1790,"And if he was that broken then, then he is also and certainly dead now."

1791,"And if Paul D saw him and could not save or comfort him because the iron bit was in his mouth, then there is still more that Paul D could tell me and my brain would go right ahead and take it and never say, No thank you."
1792,I don't want to know or have to remember that.
1793,"I have other things to do: worry, for example, about tomorrow, about Denver, about Beloved, about age and sickness not to speak of love."
1794,But her brain was not interested in the future.
1795,"Loaded with the past and hungry for more, it left her no room to imagine, let alone plan for, the next day."
1796,Exactly like that afternoon in the wild onions-- when one more step was the most she could see of the future.
1797,"Other people went crazy, why couldn't she?"
1798,"Other people's brains stopped, turned around and went on to something new, which is what must have happened to Halle."
1799,"And how sweet that would have been: the two of them back by the milk shed, squatting by the churn, smashing cold, lumpy butter into their faces with not a care in the world."
1800,"Feeling it slippery, sticky--rubbing it in their hair, watching it squeeze through their fingers."
1801,What a relief to stop it right there.
1802,Close.
1803,Shut.
1804,Squeeze the butter.
1805,But her three children were chewing sugar teat under a blanket on their way to Ohio and no butter play would change that.
1806,Paul D stepped through the door and touched her shoulder.
1807,"""I didn't plan on telling you that."""
1808,"""I didn't plan on hearing it."""
1809,"""I can't take it back, but I can leave it alone,"" Paul D said."
1810,"He wants to tell me, she thought."
1811,"He wants me to ask him about what it was like for him--about how offended the tongue is, held down by iron, how the need to spit is so deep you cry for it."
1812,"She already knew about it, had seen it time after time in the place before Sweet Home."
1813,"Men, boys, little girls,"
1814,women.
1815,The wildness that shot up into the eye the moment the lips were yanked back.
1816,"Days after it was taken out, goose fat was rubbed on the corners of the mouth but nothing to soothe the tongue or take the wildness out of the eye."
1817,Sethe looked up into Paul D's eyes to see if there was any trace left in them.

1818,"""People I saw as a child,"" she said, ""who'd had the bit always looked wild after that. Whatever they used it on them for, it couldn't have worked, because it put a wildness where before there wasn't any. When I look at you, I don't see it. There ain't no wildness in your eye nowhere."""
1819,"""There's a way to put it there and there's a way to take it out. I know em both and I haven't figured out yet which is worse."""
1820,He sat down beside her.
1821,Sethe looked at him.
1822,"In that unlit daylight his face, bronzed and reduced to its bones, smoothed her heart down."
1823,"""You want to tell me about it?"" she asked him."
1824,"""I don't know. I never have talked about it. Not to a soul. Sang it sometimes, but I never told a soul."""
1825,"""Go ahead. I can hear it."""
1826,"""What then?"""
1827,Sethe asked.
1828,"""Maybe. Maybe you can hear it. I just ain't sure I can say it. Say it right, I mean, because it wasn't the bit--that wasn't it."""
1829,"""The roosters,"" he said."
1830,"""Walking past the roosters looking at them look at me."""
1831,Sethe smiled.
1832,"""In that pine?"""
1834,Paul D smiled with her.
1835,"""Must have been five of them perched up there, and at least fifty hens."""
1836,"""Mister, too?"""
1837,"""Not right off."
1838,But I hadn't took twenty steps before I seen him.
1839,He come down off the fence post there and sat on the tub.
1840,"""He loved that tub,"" said Sethe, thinking, No, there is no stopping now."

1841,"""Didn't he? Like a throne. Was me took him out the shell, you know. He'd a died if it hadn't been for me. The hen had walked on off with all the hatched peeps trailing behind her. There was this one egg left. Looked like a blank, but then I saw it move so I tapped it open and here come Mister, bad feet and all. I watched that son a bitch grow up and whup everything in the yard."""
1842,"""He always was hateful,"" Sethe said."
1843,"""Yeah, he was hateful all right."
1844,"Bloody too, and evil."
1845,Crooked feet flapping.
1846,Comb as big as my hand and some kind of red.
1847,He sat right there on the tub looking at me. I swear he smiled.
1848,My head was full of what I'd seen of Halle a while back.
1849,I wasn't even thinking about the bit.
1850,"Just Halle and before him Sixo, but when I saw Mister I knew it was me too."
1851,"Not just them, me too."
1852,"One crazy, one sold, one missing, one burnt and me licking iron with my hands crossed behind me."
1853,The last of the Sweet Home men.
1854,"""Mister, he looked so... free."
1855,Better than me.
1856,"Stronger, tougher."
1857,"Son a bitch couldn't even get out the shell by hisself but he was still king and I was..."""
1858,Paul D stopped and squeezed his left hand with his right.
1859,He held it that way long enough for it and the world to quiet down and let him go on.

1860,"""Mister was allowed to be and stay what he was. But I wasn't allowed to be and stay what I was. Even if you cooked him you'd be cooking a rooster named Mister. But wasn't no way I'd ever be Paul D again, living or dead. Schoolteacher changed me. I was something else and that something was less than a chicken sitting in the sun on a tub."""
1861,Sethe put her hand on his knee and rubbed.
1862,"Paul D had only begun, what he was telling her was only the beginning when her fingers on his knee, soft and reassuring, stopped him."
1863,Just as well.
1864,Just as
1865,well.
1866,Saying more might push them both to a place they couldn't get back from.
1867,He would keep the rest where it belonged: in that tobacco tin buried in his chest where a red heart used to be.
1868,Its lid rusted shut.
1869,"He would not pry it loose now in front of this sweet sturdy woman, for if she got a whiff of the contents it would shame him."
1870,And it would hurt her to know that there was no red heart bright as Mister's comb beating in him.
1871,"Sethe rubbed and rubbed, pressing the work cloth and the stony curves that made up his knee."
1872,She hoped it calmed him as it did her.
1873,Like kneading bread in the half-light of the restaurant kitchen.
1874,"Before the cook arrived when she stood in a space no wider than a bench is long, back behind and to the left of the milk cans."
1875,Working dough.
1876,"Working, working dough."
1877,Nothing better than that to start the day's serious work of beating back the past.
1878,"make-a-new-step, slide, slide and strut on down."
1879,Denver sat on the bed smiling and providing the music.
1880,She had never seen Beloved this happy.
1881,She had seen her pouty lips open wide with the pleasure of sugar or some piece of news Denver gave her.
1882,She had felt warm satisfaction radiating from Beloved's skin when she listened to her mother talk about the old days.
1883,But gaiety she had never seen.
1884,"Not ten minutes had passed since Beloved had fallen backward to the floor, pop-eyed, thrashing and holding her throat."
1885,"Now, after a few seconds lying in Denver's bed, she was up and dancing."
1886,"""Where'd you learn to dance?"""
1887,Denver asked her.
1888,"""Nowhere. Look at me do this."""
1889,Beloved put her fists on her hips and commenced to skip on bare feet.
1890,Denver laughed.
1891,"""Now you. Come on,"" said Beloved."
1892,"""You may as well just come on."""
1893,Her black skirt swayed from side to side.
1894,Denver grew ice-cold as she rose from the bed.
1895,She knew she was twice
1896,"Beloved's size but she floated up, cold and light as a snowflake."
1897,Beloved took Denver's hand and placed another on Denver's shoulder.
1898,They danced then.
1899,"Round and round the tiny room and it may have been dizziness, or feeling light and icy at once, that made Denver laugh so hard."
1900,A catching laugh that Beloved caught.
1901,"The two of them, merry as kittens, swung to and fro, to and fro, until exhausted they sat on the floor."
1902,Beloved let her head fall back on the edge of the bed while she found her breath and Denver saw the tip of the thing she always saw in its entirety when Beloved undressed to sleep.
1903,"Looking straight at it she whispered, ""Why you call yourself Beloved?"""
1904,Beloved closed her eyes.
1905,"""In the dark my name is Beloved."""
1906,Denver scooted a little closer.
1907,"""What's it like over there, where you were before? Can you tell me?"""
1908,"""Dark,"" said Beloved."
1909,"""I'm small in that place. I'm like this here."""
1910,"She raised her head off the bed, lay down on her side and curled up."
1911,Denver covered her lips with her fingers.
1912,"""Were you cold?"""
1913,Beloved curled tighter and shook her head.
1914,"""Hot. Nothing to breathe down there and no room to move in."""
1915,"""You see anybody?"""
1916,"""Heaps. A lot of people is down there. Some is dead."""
1917,"""You see Jesus? Baby Suggs?"""
1918,"""I don't know. I don't know the names."""
1919,She sat up.
1920,"""Tell me, how did you get here?"""
1921,"""I wait; then I got on the bridge. I stay there in the dark, in the daytime, in the dark, in the daytime. It was a long time."""
1922,"""All this time you were on a bridge?"""
1923,"""No. After. When I got out."""
1924,"""What did you come back for?"""
1925,Beloved smiled.
1926,"""To see her face."""
1927,"""Ma'am's? Sethe?"""
1929,"Denver felt a little hurt, slighted that she was not the main reason for Beloved's return."
1930,"""Don't you remember we played together by the stream?"""
1931,"""I was on the bridge,"" said Beloved."
1932,"""You see me on the bridge?"""
1933,"""No, by the stream. The water back in the woods."""
1934,"""Oh, I was in the water. I saw her diamonds down there. I could touch them."""
1935,"""What stopped you?"""
1936,"""She left me behind. By myself,"" said Beloved."
1937,"She lifted her eyes to meet Denver's and frowned, perhaps."
1938,Perhaps not.
1939,The tiny scratches on her forehead may have made it seem so.
1940,Denver swallowed.
1941,"""Don't,"" she said."
1942,"""Don't. You won't leave us, will you?"""
1943,"""No. Never. This is where I am."""
1944,"Suddenly Denver, who was sitting cross-legged, lurched forward and grabbed Beloved's wrist."
1945,"""Don't tell her. Don't let Ma'am know who you are. Please, you hear?"""
1946,"""Don't tell me what to do. Don't you never never tell me what to do."""
1947,"""But I'm on your side, Beloved."""
1948,"""She is the one. She is the one I need. You can go but she is the one I have to have."""
1949,"Her eyes stretched to the limit, black as the all night sky."
1950,"""I didn't do anything to you. I never hurt you. I never hurt anybody,"" said Denver."
1951,"""Me either. Me either."""
1952,"""What you gonna do?"""
1953,"""Stay here. I belong here."""
1954,"""I belong here too."""
1955,"""Then stay, but don't never tell me what to do. Don't never do that."""
1956,"""We were dancing."
1957,Just a minute ago we were dancing together.
1959,"""I don't want to."""
1960,Beloved got up and lay down on the bed.
1961,Their quietness boomed about on the walls like birds in panic.
1962,Finally Denver's breath steadied against the threat of an unbearable loss.
1963,"""Tell me,"" Beloved said."
1964,"""Tell me how Sethe made you in the boat."""
1965,"""She never told me all of it,"" said Denver."
1967,Denver climbed up on the bed and folded her arms under her apron.
1968,"She had not been in the tree room once since Beloved sat on their stump after the carnival, and had not remembered that she hadn't gone there until this very desperate moment."
1969,"Nothing was out there that this sister-girl did not provide in abundance: a racing heart, dreaminess, society, danger, beauty."
1970,"She swallowed twice to prepare for the telling, to construct out of the strings she had heard all her life a net to hold Beloved."
1971,"""She had good hands, she said."
1972,"The whitegirl, she said, had thin little arms but good hands."
1973,"She saw that right away, she said."
1974,"Hair enough for five heads and good hands, she said."
1975,I guess the hands made her think she could do it: get us both across the river.
1976,But the mouth was what kept her from being
1977,scared.
1978,She said there ain't nothing to go by with whitepeople.
1979,You don't know how they'll jump.
1980,"Say one thing, do another."
1981,But if you looked at the mouth sometimes you could tell by that.
1982,"She said this girl talked a storm, but there wasn't no meanness around her mouth."
1983,"She took Ma'am to that lean-to and rubbed her feet for her, so that was one thing."
1984,And Ma'am believed she wasn't going to turn her over.
1985,"You could get money if you turned a runaway over, and she wasn't sure this girl Amy didn't need money more than anything, especially since all she talked about was getting hold of some velvet."
1986,"""Anyway, she rubbed Ma'am's feet back to life, and she cried, she said, from how it hurt. But it made her think she could make it on over to where Grandma Baby Suggs was and..."""
1987,"""What's velvet?"""
1988,"""It's a cloth, kind of deep and soft."""
1990,"""Who is that?"""
1991,"""I just said it. My grandmother."""
1992,"""Is that Sethe's mother?"""
1993,"""No. My father's mother."""
1995,"""That's where the others was."
1996,"My brothers and.., the baby girl."
1997,She sent them on before to wait for her at Grandma Baby's.
1998,So she had to put up with everything to get there.
1999,And this here girl Amy helped.
2000,Denver stopped and sighed.
2001,This was the part of the story she loved.
2002,"She was coming to it now, and she loved it because it was all about herself; but she hated it too because it made her feel like a bill was owing somewhere and"
2003,"she, Denver, had to pay it."
2004,But who she owed or what to pay it with eluded her.

2005,"Now, watching Beloved's alert and hungry face, how she took in every word, asking questions about the color of things and their size, her downright craving to know, Denver began to see what she was saying and not just to hear it: there is this nineteen-year-old slave girl--a year older than her self-- walking through the dark woods to get to her children who are far away."
2006,"She is tired, scared maybe, and maybe even lost."
2007,Most of all she is by herself and inside her is another baby she has to think about too.
2008,"Behind her dogs, perhaps; guns probably; and certainly mossy teeth."
2009,"She is not so afraid at night because she is the color of it, but in the day every sound is a shot or a tracker's quiet step."
2010,Denver was seeing it now and feeling it--through Beloved.
2011,Feeling how it must have felt to her mother.
2012,Seeing how it must have looked.
2013,"And the more fine points she made, the more detail she provided, the more Beloved liked it."
2014,So she anticipated the questions by giving blood to the scraps her mother and grandmother had told herwand a heartbeat.
2015,"The monologue became, iri fact, a duet as they lay down together, Denver nursing Beloved's interest like a lover whose pleasure was to overfeed the loved."
2016,The dark quilt with two orange patches was there with them because Beloved wanted it near her when she slept.
2017,"It was smelling like grass and feeling like hands-- the unrested hands of busy women: dry, warm, prickly."

2018,"Denver spoke, Beloved listened, and the two did the best they could to create what really happened, how it really was, something only Sethe knew because she alone had the mind for it and the time afterward to shape it: the quality of Amy's voice, her breath like burning wood."
2019,"The quick-change weather up in those hills---cool at night, hot in the day, sudden fog."
2020,How recklessly she behaved with this whitegirlNa recklessness born of desperation and encouraged by Amy's fugitive eyes and her tenderhearted mouth.
2021,"""You ain't got no business walking round these hills, miss."""
2022,"""Looka here who's talking."
2023,I got more business here 'n you got.
2024,They catch you they cut your head off.
2025,Ain't nobody after me but I know somebody after you.
2026,""" Amy pressed her fingers into the soles of the slavewoman's feet. ""Whose baby that?"""
2027,Sethe did not answer.
2029,"""You don't even know. Come here, Jesus,"" Amy sighed and shook her head."
2031,"""Good for you. More it hurt more better it is. Can't nothing heal without pain, you know. What you wiggling for?"""
2032,Sethe raised up on her elbows.
2033,Lying on her back so long had raised a ruckus between her shoulder blades.
2034,The fire in her feet and the fire on her back made her sweat.
2035,"""My back hurt me,"" she said."
2036,"""Your back? Gal, you a mess. Turn over here and let me see."""
2037,"In an effort so great it made her sick to her stomach, Sethe turned onto her right side."
2038,"Amy unfastened the back of her dress and said, ""Come here, Jesus,"" when she saw."
2039,Sethe guessed it must be bad because after that call to Jesus Amy didn't speak for a while.
2040,"In the silence of an Amy struck dumb for a change, Sethe felt the fingers of those good hands lightly touch her back."
2041,She could hear her breathing but still the whitegirl said nothing.
2042,Sethe could not move.
2043,"She couldn't lie on her stomach or her back, and to keep on her side meant pressure on her screaming feet."
2044,Amy spoke at last in her dreamwalker's voice.

2045,"""It's a tree, Lu. A chokecherry tree. See, here's the trunk--it's red and split wide open, full of sap, and this here's the parting for the branches. You got a mighty lot of branches. Leaves, too, look like, and dern if these ain't blossoms. Tiny little cherry blossoms, just as white. Your back got a whole tree on it. In bloom. What God have in mind, I wonder.
