I had me some whippings, but I don't remember nothing like this. Mr. Buddy had a right evil hand too. Whip you for looking at him straight. Sure would. I looked right at him one time and he hauled off and threw the poker at me. Guess he knew what I was a-thinking.'"""
2046,"Sethe groaned and Amy cut her reverie short--long enough to shift Sethe's feet so the weight, resting on leaf-covered stones, was above the ankles."
2047,"""That better?"
2048,Lord what a way to die.
2049,"You gonna die in here, you know."
2050,Ain't no way out of it.
2051,Thank your Maker I come along so's you wouldn't have to die outside in them weeds.
2052,Snake come along he bite you.
2053,Bear eat you up.
2054,"Maybe you should of stayed where you was, Lu."
2055,I can see by your back why you didn't ha ha.
2056,Whoever planted that tree beat Mr. Buddy by a mile.
2057,Glad I ain't you.
2058,"Well, spiderwebs is 'bout all I can do for you."
2059,What's in here ain't enough.
2060,I'll look outside.
2061,"Could use moss, but sometimes bugs and things is in it."
2062,Maybe I ought to break them blossoms open.
2063,"Get that pus to running, you think?"
2064,Wonder what God had in mind.
2065,You must of did something.
2066,Don't run off nowhere now.
2067,Sethe could hear her humming away in the bushes as she hunted spiderwebs.
2068,A humming she concentrated on because as soon as Amy ducked out the baby began to stretch.
2069,"Good question, she was thinking."
2070,What did He have in mind?
2071,"Amy had left the back of Sethe's dress open and now a tail of wind hit it, taking the pain down a step."
2072,A relief that let her feel the lesser pain of her sore tongue.
2073,"Amy returned with two palmfuls of web, which she cleaned of prey and then draped on Sethe's back, saying it was like stringing a tree for Christmas."
2074,"""We got a old nigger girl come by our place."
2075,She don't know nothing.
2076,Sews stuff for Mrs. Buddy--real fine lace but can't barely stick two words together.
2077,"She don't know nothing, just like you."
2078,You don't know a thing.
2079,"End up dead, that's what."
2080,Not me. I'm a get to Boston and get myself some velvet.
2081,Carmine.
2082,"You don't even know about that, do you?"
2083,Now you never will.
2084,Bet you never even sleep with the sun in your face.
2085,I did it a couple of times.
2086,Most times I'm feeding stock before light and don't get to sleep till way after dark comes.
2087,But I was in the back of the wagon once and fell asleep.
2088,Sleeping with the sun in your face is the best old feeling.
2089,Two times I did it.
2090,Once when I was little.
2091,Didn't nobody bother me then.
2092,"Next time, in back of the wagon, it happened again and doggone if the chickens didn't get loose."
2093,Mr. Buddy whipped my tail.
2094,Kentucky ain't no good place to be in.
2095,Boston's the place to be in.
2096,That's where my mother was before she was give to Mr. Buddy.
2097,Joe Nathan said Mr.
2098,"Buddy is my daddy but I don't believe that, you?"""
2099,Sethe told her she didn't believe Mr. Buddy was her daddy.
2100,"""You know your daddy, do you?"""
2101,"""No,"" said Sethe."
2102,"""Neither me. All I know is it ain't him."""

2103,"She stood up then, having finished her repair work, and weaving about the lean-to, her slow-moving eyes pale in the sun that lit her hair, she sang: ""'When the busy day is done And my weary little one Rocketh gently to and fro; When the night winds softly blow, And the crickets in the glen Chirp and chirp and chirp again; Where ""pon the haunted green Fairies dance around their queen, Then from yonder misty skies Cometh Lady Button Eyes."
2104,"Suddenly she stopped weaving and rocking and sat down, her skinny arms wrapped around her knees, her good good hands cupping her elbows."
2105,Her slow-moving eyes stopped and peered into the dirt at her feet.
2106,"""That's my mama's song. She taught me it."""
2107,"""Through the muck and mist and glaam To our quiet cozy home, Where to singing sweet and low Rocks a cradle to and fro."
2108,Where the clock's dull monotone
2109,"Telleth of the day that's done,"
2110,Where the moonbeams hover o'er
2111,"Playthings sleeping on the floor,"
2112,Where my weary wee one lies
2113,Cometh Lady Button Eyes.
2114,Layeth she her hands upon
2115,"My dear weary little one,"
2116,And those white hands overspread
2117,"Like a veil the curly head,"
2118,Seem to fondle and caress
2119,Every little silken tress.
2120,Then she smooths the eyelids down
2121,Over those two eyes of brown
2122,In such soothing tender wise
2123,Cometh Lady Button Eyes.
2124,"Amy sat quietly after her song, then repeated the last line before she stood, left the lean-to and walked off a little ways to lean against a young ash."
2125,When she came back the sun was in the valley below and they were way above it in blue Kentucky light.
2126,"""'You ain't dead yet, Lu? Lu?"""
2128,"""Make you a bet. You make it through the night, you make it all the way."""
2129,Amy rearranged the leaves for comfort and knelt down to massage the swollen feet again.
2130,"""Give these one more real good rub,"" she said, and when Sethe sucked air through her teeth, she said, ""Shut up. You got to keep your mouth shut."""
2131,"Careful of her tongue, Sethe bit down on her lips and let the good hands go to work to the tune of ""So bees, sing soft and bees, sing low."""

2132,"Afterward, Amy moved to the other side of the lean-to where, seated, she lowered her head toward her shoulder and braided her hair, saying, ""Don't up and die on me in the night, you hear? I don't want to see your ugly black face hankering over me. If you do die, just go on off somewhere where I can't see you, hear?"""
2133,"""I hear,"" said Sethe."
2134,"I'll do what I can, miss."
2135,"Sethe never expected to see another thing in this world, so when she felt toes prodding her hip it took a while to come out of a sleep she thought was death."
2136,"She sat up, stiff and shivery, while Amy looked in on her juicy back."
2137,"""Looks like the devil,"" said Amy."
2138,"""But you made it through."
2139,"Come down here, Jesus, Lu made it through."
2140,That's because of me.
2141,I'm good at sick things.
2142,"Can you walk, you think?"""
2143,"""I have to let my water some kind of way."""
2144,"""Let's see you walk on em."""
2145,"It was not good, but it was possible, so Sethe limped, holding on first to Amy, then to a sapling."
2146,"""Was me did it. I'm good at sick things ain't I?"""
2147,"""Yeah,"" said Sethe, ""you good."""
2148,"""We got to get off this here hill. Come on. I'll take you down to the river. That ought to suit you. Me, I'm going to the Pike. Take me straight to Boston. What's that all over your dress?"""
2150,"""You one mess."""
2151,Sethe looked down at her stomach and touched it.
2152,The baby was dead.
2154,"had not died in the night, but the baby had."
2155,"If that was the case, then there was no stopping now."
2156,She would get that milk to her baby girl if she had to swim.
2157,"""Ain't you hungry?"""
2158,Amy asked her.
2159,"""I ain't nothing but in a hurry, miss."""
2160,"""Whoa. Slow down. Want some shoes?"""
2162,"""I figured how,"" said Amy and so she had."
2163,"She tore two pieces from Sethe's shawl, filled them with leaves and tied them over her feet, chattering all the while."
2164,"""How old are you, Lu? I been bleeding for four years but I ain't having nobody's baby. Won't catch me sweating milk cause..."""
2165,"""I know,"" said Sethe."
2166,"""You going to Boston."""
2167,At noon they saw it; then they were near enough to hear it.
2168,By late afternoon they could drink from it if they wanted to.
2169,"Four stars were visible by the time they found, not a riverboat to stow Sethe away on, or a ferryman willing to take on a fugitive passenger--nothing like that--but a whole boat to steal."
2170,"It had one oar, lots of holes and two bird nests."
2171,"""There you go, Lu. Jesus looking at you."""
2172,"Sethe was looking at one mile of dark water, which would have to be split with one oar in a useless boat against a current dedicated to the Mississippi hundreds of miles away."
2173,"It looked like home to her, and the baby (not dead in the least) must have thought so too."
2174,As soon as Sethe got close to the river her own water broke loose to join it.
2175,"The break, followed by the redundant announcement of labor, arched her back."
2176,"""What you doing that for?"" asked Amy."
2177,"""Ain't you got a brain in your head?"
2178,Stop that right now.
2179,"I said stop it, Lu."
2180,You the dumbest thing on this here earth.
2181,Sethe couldn't think of anywhere to go but in.
2182,She waited for the sweet beat that followed the blast of pain.
2183,"On her knees again, she crawled into the boat."
2184,It waddled under her and she had just enough time to brace her leaf-bag feet on the bench when another rip took her breath away.

2185,"Panting under four summer stars, she threw her legs over the sides, because here come the head, as Amy informed her as though she did not know it--as though the rip was a breakup of walnut logs in the brace, or of lightning's jagged tear through a leather sky."
2186,It was stuck.
2187,Face up and drowning in its mother's blood.
2188,Amy stopped begging Jesus and began to curse His daddy.
2189,"""Push!"" screamed Amy."
2190,"""Pull,"" whispered Sethe."
2191,"And the strong hands went to work a fourth time, none too soon, for river water, seeping through any hole it chose, was spreading over Sethe's hips."
2192,She reached one arm back and grabbed the rope while Amy fairly clawed at the head.
2193,"When a foot rose from the river bed and kicked the bottom of the boat and Sethe's behind, she knew it was done and permitted herself a short faint."
2194,"Coming to, she heard no cries, just Amy's encouraging coos."
2195,Nothing happened for so long they both believed they had lost it.
2196,Sethe arched suddenly and the afterbirth shot out.
2197,Then the baby whimpered and Sethe looked.
2198,Twenty inches of cord hung from its belly and it trembled in the cooling evening air.
2199,"Amy wrapped her skirt around it and the wet sticky women clambered ashore to see what, indeed, God had in mind."

2200,"Spores of bluefern growing in the hollows along the riverbank float toward the water in silver-blue lines hard to see unless you are in or near them, lying right at the river's edge when the sunshots are low and drained."
2201,Often they are mistook for insects--but they are seeds in which the whole generation sleeps confident of a future.
2202,And for a moment it is easy to believe each one has one--will become all of what is contained in the spore: will live out its days as planned.
2203,"This moment of certainty lasts no longer than that; longer, perhaps, than the spore itself."
2204,On a riverbank in the cool of a summer evening two women struggled under a shower of silvery blue.
2205,They never expected to see each other again in this world and at the moment couldn't care less.
2206,But there on a summer night surrounded by bluefern they did something together appropriately and well.

2207,"A pateroller passing would have sniggered to see two throw-away people, two lawless outlaws-- a slave and a barefoot whitewoman with unpinned hair--wrapping a ten-minute-old baby in the rags they wore."
2208,But no pateroller came and no preacher.
2209,The water sucked and swallowed itself beneath them.
2210,There was nothing to disturb them at their work.
2211,So they did it appropriately and well.
2212,Twilight came on and Amy said she had to go; that she wouldn't be caught dead in daylight on a busy river with a runaway.
2213,"After rinsing her hands and face in the river, she stood and looked down at the baby wrapped and tied to Sethe's chest."
2214,"""She's never gonna know who I am. You gonna tell her? Who brought her into this here world?"""
2215,"She lifted her chin, looked off into the place where the sun used to be."
2216,"""You better tell her. You hear? Say Miss Amy Denver. Of Boston."""
2217,Sethe felt herself falling into a sleep she knew would be deep.
2218,"On the lip of it, just before going under, she thought, ""That's pretty."
2219,Denver.
2220,Real pretty.
2221,IT WAS TIME to lay it all down.
2222,"Before Paul D came and sat on her porch steps, words whispered in the keeping room had kept her going."

2223,Helped her endure the chastising ghost; refurbished the baby faces of Howard and Buglar and kept them whole in the world because in her dreams she saw only their parts in trees; and kept her husband shadowy but there--somewhere.
2224,"Now Halle's face between the butter press and the churn swelled larger and larger, crowding her eyes and making her head hurt."
2225,"She wished for Baby Suggs' fingers molding her nape, reshaping it, saying, ""Lay em down, Sethe."
2226,Sword and shield.
2227,Down.
2228,Down.
2229,Both of em down.
2230,Down by the riverside.
2231,Sword and shield.
2232,Don't study war no more.
2233,Lay all that mess down.
2234,Sword and shield.
2235,""" And under the pressing fingers and the quiet instructive voice, she would."
2236,"Her heavy knives of defense against misery, regret, gall and hurt, she placed one by one on a bank where dear water rushed on below."
2237,Nine years without the fingers or the voice of Baby Suggs was too much.
2238,And words whispered in the keeping room were too little.
2239,The butter-smeared face of a man God made none sweeter than demanded more: an arch built or a robe sewn.
2240,Some fixing ceremony.
2241,"Sethe decided to go to the Clearing, back where Baby Suggs had danced in sunlight."

2242,"Before and everybody in it had closed down, veiled over and shut away; before it had become the plaything of spirits and the home of the chafed, had been a cheerful, buzzing house where Baby Suggs, holy, loved, cautioned, fed, chastised and soothed."
2243,Where not one but two pots simmered on the stove; where the lamp burned all night long.

2249,"Who decided that, because slave life had"

2250,"""busted her legs, back, head, eyes, hands, kidneys, womb and tongue,"" she had nothing left to make a living with but her heart--which she put to work at once. Accepting no title of honor before her name, but allowing a small caress after it, she became an unchurched preacher, one who visited pulpits and opened her great heart to those who could use it. In winter and fall she carried it to AME's and Baptists, Holinesses and Sanctifieds, the Church of the Redeemer and the Redeemed. Uncalled, unrobed, un anointed, she let her great heart beat in their presence. When warm weather came, Baby Suggs, holy, followed by every black man, woman and child who could make it through, took her great heart to the Clearing--a wide-open place cut deep in the woods nobody knew for what at the end of a path known only to deer and whoever cleared the land in the first place."
2251,"In the heat of every Saturday afternoon, she sat in the clearing while the people waited among the trees."
2252,"After situating herself on a huge flat-sided rock, Baby Suggs bowed her head and prayed silently."
2253,The company watched her from the trees.
2254,They knew she was ready when she put her stick down.
2255,"Then she shouted, ""Let the children come!"" and they ran from the trees toward her."
2256,"""Let your mothers hear you laugh,"" she told them, and the woods rang."
2257,The adults looked on and could not help smiling.
2258,"Then ""Let the grown men come,"" she shouted."
2259,They stepped out one by one from among the ringing trees.
2260,"""Let your wives and your children see you dance,"" she told them, and groundlife shuddered under their feet."
2261,Finally she called the women to her.
2262,"""Cry,"" she told them."
2263,"""For the living and the dead. Just cry."""
2264,And without covering their eyes the women let loose.
2265,"It started that way: laughing children, dancing men, crying women and then it got mixed up."

2266,"Women stopped crying and danced; men sat down and cried; children danced, women laughed, children cried until, exhausted and riven, all and each lay about the Clearing damp and gasping for breath."
2267,"In the silence that followed, Baby Suggs, holy, offered up to them her great big heart."
2268,She did not tell them to clean up their lives or to go and sin no more.
2269,"She did not tell them they were the blessed of the earth, its inheriting meek or its glorybound pure."
2270,She told them that the only grace they could have was the grace they could imagine.
2271,"That if they could not see it, they would not have it."
2272,"""Here,"" she said, ""in this here place, we flesh; flesh that weeps, laughs; flesh that dances on bare feet in grass."
2273,Love it.
2274,Love it hard.
2275,Yonder they do not love your flesh.
2276,They despise it.
2277,They don't love your eyes; they'd just as soon pick em out.
2278,No more do they love the skin on your back.
2279,Yonder they flay it.
2280,And O my people they do not love your hands.
2281,"Those they only use, tie, bind, chop off and leave empty."
2282,Love your hands!
2283,Love them.
2284,Raise them up and kiss them.
2285,"Touch others with them, pat them together, stroke them on your face 'cause they don't love that either."
2286,"You got to love it, you!"
2287,"And no, they ain't in love with your mouth."
2288,"Yonder, out there, they will see it broken and break it again."
2289,What you say out of it they will not heed.
2290,What you scream from it they do not hear.
2291,What you put into it to nourish your body they will snatch away and give you leavins instead.
2292,"No, they don't love your mouth."
2293,You got to love it.
2294,This is flesh I'm talking about here.
2295,Flesh that needs to be loved.
2296,"Feet that need to rest and to dance; backs that need support; shoulders that need arms, strong arms I'm telling you."
2297,"And O my people, out yonder, hear me, they do not love your neck unnoosed and straight."
2298,"So love your neck; put a hand on it, grace it, stroke it and hold it up."
2299,"And all your inside parts that they'd just as soon slop for hogs, you got to love them."
2300,"The dark, dark liver-- love it, love it, and the beat and beating heart, love that too."
2301,More than eyes or feet.
2302,More than lungs that have yet to draw free air.
2303,"More than your life holding womb and your life-giving private parts, hear me now, love your heart."
2304,For this is the prize.
2305,""" Saying no more, she stood up then and danced with her twisted hip the rest of what her heart had to say while the others opened their mouths and gave her the music."
2306,Long notes held until the four-part harmony was perfect enough for their deeply loved flesh.

2308,At the least to listen to the spaces that the long-ago singing had left behind.

2309,"At the most to get a clue from her husband's dead mother as to what she should do with her sword and shield now, dear Jesus, now nine years after Baby Suggs, holy, proved herself a liar, dismissed her great heart and lay in the keeping-room bed roused once in a while by a craving for color and not for another thing."

2310,"""Those white things have taken all I had or dreamed,"" she said, ""and broke my heartstrings too. There is no bad luck in the world but whitefolks."" shut down and put up with the venom of its ghost."
2311,"No more lamp all night long, or neighbors dropping by."
2312,No low conversations after supper.
2313,No watched barefoot children playing in the shoes of strangers.
2314,"Baby Suggs, holy, believed she had lied."
2315,There was no grace-imaginary or real--and no sunlit dance in a Clearing could change that.

2317,Yet it was to the Clearing that Sethe determined to go--to pay tribute to Halle.
2318,"Before the light changed, while it was still the green blessed place she remembered: misty with plant steam and the decay of berries."
2319,She put on a shawl and told Denver and Beloved to do likewise.
2320,"All three set out late one Sunday morning, Sethe leading, the girls trotting behind, not a soul in sight."
2321,"When they reached the woods it took her no time to find the path through it because big-city revivals were held there regularly now, complete with food- laden tables, banjos and a tent."
2322,"The old path was a track now, but still arched over with trees dropping buckeyes onto the grass below."
2323,"There was nothing to be done other than what she had done, but Sethe blamed herself for Baby Suggs' collapse."
2324,"However many times Baby denied it, Sethe knew the grief at started when she jumped down off the wagon,"
2325,her newborn tied to her chest in the underwear of a whitegirl looking for Boston.
2326,"Followed by the two girls, down a bright green corridor of oak and horse chestnut, Sethe began to sweat a sweat just like the other one when she woke, mud-caked, on the banks of the Ohio."
2327,Amy was gone.
2328,"Sethe was alone and weak, but alive, and so was her baby."
2329,She walked a ways downriver and then stood gazing at the glimmering water.
2330,"By and by a flatbed slid into view, but she could not see if the figures on it were whitepeople or not."
2331,She began to sweat from a fever she thanked God for since it would certainly keep her baby warm.

2332,When the flatbed was beyond her sight she stumbled on and found herself near three coloredpeople fishing-- two boys and an older man. She stopped and waited to be spoken to. One of the boys pointed and the man looked over his shoulder at her--a quick look since all he needed to know about her he could see in no time.
2333,No one said anything for a while.
2334,"Then the man said, ""Headin'"
2336,"""Yes, sir,"" said Sethe."
2337,"""Anybody know you coming?"""
2339,He looked at her again and nodded toward a rock that stuck out of the ground above him like a bottom lip.
2340,Sethe walked to it and sat down.
2341,The stone had eaten the sun's rays but was nowhere near as hot as she was.
2342,"Too tired to move, she stayed there, the sun in her eyes making her dizzy."
2343,Sweat poured over her and bathed the baby completely.
2344,"She must have slept sitting up, because when next she opened her eyes the man was standing in front of her with a smoking-hot piece of fried eel in his hands."
2345,"It was an effort to reach for, more to smell, impossible to eat."
2346,She begged him for water and he gave her some of the Ohio in a jar.
2347,Sethe drank it all and begged more.
2348,"The clanging was back in her head but she refused to believe that she had come all that way, endured all she had, to die on the wrong side of the river."
2349,The man watched her streaming face and called one of the boys over.
2350,"""Take off that coat,"" he told him."
2352,"""You heard me."""
2353,"The boy slipped out of his jacket, whining, ""What you gonna do? What I'm gonna wear?"""
2354,"The man untied the baby from her chest and wrapped it in the boy's coat, knotting the sleeves in front."
2355,"""What I'm gonna wear?"""

2356,"The old man sighed and, after a pause, said, ""You want it back, then go head and take it off that baby. Put the baby naked in the grass and put your coat back on. And if you can do it, then go on 'way somewhere and don't come back."""
2357,"The boy dropped his eyes, then turned to join the other."
2358,"With eel in her hand, the baby at her feet, Sethe dozed, dry-mouthed and sweaty."
2359,Evening came and the man touched her shoulder.
2360,"Contrary to what she expected they poled upriver, far away from the rowboat Amy had found."
2361,"Just when she thought he was taking her back to Kentucky, he turned the flatbed and crossed the Ohio like a shot."
2362,"There he helped her up the steep bank, while the boy without a jacket carried the baby who wore it."
2363,The man led her to a brush-covered hutch with a beaten floor.
2364,"""Wait here. Somebody be here directly. Don't move. They'll find you."""
2365,"""Thank you,"" she said."
2366,"""I wish I knew your name so I could remember you right."""
2367,"""Name's Stamp,"" he said."
2368,"""Stamp Paid. Watch out for that there baby, you hear?"""
2369,"""I hear. I hear,"" she said, but she didn't."
2370,Hours later a woman was right up on her before she heard a thing.
2371,"A short woman, young, with a croaker sack, greeted her."
2372,"""'Saw the sign a while ago,"" she said."
2373,"""But I couldn't get here no quicker."""
2374,"""What sign?"" asked Sethe."
2375,"""Stamp leaves the old sty open when there's a crossing. Knots a white rag on the post if it's a child too."""
2376,She knelt and emptied the sack.
2377,"""My name's Ella,"" she said, taking a wool blanket, cotton cloth, two baked sweet potatoes and a pair of men's shoes from the sack."
2378,"""My husband, John, is out yonder a ways. Where you heading?"""
2379,Sethe told her about Baby Suggs where she had sent her three children.
2380,Ella wrapped a cloth strip tight around the baby's navel as she listened for the holes--the things the fugitives did not say; the questions they did not ask.
2381,"Listened too for the unnamed, unmentioned people left behind."
2382,She shook gravel from the men's shoes and tried to force Sethe's feet into them.
2383,They would not go.
2384,"Sadly, they split them down the heel, sorry indeed to ruin so valuable an item."
2385,"Sethe put on the boy's jacket, not daring to ask whether there was any word of the children."
2386,"""They made it,"" said Ella."
2387,"""Stamp ferried some of that party."
2388,Left them on Bluestone.
2389,It ain't too far.

2391,"""They be glad to see you,"" said Ella."

2394,"""I hope she makes it."""
2395,"Ella looked at the tiny, dirty face poking out of the wool blanket and shook"
2396,her head.
2397,"""Hard to say,"" she said."
2398,"""If anybody was to ask me I'd say, 'Don't love nothing.' """

2400,"""You had that baby by yourself?"""
2401,"""No. Whitegirl helped."""
2402,"""Then we better make tracks."""

2404,They were asleep she said and Sethe was too uglylooking to wake them in the night.

2410,"Then, while waiting for another pan of heated water, she sat next to her and stitched gray cotton."
2411,Sethe dozed and woke to the washing of her hands and arms.
2412,"After each bathing, Baby covered her with a quilt and put another pan on in the kitchen."
2413,"Tearing sheets, stitching the gray cotton, she supervised the woman in the bonnet who tended the baby and cried into her cooking."
2414,"When Sethe's legs were done, Baby looked at her feet and wiped them lightly."
2415,She cleaned between Sethe's legs with two separate pans of hot water and then tied her stomach and vagina with sheets.
2416,Finally she attacked the unrecognizable feet.
2417,"""You feel this?"""
2418,"""Feel what?"" asked Sethe."
2419,"""Nothing. Heave up."""
2420,She helped Sethe to a rocker and lowered her feet into a bucket of salt water and juniper.
2421,The rest of the night Sethe sat soaking.
2422,The crust from her nipples Baby softened with lard and then washed away.

2425,"""And when you through, call me."""

2427,She frowned and looked at her daughter-in-law bending toward the baby.

2458,"""Wedding present."""
2459,"""Be nice if there was a groom to go with it."""
2460,She gazed into her hand.
2461,"""What you think happened to him?"""
2462,"""I don't know,"" said Sethe."
2463,"""He wasn't where he said to meet him at. I had to get out. Had to."""
2464,Sethe watched the drowsy eyes of the sucking girl for a moment then looked at Baby Suggs' face.
2465,"""He'll make it. If I made it, Halle sure can."""
2466,"""Well, put these on. Maybe they'll light his way."""

2468,"""I need holes in my ears."""
2469,"""I'll do it,"" said Baby Suggs."
2470,"""Soon's you up to it."""

2472,"girl, who reached for them over and over again."
2473,"In the Clearing, Sethe found Baby's old preaching rock and remembered the smell of leaves simmering in the sun, thunderous feet and the shouts that ripped pods off the limbs of the chestnuts."
2474,"With Baby Suggs' heart in charge, the people let go."
2475,Sethe had had twenty-eight days--the travel of one whole moon--of unslaved life.
2476,From the pure clear stream of spit that the little girl dribbled into her face to her oily blood was twenty-eight days.
2477,"Days of healing, ease and real-talk."

2478,"Days of company: knowing the names of forty, fifty other Negroes, their views, habits; where they had been and what done; of feeling their fun and sorrow along with her own, which made it better."
2479,One taught her the alphabet; another a stitch.
2480,All taught her how it felt to wake up at dawn and decide what to do with the
2482,That's how she got through the waiting for Halle.
2483,"Bit by bit, at and in the Clearing, along with the others, she had claimed herself."
2484,Freeing yourself was one thing; claiming ownership of that freed self was another.
2485,"Now she sat on Baby Suggs' rock, Denver and Beloved watching her from the trees."
2486,"There will never be a day, she thought, when Halle will knock on the door."
2487,Not knowing it was hard; knowing it was harder.
2488,"Just the fingers, she thought."
2489,"Just let me feel your fingers again on the back of my neck and I will lay it all down, make a way out of this no way."
2490,Sethe bowed her head and sure enough--they were there.
2491,"Lighter now, no more than the strokes of bird feather, but unmistakably caressing fingers."
2492,"She had to relax a bit to let them do their work, so light was the touch, childlike almost, more finger kiss than kneading."
2493,Still she was grateful for the effort; Baby Suggs' long distance love was equal to any skin-close love she had known.

2494,"The desire, let alone the gesture, to meet her needs was good enough to lift her spirits to the place where she could take the next step: ask for some clarifying word; some advice about how to keep on with a brain greedy for news nobody could live with in a world happy to provide it."

2495,"She knew Paul D was adding something to her life--something she wanted to count on but was scared to. Now he had added more: new pictures and old rememories that broke her heart. Into the empty space of not knowing about Halle---a space sometimes colored with righteous resentment at what could have been his cowardice, or stupidity or bad luck--that empty place of no definite news was filled now with a brand-new sorrow and who could tell how many more on the way."
2496,"Years ago--when was alive--she had women friends, men friends from all around to share grief with."
2497,"Then there was no one, for they would not visit her while the baby ghost filled the house, and she returned their disapproval with the potent pride of the mistreated."
2498,"But now there was someone to share it, and he had beat the spirit away the very day he entered her house and no sign of it since."

2499,"A blessing, but in its place he brought another kind of haunting: Halle's face smeared with butter and the dabber too; his own mouth jammed full of iron, and Lord knows what else he could tell her if he wanted to."
2500,The fingers touching the back of her neck were stronger now-- the strokes bolder as though Baby Suggs were gathering strength.
2501,"Putting the thumbs at the nape, while the fingers pressed the sides."
2502,"Harder, harder, the fingers moved slowly around toward her windpipe, making little circles on the way."
2503,Sethe was actually more surprised than frightened to find that she was being strangled.
2504,Or so it seemed.
2505,"In any case, Baby Suggs' fingers had a grip on her that would not let her breathe."
2506,"Tumbling forward from her seat on the rock, she clawed at the hands that were not there."
2507,Her feet were thrashing by the time Denver got to her and then Beloved.
2509,Denver shouted.
2510,"""Ma'ammy!"" and turned her mother over on her back."
2511,The fingers left off and Sethe had to swallow huge draughts of air before she recognized her daughter's face next to her own and Beloved's hovering above.
2512,"""You all right?"""
2514,"""Somebody choked me,"" said Sethe."
2515,Sethe rubbed her neck and struggled to a sitting position.
2516,"""Grandma Baby, I reckon. I just asked her to rub my neck, like she used to and she was doing fine and then just got crazy with it, I guess."""
2517,"""She wouldn't do that to you, Ma'am. Grandma Baby? Uh uh."""
2518,"""Help me up from here."""
2520,Beloved was pointing at Sethe's neck.
2521,"""What is it? What you see?"" asked Sethe."
2522,"""Bruises,"" said Denver."
2523,"""On my neck?"""
2524,"""Here,"" said Beloved."
2525,"""Here and here, too."""
2526,"She reached out her hand and touched the splotches, gathering color darker than Sethe's dark throat, and her fingers were mighty cool."
2527,"""That don't help nothing,"" Denver said, but Beloved was leaning in, her two hands stroking the damp skin that felt like chamois and looked like taffeta."
2528,Sethe moaned.
2529,The girl's fingers were so cool and knowing.

2530,"Sethe's knotted, private, walk-on-water life gave in a bit, softened, and it seemed that the glimpse of happiness she caught in the shadows swinging hands on the road to the carnival was a likelihood--if she could just manage the news Paul D brought and the news he kept to himself."
2531,Just manage it.
2532,"Not break, fall or cry each time a hateful picture drifted in front of her face."
2533,"Not develop some permanent craziness like Baby Suggs' friend, a young woman in a bonnet whose food was full of tears."
2534,"Like Aunt Phyllis, who slept with her eyes wide open."
2535,"Like Jackson Till, who slept under the bed."

2537,As she had.
2538,Alone with her daughter in a haunted house she managed every damn thing.
2539,"Why now, with Paul D instead of the ghost, was she breaking up?"
2540,getting scared?
2541,needing Baby?
2542,"The worst was over, wasn't it?"
2543,"She had already got through, hadn't she?"
2544,"With the ghost in she could bear, do, solve anything."
2545,Now a hint of what had happened to Halie and she cut out like a rabbit looking for its mother.
2546,Beloved's fingers were heavenly.
2547,"Under them and breathing evenly again, the anguish rolled down."
2548,The peace Sethe had come there to find crept into her.
2549,"We must look a sight, she thought, and closed her eyes to see it: the three women in the middle of the Clearing, at the base of the rock where Baby Suggs, holy, had loved."
2550,"One seated, yielding up her throat to the kind hands of one of the two kneeling before her."
2551,Denver watched the faces of the other two.
2552,Beloved watched the work her thumbs were doing and must have loved what she saw because she leaned over and kissed the tenderness under Sethe's chin.

2557,"""Come on up! Up!"""
