2561,"Sethe was bothered, not because of the kiss, but because, just before it, when she was feeling so fine letting Beloved massage away the pain, the fingers she was loving and the ones that had soothed her before they strangled her had reminded her of something that now slipped her mind."
2562,"But one thing for sure, Baby Suggs had not choked her as first she thought."

2563,"Denver was right, and walking in the dappled tree-light, clearer-headed now-- away from the enchantment of the Clearing--Sethe remembered the tou ch of those fingers that she knew better than her own."

2564,"They had bathed her in sections, wrapped her womb, combed her hair, oiled her nipples, stitched her clothes, cleaned her feet, greased her back and dropped just about anything they were doing to massage Sethe's nape when, especially in the early days, her spirits fell down under the weight of the things she remembered and those she did not: schoolteacher writing in ink she herself had made while his nephews played on her; the face of the woman in a felt hat as she rose to stretch in the field."
2565,"If she lay among all the hands in the world, she would know Baby Suggs' just as she did the good hands of the whitegirl looking for velvet."
2566,But for eighteen years she had lived in a house full of touches from the other side.
2567,And the thumbs that pressed her nape were the same.
2568,Maybe that was where it had gone to.
2569,"After Paul D beat it out of , maybe it collected itself in the Clearing."
2570,"Reasonable, she thought."
2571,"Why she had taken Denver and Beloved with her didn't puzzle her now--at the time it seemed impulse, with a vague wish for protection."
2572,"And the girls had saved her, Beloved so agitated she behaved like a two-year- old."
2573,"Like a faint smell of burning that disappears when the fire is cut off or the window opened for a breeze, the suspicion that the girl's touch was also exactly like the baby's ghost dissipated."
2574,"It was only a tiny disturbance anyway--not strong enough to divert her from the ambition welling in her now: she wanted Paul D. No matter what he told and knew, she wanted him in her life."
2575,"More than commemorating Halle, that is what she had come to the Clearing to figure out, and now it was figured."
2576,"Trust and rememory, yes, the way she believed it could be when he cradled her before the cooking stove."
2577,"The weight and angle of him; the true-to-life beard hair on him; arched back, educated hands."
2578,His waiting eyes and awful human power.
2579,The mind of him that knew her own.

2580,"Her story was bearable because it was his as well--to tell, to refine and tell again. The things neither knew about the other--the things neither had word-shapes for--well, it would come in time: where they led him off to sucking iron; the perfect death of her crawling-already?"
2581,baby.

2582,"She wanted to get back--fast. Set these idle girls to some work that would fill their wandering heads. Rushing through the green corridor, cooler now because the sun had moved, it occurred to her that the two were alike as sisters. Their obedience and absolute reliability shot through with surprise. Sethe understood Denver. Solitude had made her secretive--self-manipulated."
2583,Years of haunting had dulled her in ways you wouldn't believe and sharpened her in ways you wouldn't believe either.
2584,The consequence was a timid but hard-headed daughter Sethe would die to protect.

2585,"The other, Beloved, she knew less, nothing, about---except that there was nothing she wouldn't do for Sethe and that Denver and she liked each other's company. Now she thought she knew why. They spent up or held on to their feelings in harmonious ways. What one had to give the other was pleased to take. They hung back in the trees that ringed the Clearing, then rushed into it with screams and kisses when Sethe choked--anyhow that's how she explained it to herself for she noticed neither competition between the two nor domination by one."
2586,"On her mind was the supper she wanted to fix for Paul D--something difficult to do, something she would do just so--to launch her newer, stronger life with a tender man."
2587,"Those litty bitty potatoes browned on all sides, heavy on the pepper; snap beans seasoned with rind; yellow squash sprinkled with vinegar and sugar."
2588,Maybe corn cut from the cob and fried with green onions and butter.
2589,"Raised bread, even."
2590,"Her mind, searching the kitchen before she got to it, was so full of her offering she did not see right away, in the space under the white stairs, the wooden tub and Paul D sitting in it."
2591,She smiled at him and he smiled back.
2592,"""Summer must be over,"" she said."
2593,"""Come on in here."""
2594,"""Uh uh. Girls right behind me."""
2595,"""I don't hear nobody."""
2596,"""I have to cook, Paul D."""
2597,"""What you gonna cook?"""
2598,"""I thought some snap beans."""
2600,"""Fry up a little corn?"""
2603,He stood up and made her stay there while he held her in his arms.
2604,Her dress soaked up the water from his body.
2605,His jaw was near her ear.
2606,Her chin touched his shoulder.
2607,There was no question but that she could do it.
2608,"Just like the day she arrived at --sure enough, she had milk enough for all."
2609,"Beloved came through the door and they ought to have heard her tread, but they didn't."
2610,"Breathing and murmuring, breathing and murmuring."
2611,Beloved heard them as soon as the door banged shut behind her.
2612,She jumped at the slam and swiveled her head toward the whispers coming from behind the white stairs.
2613,She took a step and felt like crying.
2614,"She had been so close, then closer."
2615,And it was so much better than the anger that ruled when Sethe did or thought
2616,anything that excluded herself.
2617,She could bear the hours---nine or ten of them each day but one--- when Sethe was gone.
2618,"Bear even the nights when she was close but out of sight, behind walls and doors lying next to him."
2619,"But now-- even the daylight time that Beloved had counted on, disciplined herself to be content with, was being reduced, divided by Sethe's willingness to pay attention to other things."
2620,Him mostly.
2621,Him who said something to her that made her run out into the woods and talk to herself on a rock.
2622,Him who kept her hidden at night behind doors.
2623,And him who had hold of her now whispering behind the stairs after Beloved had rescued her neck and was ready now to put her hand in that woman's own.
2624,Beloved turned around and left.
2625,"Denver had not arrived, or else she was waiting somewhere outside."
2626,"Beloved went to look, pausing to watch a cardinal hop from limb to branch."
2627,"She followed the blood spot shifting in the leaves until she lost it and even then she walked on, backward, still hungry for another glimpse."
2628,She turned finally and ran through the woods to the stream.
2629,Standing close to its edge she watched her reflection there.
2630,"When Denver's face joined hers, they stared at each other in the water."
2631,"""You did it, I saw you,"" said Denver."
2633,"""I saw your face. You made her choke."""
2634,"""I didn't do it."""
2635,"""You told me you loved her."""
2636,"""I fixed it, didn't I? Didn't I fix her neck?"""
2637,"""After. After you choked her neck."""
2638,"""I kissed her neck. I didn't choke it. The circle of iron choked it."""
2640,Denver grabbed Beloved's arm.
2641,"""Look out, girl,"" said Beloved and, snatching her arm away, ran ahead as fast as she could along the stream that sang on the other side of the woods."
2642,"Left alone, Denver wondered if, indeed, she had been wrong."
2643,"She and Beloved were standing in the trees whispering, while Sethe sat on the rock."
2644,"Denver knew that the Clearing used to be where Baby Suggs preached, but that was when she was a baby."
2645,She had never been there herself to remember it .
2646,and the field behind it were all the world she knew or wanted.
2647,Once upon a time she had known more and wanted to.
2648,Had walked the path leading to a real other house.
2649,Had stood outside the window listening.

2650,"Four times she did it on her own--crept away from early in the afternoon when her mother and grandmother had their guard down, just before supper, after chores; the blank hour before gears changed to evening occupations."
2651,Denver had walked off looking for the house other children visited but not her.
2652,When she found it she was too timid to go to the front door so she peeped in the window.
2653,Lady Jones sat in a straight-backed chair; several children sat cross-legged on the floor in front of her.
2654,Lady Jones had a book.
2655,The children had slates.
2656,Lady Jones was saying something too soft for Denver to hear.
2657,The children were saying it after her.
2658,Four times Denver went to look.
2659,"The fifth time Lady Jones caught her and said, ""Come in the front door, Miss Denver. This is not a side show."""
2660,So she had almost a whole year of the company of her peers and along with them learned to spell and count.
2661,"She was seven, and those two hours in the afternoon were precious to her."
2662,Especially so because she had done it on her own and was pleased and surprised by the pleasure and surprise it created in her mother and her brothers.
2663,"For a nickel a month, Lady Jones did what whitepeople thought unnecessary if not illegal: crowded her little parlor with the colored children who had time for and interest in book learning."
2664,"The nickel, tied to a handkerchief knot, tied to her belt, that she carried to Lady Jones, thrilled her."

2665,"The effort to handle chalk expertly and avoid the scream it would make; the capital w, the little i, the beauty of the letters in her name, the deeply mournful sentences from the Bible Lady Jones used as a textbook."
2666,Denver practiced every morning; starred every afternoon.
2667,She was so happy she didn't even know she was being avoided by her classmates--that they made excuses and altered their pace not to walk with her.

2668,"It was Nelson Lord- -the boy as smart as she was--who put a stop to it; who asked her the question about her mother that put chalk, the little i and all the rest that those afternoons held, out of reach forever."
2669,"She should have laughed when he said it, or pushed him down, but there was no meanness in his face or his voice."
2670,Just curiosity.
2671,But the thing that leapt up in her when he asked it was a thing that had been lying there all along.
2672,She never went back.
2673,"The second day she didn't go, Sethe asked her why not."
2674,Denver didn't answer.

2675,She was too scared to ask her brothers or anyone else Nelson Lord's question because certain odd and terrifying feelings about her mother were collecting around the thing that leapt up inside her.
2676,"Later on, after Baby Suggs died, she did not wonder why Howard and Buglar had run away."
2677,She did not agree with Sethe that they left because of the ghost.
2678,"If so, what took them so long?"
2679,They had lived with it as long as she had.
2680,"But if Nelson Lord was right--no wonder they were sulky, staying away from home as much as they could."
2681,Meanwhile the monstrous and unmanageable dreams about Sethe found release in the concentration Denver began to fix on the baby ghost.
2682,"Before Nelson Lord, she had been barely interested in its antics."
2683,The patience of her mother and grandmother in its presence made her indifferent to it.
2684,"Then it began to irritate her, wear her out with its mischief."
2685,That was when she walked off to follow the children to Lady Jones' house- school.
2686,"Now it held for her all the anger, love and fear she didn't know what to do with."
2687,"Even when she did muster the courage to ask Nelson Lord's question, she could not hear Sethe's answer, nor Baby Suggs' words, nor anything at all thereafter."
2688,For two years she walked in a silence too solid for penetration but which gave her eyes a power even she found hard to believe.
2689,"The black nostrils of a sparrow sitting on a branch sixty feet above her head, for instance."
2690,For two years she heard nothing at all and then she heard close thunder crawling up the stairs.
2691,Baby Suggs thought it was Here Boy padding into places he never went.
2692,Sethe thought it was the India-rubber ball the boys played with bounding down the stairs.
2693,"""Is that damn dog lost his mind?"" shouted Baby Suggs."
2694,"""He's on the porch,"" said Sethe."
2695,"""See for yourself."""
2696,"""Well, what's that I'm hearing then?"""
2697,Sethe slammed the stove lid.
2698,"""Buglar! Buglar! I told you all not to use that ball in here."""
2699,She looked at the white stairs and saw Denver at the top.
2700,"""She was trying to get upstairs."""
2702,The cloth she used to handle the stove lid was balled in Sethe's hand.
2703,"""The baby,"" said Denver."
2704,"""Didn't you hear her crawling?"""
2705,What to jump on first was the problem: that Denver heard anything at all or that the crawling-already?

2706,"baby girl was still at it but more so, The return of Denver's hearing, cut off by an answer she could not hear to hear, cut on by the sound of her dead sister trying to climb the stairs, signaled another shift in the fortunes of the people of ."
2707,From then on the presence was full of spite.
2708,Instead of sighs and accidents there was pointed and deliberate abuse.
2709,"Buglar and Howard grew furious at the company of the women in the house, and spent in sullen reproach any time they had away from their odd work in town carrying water and feed at the stables."
2710,Until the spite became so personal it drove each off.
2711,"Baby Suggs grew tired, went to bed and stayed there until her big old heart quit."

2712,"Except for an occasional request for color she said practically nothing--until the afternoon of the last day of her life when she got out of bed, skipped slowly to the door of the keeping room and announced to Sethe and Denver the lesson she had learned from her sixty years a slave and ten years free: that there was no bad luck in the world but white people."
2713,"""They don't know when to stop,"" she said, and returned to her bed, pulled up the quilt and left them to hold that thought forever."
2714,"Shortly afterward Sethe and Denver tried to call up and reason with the baby ghost, but got nowhere."
2715,"It took a man, Paul D, to shout it off, beat it off and take its place for himself."
2716,"And carnival or no carnival, Denver preferred the venomous baby to him any day."

2717,"During the first days after Paul D moved in, Denver stayed in her emerald closet as long as she could, lonely as a mountain and almost as big, thinking everybody had somebody but her; thinking even a ghost's company was denied her."
2718,So when she saw the black dress with two unlaced shoes beneath it she trembled with secret thanks.
2719,"Whatever her power and however she used it, Beloved was hers."
2720,"Denver was alarmed by the harm she thought Beloved planned for Sethe, but felt helpless to thwart it, so unrestricted was her need to love another."
2721,The display she witnessed at the Clearing shamed her because the choice between Sethe and Beloved was without conflict.
2722,"Walking toward the stream, beyond her green bush house, she let herself wonder what if Beloved really decided to choke her mother."
2723,Would she let it happen?
2724,"Murder, Nelson Lord had said."
2725,"""Didn't your mother get locked away for murder? Wasn't you in there with her when she went?"""
2726,It was the second question that made it impossible for so long to ask Sethe about the first.
2727,"The thing that leapt up had been coiled in just such a place: a darkness, a stone, and some other thing that moved by itself."

2728,"She went deaf rather than hear the answer, and like the little four o'clocks that searched openly for sunlight, then closed themselves tightly when it left, Denver kept watch for the baby and withdrew from everything else."
2729,Until Paul D came.
2730,But the damage he did came undone with the miraculous resurrection of Beloved.

2731,"Just ahead, at the edge of the stream, Denver could see her silhouette, standing barefoot in the water, liking her black skirts up above her calves, the beautiful head lowered in rapt attention."
2732,"Blinking fresh tears Denver approached her--eager for a word, a sign of forgiveness."
2733,Denver took off her shoes and stepped into the water with her.
2734,It took a moment for her to drag her eyes from the spectacle of Beloved's head to see what she was staring at.
2735,"A turtle inched along the edge, turned and climbed to dry ground."
2736,"Not far behind it was another one, headed in the same direction."
2737,Four placed plates under a hovering motionless bowl.
2738,"Behind her in the grass the other one moving quickly, quickly to mount her."
2739,The impregnable strength of him--earthing his feet near her shoulders.
2740,"The embracing necks--hers stretching up toward his bending down, the pat pat pat of their touching heads."
2741,"No height was beyond her yearning neck, stretched like a finger toward his, risking everything outside the bowl just to touch his face."
2742,"The gravity of their shields, clashing, countered and mocked the floating heads touching."
2743,Beloved dropped the folds of her skirt.
2744,It spread around her.
2745,The hem darkened in the water.
2746,"OUT OF SIGHT of Mister's sight, away, praise His name, from the smiling boss of roosters, Paul D began to tremble."
2747,Not all at once and not so anyone could tell.

2748,"When he turned his head, aiming for a last look at Brother, turned it as much as the rope that connected his neck to the axle of a buckboard allowed, and, later on, when they fastened the iron around his ankles and clamped the wrists as well, there was no outward sign of trembling at all."
2749,"Nor eighteen days after that when he saw the ditches; the one thousand feet of earth--five feet deep, five feet wide, into which wooden boxes had been fitted."
2750,A door of bars that you could lift on hinges like a cage opened into three walls and a roof of scrap lumber and red dirt.
2751,Two feet of it over his head; three feet of open trench in front of him with anything that crawled or scurried welcome to share that grave calling itself quarters.
2752,And there were forty-five more.
2753,"He was sent there after trying to kill Brandywine, the man schoolteacher sold him to."
2754,"Brandywine was leading him, in a coffle with ten others, through Kentucky into Virginia."
2755,"He didn't know exactly what prompted him to try--other than Halle, Sixo, Paul A, Paul F and Mister."
2756,But the trembling was fixed by the time he knew it was there.
2757,"Still no one else knew it, because it began inside."
2758,"A flutter of a kind, in the chest, then the shoulder blades."
2759,It felt like rippling-- gentle at first and then wild.

2760,"As though the further south they led him the more his blood, frozen like an ice pond for twenty years, began thawing, breaking into pieces that, once melted, had no choice but to swirl and eddy."
2761,Sometimes it was in his leg.
2762,Then again it moved to the base of his spine.
2763,"By the time they unhitched him from the wagon and he saw nothing but dogs and two shacks in a world of sizzling grass, the roiling blood was shaking him to and fro."
2764,But no one could tell.
2765,The wrists he held out for the bracelets that evening were steady as were the legs he stood on when chains were attached to the leg irons.
2766,"But when they shoved him into the box and dropped the cage door down, his hands quit taking instruction."
2767,"On their own, they traveled."
2768,Nothing could stop them or get their attention.
2769,They would not hold his penis to urinate or a spoon to scoop lumps of lima beans into his mouth.
2770,The miracle of their obedience came with the hammer at dawn.
2771,All forty-six men woke to rifle shot.
2772,All forty-six.
2773,Three whitemen walked along the trench unlocking the doors one by one.
2774,No one stepped through.
2775,"When the last lock was opened, the three returned and lifted the bars, one by one."
2776,"And one by one the blackmen emerged--promptly and without the poke of a rifle butt if they had been there more than a day; promptly with the butt if, like Paul D, they had just arrived."

2777,"When all forty-six were standing in a line in the trench, another rifle shot signaled the climb out and up to the ground above, where one thousand feet of the best hand-forged chain in Georgia stretched."
2778,Each man bent and waited.
2779,The first man picked up the end and threaded it through the loop on his leg iron.
2780,"He stood up then, and, shuffling a little, brought the chain tip to the next prisoner, who did likewise."
2781,"As the chain was passed on and each man stood in the other's place, the line of men turned around, facing the boxes they had come out of."
2782,Not one spoke to the other.
2783,At least not with words.
2784,"The eyes had to tell what there was to tell: ""Help me this mornin; 's bad""; ""I'm a make it""; ""New man""; ""Steady now steady."""
2785,"Chain-up completed, they knelt down."
2786,"The dew, more likely than not, was mist by then."
2787,Heavy sometimes and if the dogs were quiet and just breathing you could hear doves.
2788,"Kneeling in the mist they waited for the whim of a guard, or two, or three."
2789,Or maybe all of them wanted it.
2790,Wanted it from one prisoner in particular or none-- or all.
2791,"""Breakfast? Want some breakfast, nigger?"""
2793,"""Hungry, nigger?"""
2795,"""Here you go."""
2796,"Occasionally a kneeling man chose gunshot in his head as the price, maybe, of taking a bit of foreskin with him to Jesus."
2797,Paul D did not know that then.
2798,"He was looking at his palsied hands, smelling the guard, listening to his soft grunts so like the doves', as he stood before the man kneeling in mist on his right."
2799,"Convinced he was next, Paul D retched--vomiting up nothing at all."
2800,An observing guard smashed his shoulder with the rifle and the engaged one decided to skip the new man for the time being lest his pants and shoes got soiled by nigger puke.
2802,"It was the first sound, other than ""Yes, sir"" a blackman was allowed to speak each morning, and the lead chain gave it everything he had."
2804,It was never clear to Paul D how he knew when to shout that mercy.
2805,They called him Hi Man and Paul D thought at first the guards told him when to give the signal that let the prisoners rise up off their knees and dance two-step to the music of hand forged iron.
2806,Later he doubted it.

2807,"He believed to this day that the ""Hiiii!"" at dawn and the ""Hoooo!"" when evening came were the responsibility Hi Man assumed because he alone knew what was enough, what was too much, when things were over, when the time had come."
2808,"They chain-danced over the fields, through the woods to a trail that ended in"
2809,"the astonishing beauty of feldspar, and there Paul D's hands disobeyed the furious rippling of his blood and paid attention."
2810,"With a sledge hammer in his hands and Hi Man's lead, the men got through."
2811,"They sang it out and beat it up, garbling the words so they could not be understood; tricking the words so their syllables yielded up other meanings."
2812,They sang the women they knew; the children they had been; the animals they had tamed themselves or seen others tame.
2813,They sang of bosses and masters and misses; of mules and dogs and the shamelessness of life.
2814,They sang lovingly of graveyards and sisters long gone.
2815,"Of pork in the woods; meal in the pan; fish on the line; cane, rain and rocking chairs."
2816,And they beat.
2817,"The women for having known them and no more, no more; the children for having been them but never again."
2818,They killed a boss so often and so completely they had to bring him back to life to pulp him one more time.
2819,"Tasting hot mealcake among pine trees, they beat it away."
2820,"Singing love songs to Mr. Death, they smashed his head."
2821,"More than the rest, they killed the flirt whom folks called Life for leading them on."
2822,Making them think the next sunrise would be worth it; that another stroke of time would do it at last.
2823,Only when she was dead would they be safe.

2824,"The successful ones--the ones who had been there enough years to have maimed, mutilated, maybe even buried her--kept watch over the others who were still in her cock-teasing hug, caring and looking forward, remembering and looking back."

2825,"They were the ones whose eyes said, ""Help me, 's bad""; or ""Look out,"" meaning this might be the day I bay or eat my own mess or run, and it was this last that had to be guarded against, for if one pitched and ran--all, all forty-six, would be yanked by the chain that bound them and no telling who or how many would be killed."
2826,"A man could risk his own life, but not his brother's."
2827,"So the eyes said, ""Steady now,"" and ""Hang by me."""
2828,Eighty-six days and done.
2829,Life was dead.
2830,Paul D beat her butt all day every day till there was not a whimper in her.
2831,"Eighty-six days and his hands were still, waiting serenely each rat-rustling night for ""Hiiii!"" at dawn and the eager clench on the hammer's shaft."
2832,Life rolled over dead.
2833,Or so he thought.
2834,It rained.
2835,Snakes came down from short-leaf pine and hemlock.
2836,It rained.
2837,It rained.
2838,"Cypress, yellow poplar, ash and palmetto drooped under five days of rain without wind."
2839,"By the eighth day the doves were nowhere in sight, by the ninth even the salamanders were gone."
2840,Dogs laid their ears down and stared over their paws.
2841,The men could not work.
2842,"Chain-up was slow, breakfast abandoned, the two-step became a slow drag over soupy grass and unreliable earth."
2843,"It was decided to lock everybody down in the boxes till it either stopped or lightened up so a whiteman could walk, damnit, without flooding his gun and the dogs could quit shivering."
2844,The chain was threaded through forty-six loops of the best hand-forged iron in Georgia.
2845,In the boxes the men heard the water rise in the trench and looked out for cottonmouths.
2846,"They squatted in muddy water, slept above it, peed in it."
2847,Paul D thought he was screaming; his mouth was open and there was this loud throat-splitting sound--but it may have been somebody else.
2848,Then he thought he was crying.
2849,Something was running down his cheeks.
2850,He lifted his hands to wipe away the tears and saw dark brown slime.
2851,Above him rivulets of mud slid through the boards of the roof.
2852,"When it come down, he thought, gonna crush me like a tick bug."
2853,It happened so quick he had no time to ponder.
2854,Somebody yanked the chain--once--hard enough to cross his legs and throw him into the mud.
2855,"He never figured out how he knew-- how anybody did--but he did know--he did--and he took both hands and yanked the length of chain at his left, so the next man would know too."
2856,"The water was above his ankles, flowing over the wooden plank he slept on."
2857,And then it wasn't water anymore.
2858,The ditch was caving in and mud oozed under and through the bars.
2859,They waited--each and every one of the forty-six.
2860,"Not screaming, although some of them must have fought like the devil not to."
2861,The mud was up to his thighs and he held on to the bars.
2862,Then it came-- another yank--from the left this time and less forceful than the first because of the mud it passed through.
2863,It started like the chain-up but the difference was the power of the chain.
2864,"One by one, from Hi Man back on down the line, they dove."
2865,"Down through the mud under the bars, blind, groping."
2866,"Some had sense enough to wrap their heads in their shirts, cover their faces with rags, put on their shoes."
2867,"Others just plunged, simply ducked down and pushed out, fighting up, reaching for air."
2868,"Some lost direction and their neighbors, feeling the confused pull of the chain, snatched them around."
2869,"For one lost, all lost."
2870,"The chain that held them would save all or none, and Hi Man was the Delivery."
2871,"They talked through that chain like Sam Morse and, Great God, they all came up."
2872,"Like the unshriven dead, zombies on the loose, holding the chains in their hands, they trusted the rain and the dark, yes, but mostly Hi Man and each other."
2873,"Past the sheds where the dogs lay in deep depression; past the two guard shacks, past the stable of sleeping horses, past the hens whose bills were bolted into their feathers, they waded."
2874,The moon did not help because it wasn't there.
2875,"The field was a marsh, the track a trough."
2876,"All Georgia seemed to be sliding, melting away."
2877,Moss wiped their faces as they fought the live-oak branches that blocked their way.
2878,"Georgia took up all of Alabama and Mississippi then, so there was no state line to cross and it wouldn't have mattered anyway."

2879,"If they had known about it, they would have avoided not only Alfred and the beautiful feldspar, but Savannah too and headed for the Sea Islands on the river that slid down from the Blue Ridge Mountains."
2880,But they didn't know.
2881,Daylight came and they huddled in a copse of redbud trees.
2882,"Night came and they scrambled up to higher ground, praying the rain would go on shielding them and keeping folks at home."
2883,"They were hoping for a shack, solitary, some distance from its big house, where a slave might be making rope or heating potatoes at the grate."
2884,What they found was a camp of sick Cherokee for whom a rose was named.
2885,"Decimated but stubborn, they were among those who chose a fugitive life rather than Oklahoma."
2886,The illness that swept them now was reminiscent of the one that had killed half their number two hundred years earlier.

2887,"In between that calamity and this, they had visited George III in London, published a newspaper, made baskets, led Oglethorpe through forests, helped Andrew Jackson fight Creek, cooked maize, drawn up a constitution,"
2888,"petitioned the King of Spain, been experimented on by Dartmouth, established asylums, wrote their language, resisted settlers, shot bear and translated scripture."
2889,All to no avail.
2890,"The forced move to the Arkansas River, insisted upon by the same president they fought for against the Creek, destroyed another quarter of their already shattered number."
2891,"That was it, they thought, and removed themselves from those Cherokee who signed the treaty, in order to retire into the forest and await the end of the world."
2892,The disease they suffered now was a mere inconvenience compared to the devastation they remembered.
2893,"Still, they protected each other as best they could."
2894,The healthy were sent some miles away; the sick stayed behind with the dead--to survive or join them.
2895,"The prisoners from Alfred, Georgia, sat down in semicircle near the encampment."
2896,No one came and still they sat.
2897,Hours passed and the rain turned soft.
2898,Finally a woman stuck her head out of her house.
2899,Night came and nothing happened.
2900,At dawn two men with barnacles covering their beautiful skin approached them.
2901,"No one spoke for a moment, then Hi Man raised his hand."
2902,The Cherokee saw the chains and went away.
2903,When they returned each carried a handful of small axes.
2904,Two children followed with a pot of mush cooling and thinning in the rain.
2905,"Buffalo men, they called them, and talked slowly to the prisoners scooping mush and tapping away at their chains."
2906,"Nobody from a box in Alfred, Georgia, cared about the illness the Cherokee warned them about, so they stayed, all forty-six, resting, planning their next move."
2907,"Paul D had no idea of what to do and knew less than anybody, it seemed."
2908,"He heard his co-convicts talk knowledgeably of rivers and states, towns and territories."
2909,Heard Cherokee men describe the beginning of the world and its end.

2910,Listened to tales of other Buffalo men they knew--three of whom were in the healthy camp a few miles away. Hi Man wanted to join them; others wanted to join him. Some wanted to leave; some to stay on. Weeks later Paul D was the only Buffalo man left--without a plan.
2911,"All he could think of was tracking dogs, although Hi Man said the rain they left in gave that no chance of success."
2912,"Alone, the last man with buffalo hair among the ailing Cherokee, Paul D finally woke up and, admitting his ignorance, asked how he might get North."
2913,Free North.
2914,Magical North.
2915,"Welcoming, benevolent North."
2916,The Cherokee smiled and looked around.
2917,The flood rains of a month ago had turned everything to steam and blossoms.
2918,"""That way,"" he said, pointing."
2919,"""Follow the tree flowers,"" he said."
2920,"""Only the tree flowers. As they go, you go. You will be where you want to be when they are gone."""
2921,So he raced from dogwood to blossoming peach.
2922,"When they thinned out he headed for the cherry blossoms, then magnolia, chinaberry, pecan, walnut and prickly pear."
2923,At last he reached a field of apple trees whose flowers were just becoming tiny knots of fruit.
2924,"Spring sauntered north, but he had to run like hell to keep it as his traveling companion."
2925,From February to July he was on the lookout for blossoms.

2926,"When he lost them, and found himself without so much as a petal to guide him, he paused, climbed a tree on a hillock and scanned the horizon for a flash of pink or white in the leaf world that surrounded him."
2927,He did not touch them or stop to smell.
2928,"He merely followed in their wake, a dark ragged figure guided by the blossoming plums."
2929,The apple field turned out to be Delaware where the weaver lady lived.
2930,She snapped him up as soon as he finished the sausage she fed him and he crawled into her bed crying.
2931,She passed him off as her nephew from Syracuse simply by calling him that nephew's name.
2932,Eighteen months and he was looking out again for blossoms only this time he did the looking on a dray.

2933,"It was some time before he could put Alfred, Georgia, Sixo, schoolteacher, Halle, his brothers, Sethe, Mister, the taste of iron, the sight of butter, the smell of hickory, notebook paper, one by one, into the tobacco tin lodged in his chest."
2934,By the time he got to nothing in this world could pry it open.
2935,SHE MOVED HIM.
2936,Not the way he had beat off the baby's ghost--all bang and shriek with windows smashed and icily iars rolled in a heap.
2937,"But she moved him nonetheless, and Paul D didn't know how to stop it because it looked like he was moving himself."
2938,"Imperceptibly, downright reasonably, he was moving out of ."
2939,The beginning was so simple.
2940,"One day, after supper, he sat in the rocker by the stove, bone-tired, river-whipped, and fell asleep."
2941,He woke to the footsteps of Sethe coming down the white stairs to make breakfast.
2942,"""I thought you went out somewhere,"" she said."
2943,"Paul D moaned, surprised to find himself exactly where he was the last time he looked."
2944,"""Don't tell me I slept in this chair the whole night."""
2945,Sethe laughed.
2946,"""Me? I won't say a word to you."""
2947,"""Why didn't you rouse me?"""
2948,"""I did. Called you two or three times. I gave it up around midnight and then I thought you went out somewhere."""
2949,"He stood, expecting his back to fight it."
2950,But it didn't.
2951,Not a creak or a stiff joint anywhere.
2952,In fact he felt refreshed.
2953,"Some things are like that, he thought, good-sleep places."

2954,"The base of certain trees here and there; a wharf, a bench, a rowboat once, a haystack usually, not always bed, and here, now, a rocking chair, which was strange because in his experience furniture was the worst place for a good-sleep sleep."
2955,The next evening he did it again and then again.

2956,"He was accustomed to sex with Sethe just about every day, and to avoid the confusion Beloved's shining caused him he still made it his business to take her back upstairs in the morning, or lie down with her after supper."
2957,But he found a way and a reason
2958,to spend the longest part of the night in the rocker.
2959,He told himself it must be his back-- something supportive it needed for a weakness left over from sleeping in a box in Georgia.
2960,"It went on that way and might have stayed that way but one evening, after supper, after Sethe, he came downstairs, sat in the rocker and didn't want to be there."
2961,He stood up and realized he didn't want to go upstairs either.
2962,"Irritable and longing for rest, he opened the door to Baby Suggs' room and dropped off to sleep on the bed the old lady died in."
2963,That settled it--so it seemed. It became his room and Sethe didn't object--her bed made for two had been occupied by one for eighteen years before Paul D came to call.
2964,"And maybe it was better this way, with young girls in the house and him not being her true-to-life husband."
2965,"In any case, since there was no reduction in his before-breakfast or after-supper appetites, he never heard her complain."
2966,"It went on that way and might have stayed that way, except one evening, after supper, after Sethe, he came downstairs and lay on Baby Suggs' bed and didn't want to be there."
2967,"He believed he was having house-fits, the glassy anger men sometimes feel when a woman's house begins to bind them, when they want to yell and break something or at least run off."
2968,"He knew all about that--felt it lots of times--in the Delaware weaver's house, for instance."
2969,But always he associated the house-fit with the woman in it.

2970,"This nervousness had nothing to do with the woman, whom he loved a little bit more every day: her hands among vegetables, her mouth when she licked a thread end before guiding it through a needle or bit it in two when the seam was done, the blood in her eye when she defended her girls (and Beloved was hers now) or any coloredwoman from a slur."
2971,"Also in this house-fit there was no anger, no suffocation, no yearning to be elsewhere."
2972,"He just could not, would not, sleep upstairs or in the rocker or, now, in Baby Suggs' bed."
2973,So he went to the storeroom.
2974,"It went on that way and might have stayed that way except one evening, after supper, after Sethe, he lay on a pallet in the storeroom and didn't want to be there."

2975,"Then it was the cold house and it was out there, separated from the main part of , curled on top of two croaker sacks full of sweet potatoes, staring at the sides of a lard can, that he realized the moving was involuntary."
2976,He wasn't being nervous; he was being prevented.
2977,So he waited.
2978,Visited Sethe in the morning; slept in the cold room at night and waited.
2979,"She came, and he wanted to knock her down."
2980,In Ohio seasons are theatrical.
2981,"Each one enters like a prima donna, convinced its performance is the reason the world has people in it."
2982,"When Paul D had been forced out of into a shed behind it, summer had been hooted offstage and autumn with its bottles of blood and gold had everybody's attention."
2983,"Even at night, when there should have been a restful intermission, there was none because the voices of a dying landscape were insistent and loud."
2984,"Paul D packed newspaper under himself and over, to give his thin blanket some help."
2985,But the chilly night was not on his mind.
2986,When he heard the door open behind him he refused to turn and look.
2987,"""What you want in here? What you want?"""
2988,He should have been able to hear her breathing.
2989,"""I want you to touch me on the inside part and call me my name."""
2990,Paul D never worried about his little tobacco tin anymore.
2991,It was rusted shut.
2992,"So, while she hoisted her skirts and turned her head over her shoulder the way the turtles had, he just looked at the lard can, silvery in moonlight, and spoke quietly."
2993,"""When good people take you in and treat you good, you ought to try to be good back. You don't... Sethe loves you. Much as her own daughter. You know that."""
2994,Beloved dropped her skirts as he spoke and looked at him with empty eyes.
2995,She took a step he could not hear and stood close behind him.
2996,"""She don't love me like I love her. I don't love nobody but her."""
2997,"""Then what you come in here for?"""
2998,"""I want you to touch me on the inside part."""
2999,"""Go on back in that house and get to bed."""
3000,"""You have to touch me. On the inside part. And you have to call me my name."""
3001,As long as his eyes were locked on the silver of the lard can he was safe.

3002,"If he trembled like Lot's wife and felt some womanish need to see the nature of the sin behind him; feel a sympathy, perhaps, for the cursing cursed, or want to hold it in his arms out of respect for the connection between them, he too would be lost."
3003,"""Call me my name."""
3004,"""Please call it. I'll go if you call it."""
3006,"He said it, but she did not go."
3007,She moved closer with a footfall he didn't hear and he didn't hear the whisper that the flakes of rust made either as they fell away from the seams of his tobacco tin.
3008,So when the lid gave he didn't know it.
3009,"What he knew was that when he reached the inside part he was saying, ""Red heart. Red heart,"" over and over again."
3010,"Softly and then so loud it woke Denver, then Paul D himself."
3011,"""Red heart. Red heart. Red heart."""
3012,TO GO BACK to the original hunger was impossible.
3013,"Luckily for Denver, looking was food enough to last."
3014,But to be looked at in turn was beyond appetite; it was breaking through her own skin to a place where hunger hadn't been discovered.

3015,"It didn't have to happen often, because Beloved seldom looked right at her, or when she did, Denver could tell that her own face was just the place those eyes stopped while the mind behind it walked on."
3016,But sometimes--at moments Denver could neither anticipate nor create--Beloved rested cheek on knuckles and looked at Denver with attention.
3017,It was lovely.
3018,"Not to be stared at, not seen, but being pulled into view by the interested, uncritical eyes of the other."
3019,"Having her hair examined as a part of her self, not as material or a style."
3020,"Having her lips, nose, chin caressed as they might be if she were a moss rose a gardener paused to admire."
3021,Denver's skin dissolved under that gaze and became soft and bright like the lisle dress that had its arm around her mother's waist.
3022,"She floated near but outside her own body, feeling vague and intense at the same time."
3023,Needing nothing.
3024,Being what there was.
3025,At such times it seemed to be Beloved who needed somethingm wanted something.

3026,"Deep down in her wide black eyes, back behind the expressionlessness, was a palm held out for a penny which Denver would gladly give her, if only she knew how or knew enough about her, a knowledge not to be had by the answers to the questions Sethe occasionally put to her: '""You disremember everything? I never knew my mother neither, but I saw her a couple of times. Did you never see yours? What kind of whites was they? You don't remember none?"""
3027,"Beloved, scratching the back of her hand, would say she remembered a woman who was hers, and she remembered being snatched away from her."
3028,"Other than that, the clearest memory she had, the one she repeated, was the bridge--standing on the bridge looking down."
3029,And she knew one whiteman.
3030,"Sethe found that remarkable and more evidence to support her conclusions, which she confided to Denver."
3031,"""Where'd you get the dress, them shoes?"""
3032,Beloved said she took them.
3034,Silence and a faster scratching of her hand.
3035,She didn't know; she saw them and just took them.
3036,"""Uh huh,"" said Sethe, and told Denver that she believed Beloved had been locked up by some whiteman for his own purposes, and never let out the door."
3037,That she must have escaped to a bridge or someplace and rinsed the rest
3038,out of her mind.
3039,Something like that had happened to Ella except it was two men---a father and son--- and Ella remembered every bit of it.
3040,"For more than a year, they kept her locked in a room for themselves."
3041,"""You couldn't think up,"" Ella had said, ""what them two done to me."""
3042,"Sethe thought it explained Beloved's behavior around Paul D, whom she hated so."
3043,"Denver neither believed nor commented on Sethe's speculations, and she lowered her eyes and never said a word about the cold house."
3044,"She was certain that Beloved was the white dress that had knelt with her mother in the keeping room, the true-to-life presence of the baby that had kept her company most of her life."
3045,"And to be looked at by her, however briefly, kept her grateful for the rest of the time when she was merely the looker."
3046,"Besides, she had her own set of questions which had nothing to do with the past."

3047,"The present alone interested Denver, but she was careful to appear uninquisitive about the things she was dying to ask Beloved, for if she pressed too hard, she might lose the penny that the held-out palm wanted, and lose, therefore, the place beyond appetite."

3048,"It was better to feast, to have permission to be the looker, because the old hunger--the before-Beloved hunger that drove her into boxwood and cologne for just a taste of a life, to feel it bumpy and not flat--was out of the question."
3049,Looking kept it at bay.
3050,"So she did not ask Beloved how she knew about the earrings, the night walks to the cold house or the tip of the thing she saw when Beloved lay down or came undone in her sleep."
3051,"The look, when it came, came when Denver had been careful, had explained things, or participated in things, or told stories to keep her occupied when Sethe was at the restaurant."
3052,No given chore was enough to put out the licking fire that seemed always to burn in her.
3053,Not when they wrung out sheets so tight the rinse water ran back up their arms.
3054,Not when they shoveled snow from the path to the outhouse.
3055,"Or broke three inches of ice from the rain barrel; scoured and boiled last summer's canning jars, packed mud in the cracks of the hen house and warmed the chicks with their skirts."
3056,All the while Denver was obliged to talk about what they were doing--the how and why of it.
3057,"About people Denver knew once or had seen, giving them more life than life had: the sweet-smelling whitewoman who"
3058,brought her oranges and cologne and good wool skirts; Lady Jones who taught them songs to spell and count by; a beautiful boy as smart as she was with a birthmark like a nickel on his cheek.
3059,A white preacher who prayed for their souls while Sethe peeled potatoes and Grandma Baby sucked air.

3060,And she told her about Howard and Buglar: the parts of the bed that belonged to each (the top reserved for herself); that before she transferred to Baby Suggs' bed she never knew them to sleep without holding hands.

3061,"She described them to Beloved slowly, to keep her attention, dwelling on their habits, the games they taught her and not the fright that drove them increasingly out of the house---anywhere--and finally far away."
3062,This day they are outside.
3063,It's cold and the snow is hard as packed dirt.
3064,Denver has finished singing the counting song Lady Jones taught her students.
3065,Beloved is holding her arms steady while Denver unclasps frozen underwear and towels from the line.
3066,"One by one she lays them in Beloved's arms until the pile, like a huge deck of cards, reaches her chin."
3067,"The rest, aprons and brown stockings, Denver carries herself."
3068,"Made giddy by the cold, they return to the house."
3069,"The clothes will thaw slowly to a dampness perfect for the pressing iron, which will make them smell like hot rain."
3070,"Dancing around the room with Sethe's apron, Beloved wants to know if there are flowers in the dark."
3071,Denver adds sticks to the stovefire and assures her there are.
3072,"Twirling, her face framed by the neckband, her waist in the apron strings' embrace, she says she is thirsty."
3073,"Denver suggests warming up some cider, while her mind races to something she might do or say to interest and entertain the dancer."

3074,"Denver is a strategist now and has to keep Beloved by her side from the minute Sethe leaves for work until the hour of her return when Beloved begins to hover at the window, then work her way out the door, down the steps and near the road."
3075,Plotting has changed Denver markedly.
3076,"Where she was once indolent, resentful of every task, now she is spry, executing, even extending the assignments Sethe leaves for them."
3077,"All to be able to say ""We got to"" and ""Ma'am said for us to."""
3078,"Otherwise Beloved gets private and dreamy, or quiet and sullen, and Denver's chances of being looked at by her go down to nothing."
3079,She has no control over the evenings.
3080,"When her mother is anywhere around, Beloved has eyes only for Sethe."
3081,"At night, in bed,"
3082,anything might happen.
3083,She might want to be told a story in the dark when Denver can't see her.
3084,Or she might get up and go into the cold house where Paul D has begun to sleep.
3085,"Or she might cry, silently."
3086,"She might even sleep like a brick, her breath sugary from fingerfuls of molasses or sand-cookie crumbs."
3087,"Denver will turn toward her then, and if Beloved faces her, she will inhale deeply the sweet air from her mouth."
3088,"If not, she will have to lean up and over her, every once in a while, to catch a sniff."

3089,"For anything is better than the original hunger--the time when, after a year of the wonderful little i, sentences rolling out like pie dough and the company of other children, there was no sound coming through."
3090,Anything is better than the silence when she answered to hands gesturing and was indifferent to the movement of lips.
3091,When she saw every little thing and colors leaped smoldering into view.
3092,"She will forgo the most violent of sunsets, stars as fat as dinner plates and all the blood of autumn and settle for the palest yellow if it comes from her Beloved."
3093,"The cider jug is heavy, but it always is, even when empty."
3094,"Denver can carry it easily, yet she asks Beloved to help her."
3095,It is in the cold house next to the molasses and six pounds of cheddar hard as bone.
3096,A pallet is in the middle of the floor covered with newspaper and a blanket at the foot.
3097,"It has been slept on for almost a month, even though snow has come and, with it, serious winter."
3098,"It is noon, quite light outside; inside it is not."
3099,A few cuts of sun break through the roof and walls but once there they are too weak to shift for themselves.
3100,Darkness is stronger and swallows them like minnows.
3101,The door bangs shut.
3102,Denver can't tell where Beloved is standing.
3103,"""Where are you?"" she whispers in a laughing sort of way."
3104,"""Here,"" says Beloved."
3106,"""Come find me,"" says Beloved."
3107,Denver stretches out her right arm and takes a step or two.
3108,She trips and falls
3109,down onto the pallet.
3110,Newspaper crackles under her weight.
3111,She laughs again.
3112,"""Oh, shoot. Beloved?"""
3113,No one answers.
3114,"Denver waves her arms and squinches her eyes to separate the shadows of potato sacks, a lard can and a side of smoked pork from the one that might be human."
3115,"""Stop fooling,"" she says and looks up toward the light to check and make sure this is still the cold house and not something going on in her sleep."
3116,The minnows of light still swim there; they can't make it down to where she is.
3117,"""You the one thirsty. You want cider or don't you?"""
3118,Denver's voice is mildly accusatory.
3119,Mildly.
3120,She doesn't want to offend and she doesn't want to betray the panic that is creeping over her like hairs.
3121,There is no sight or sound of Beloved.
3122,Denver struggles to her feet amid the crackling newspaper.
3123,"Holding her palm out, she moves slowly toward the door."
3124,There is no latch or knob-- just a loop of wire to catch a nail.
3125,She pushes the door open.
3126,Cold sunlight displaces the dark.
3127,The room is just as it was when they entered-except Beloved is not there.
3128,"There is no point in looking further, for everything in the place can be seen at first sight."
3129,Denver looks anyway because the loss is ungovernable.
3130,"She steps back into the shed, allowing the door to close quickly behind her."
3131,"Darkness or not, she moves rapidly around, reaching, touching cobwebs, cheese, slanting shelves, the pallet interfering with each step."
3132,"If she stumbles, she is not aware of it because she does not know where her body stops, which part of her is an arm, a foot or a knee."
3133,"She feels like an ice cake torn away from the solid surface of the stream, floating on darkness, thick and crashing against the edges of things around it."
3134,"Breakable, meltable and cold."
3135,It is hard to breathe and even if there were light she wouldn't be able to see anything because she is crying.
3136,"Just as she thought it might happen, it has."
3137,Easy as walking into a room.
3138,"A magical appearance on a stump, the face wiped out by sunlight, and a magical disappearance in a shed, eaten alive by the dark."
3139,"""Don't,"" she is saying between tough swallows."
3140,"""Don't. Don't go back."""
3141,This is worse than when Paul D came to and she cried helplessly into the stove.
3142,This is worse.
3143,Then it was for herself.
3144,Now she is crying because she has no self.
3145,Death is a skipped meal compared to this.
3146,"She can feel her thickness thinning, dissolving into nothing."
3147,She grabs the hair at her temples to get enough to uproot it and halt the melting for a while.
3148,"Teeth clamped shut, Denver brakes her sobs."
3149,She doesn't move to open the door because there is no world out there.
3150,She decides to stay in the cold house and let the dark swallow her like the minnows of light above.
3151,"She won't put up with another leaving, another trick."
3152,"Waking up to find one brother then another not at the bottom of the bed, his foot jabbing her spine."
3153,"Sitting at the table eating turnips and saving the liquor for her grandmother to drink; her mother's hand on the keeping-room door and her voice saying, ""Baby Suggs is gone, Denver."""
3154,"And when she got around to worrying about what would be the case if Sethe died or Paul D took her away, a dream-come- true comes true just to leave her on a pile of newspaper in the dark."
3155,"No footfall announces her, but there she is, standing where before there was nobody when Denver looked."
3156,And smiling.
3157,Denver grabs the hem of Beloved's skirt.
3158,"""I thought you left me."
3159,I thought you went back.
3160,"Beloved smiles, ""I don't want that place. This the place I am."""
3161,"She sits down on the pallet and, laughing, lies back looking at the cracklights above."
3162,"Surreptitiously, Denver pinches a piece of Beloved's skirt between her fingers and holds on."
3163,A good thing she does because suddenly Beloved sits up.
3164,"""What is it?"" asks Denver."
3165,"""Look,"" she points to the sunlit cracks."
3166,"""What? I don't see nothing."""
3167,Denver follows the pointing finger.
3168,Beloved drops her hand.
3169,"""I'm like this."""
3170,"Denver watches as Beloved bends over, curls up and rocks."
3171,Her eyes go to no place; her moaning is so small Denver can hardly hear it.
3172,"""You all right? Beloved?"""
3173,Beloved focuses her eyes.
3174,"""Over there. Her face."""
3175,Denver looks where Beloved's eyes go; there is nothing but darkness there.
3176,"""Whose face? Who is it?"""
3178,She is smiling again.
3179,"THE LAST of the Sweet Home men, so named and called by one who would know, believed it."
3180,"The other four believed it too, once, but they were long gone."
3181,"The sold one never returned, the lost one never found."
3182,"One, he knew, was dead for sure; one he hoped was, because butter and clabber was no life or reason to live it."
3183,"He grew up thinking that, of all the Blacks in Kentucky, only the five of them were men."
3184,"Allowed, encouraged to correct Garner, even defy him."
3185,To invent ways of doing things; to see what was needed and attack it without permission.
3186,"To buy a mother, choose a horse or a wife, handle guns, even learn reading if they wanted to--but they didn't want to since nothing important to them could be put down on paper."
3187,Was that it?
3188,Is that where the manhood lay?
3189,In the naming done by a whiteman who was supposed to know?
3190,Who gave them the privilege not of working but of deciding how to?
3191,"In their relationship with Garner was true metal: they were believed and trusted, but most of all they were listened"
3192,"He thought what they said had merit, and what they felt was serious."
3193,Deferring to his slaves' opinions did not deprive him of authority or power.
3194,It was schoolteacher who taught them otherwise.
3195,A truth that waved like a scarecrow in rye: they were only Sweet Home men at Sweet Home.
3196,One step off that ground and they were trespassers among the human race.
3197,Watchdogs without teeth; steer bulls without horns; gelded workhorses whose neigh and whinny could not be translated into a language responsible humans spoke.
3198,His strength had lain in knowing that schoolteacher was wrong.
3199,Now he wondered.
3200,"There was Alfred, Georgia, there was Delaware, there was Sixo and still he wondered."

3201,"If schoolteacher was right it explained how he had come to be a rag doll--picked up and put back down anywhere any time by a girl young enough to be his daughter. Fucking her when he was convinced he didn't want to. Whenever she turned her behind up, the calves of his youth (was that it?) cracked his resolve. But it was more than appetite that humiliated him and made him wonder if schoolteacher was right. It was being moved, placed where she wanted him, and there was nothing he was able to do about it. For his life he could not walk up the glistening white stairs in the evening; for his life he could not stay in the kitchen, in the keeping room, in the storeroom at night. And he tried. Held his breath the way he had when he ducked into the mud; steeled his heart the way he had when the trembling began. But it was worse than that, worse than the blood eddy he had controlled with a sledge hammer. When he stood up from the supper table at and turned toward the stairs, nausea was first, then repulsion. He, he. He who had eaten raw meat barely dead, who under plum trees bursting with blossoms had crunched through a dove's breast before its heart stopped beating. Because he was a man and a man could do what he would: be still for six hours in a dry well while night dropped; fight raccoon with his hands and win; watch another man, whom he loved better than his brothers, roast without a tear just so the roasters would know what a man was like. And it was he, that man, who had walked from Georgia to Delaware, who could not go or stay put where he wanted to in --shame."
3202,"Paul D could not command his feet, but he thought he could still talk and he"
3203,made up his mind to break out that way.
3204,He would tell Sethe about the last three weeks: catch her alone coming from work at the beer garden she called a restaurant and tell it all.
3205,He waited for her.
3206,The winter afternoon looked like dusk as he stood in the alley behind Sawyer's Restaurant.
3207,"Rehearsing, imagining her face and letting the words flock in his head like kids before lining up to follow the leader."

3208,"""Well, ah, this is not the, a man can't, see, but aw listen here, it ain't that, it really ain't, Ole Garner, what I mean is, it ain't a weak- ness, the kind of weakness I can fight 'cause 'cause something is happening to me, that girl is doing it, I know you think I never liked her nohow, but she is doing it to me. Fixing me. Sethe, she's fixed me and I can't break it."""
3209,What?
3210,A grown man fixed by a girl?
3211,"But what if the girl was not a girl, but something in disguise?"

3212,"A lowdown something that looked like a sweet young girl and fucking her or not was not the point, it was not being able to stay or go where he wished in , and the danger was in losing Sethe because he was not man enough to break out, so he needed her, Sethe, to help him, to know about it, and it shamed him to have to ask the woman he wanted to protect to help him do it, God damn it to hell."
3213,Paul D blew warm breath into the hollow of his cupped hands.
3214,The wind raced down the alley so fast it sleeked the fur of four kitchen dogs waiting for scraps.
3215,He looked at the dogs.
3216,The dogs looked at him.
3217,Finally the back door opened and Sethe stepped through holding a scrap pan in the crook of her arm.
3218,"When she saw him, she said Oh, and her smile was both pleasure and surprise."
3219,Paul D believed he smiled back but his face was so cold he wasn't sure.
3220,"""Man, you make me feel like a girl, coming by to pick me up after work. Nobody ever did that before. You better watch out, I might start looking forward to it."""
3221,She tossed the largest bones into the dirt rapidly so the dogs would know there was enough and not fight each other.
3222,"Then she dumped the skins of some things, heads of other things and the insides of still more"
3223,things--what the restaurant could not use and she would not--in a smoking pile near the animals' feet.
3224,"""Got to rinse this out,"" she said, ""and then I'll be right with you."""
3225,He nodded as she returned to the kitchen.

3226,"The dogs ate without sound and Paul D thought they at least got what they came for, and if she had enough for them-- The cloth on her head was brown wool and she edged it down over her hairline against the wind."
3227,"""You get off early or what?"""
3228,"""I took off early."""
3229,"""Anything the matter?"""
3230,"""In a way of speaking,"" he said and wiped his lips."
3231,"""Not cut back?"""
3232,"""No, no. They got plenty work. I just--"""
3233,"""Sethe, you won't like what I'm 'bout to say."""
3234,She stopped then and turned her face toward him and the hateful wind.
3235,Another woman would have squinted or at least teared if the wind whipped her face as it did Sethe's.
3236,"Another woman might have shot him a look of apprehension, pleading, anger even, because what he said sure sounded like part one of Goodbye, I'm gone."
3237,"Sethe looked at him steadily, calmly, already ready to accept, release or excuse an in-need-or-trouble man."
3238,"Agreeing, saying okay, all right, in advance, because she didn't believe any of them--over the long haul--could measure up."
3239,"And whatever the reason, it was all right."
3240,No fault.
3241,Nobody's fault.
3242,"He knew what she was thinking and even though she was wrong-- he was not leaving her, wouldn't ever--the thing he had in mind to tell her was going to be worse."
3243,"So, when he saw the diminished expectation in her eyes, the melancholy without blame, he could not say it."
3244,"He could not say to this woman who did not squint in the wind, ""I am not a man."""
3245,"""Well, say it, Paul D, whether I like it or not."""
3246,"Since he could not say what he planned to, he said something he didn't know was on his mind."
3247,"""I want you pregnant, Sethe. Would you do that for me?"""
3248,Now she was laughing and so was he.
3249,"""You came by here to ask me that? You are one crazy-headed man. You right; I don't like it. Don't you think I'm too old to start that all over again?"""
3250,She slipped her fingers in his hand for all the world like the hand-holding shadows on the side of the road.
3251,"""Think about it,"" he said."
3252,"And suddenly it was a solution: a way to hold on to her, document his manhood and break out of the girl's spell--all in one."
3253,He put the tips of Sethe's fingers on his cheek.
3254,"Laughing, she pulled them away lest somebody passing the alley see them misbehaving in public, in daylight, in the wind."
3255,"Still, he'd gotten a little more time, bought it, in fact, and hoped the price wouldn't wreck him."
3256,Like paying for an afternoon in the coin of life to come.
3257,"They left off playing, let go hands and hunched forward as they left the alley and entered the street."
3258,"The wind was quieter there but the dried-out cold it left behind kept pedestrians fast-moving, stiff inside their coats."
3259,No men leaned against door frames or storefront windows.
3260,The wheels of wagons delivering feed or wood screeched as though they hurt.
3261,Hitched horses in front of the saloons shivered and closed their eyes.
3262,"Four women, walking two abreast, approached, their shoes loud on the wooden walkway."
3263,Paul D touched Sethe's elbow to guide her as they stepped from the slats to the dirt to let the women pass.
3264,"Half an hour later, when they reached the city's edge, Sethe and Paul D resumed catching and snatching each other's fingers, stealing quick pats on the behind."
3265,Joyfully embarrassed to be that grownup and that young at the same time.
3266,"Resolve, he thought."
3267,"That was all it took, and no motherless gal was going to break it up."
3268,"No lazy, stray pup of a woman could turn him around, make him doubt himself, wonder, plead or confess."
3269,"Convinced of it, that he could do it, he threw his arm around Sethe's shoulders and squeezed."
3270,"She let her head touch his chest, and since the moment was valuable to both of them, they stopped and stood that way--not breathing, not even caring if a passerby passed them by."
3271,The winter light was low.
3272,Sethe closed her eyes.
3273,"Paul D looked at the black trees lining the roadside, their defending arms raised against attack."
3274,"Softly, suddenly, it began to snow, like a present come down from the sky."
3275,"Sethe opened her eyes to it and said, ""Mercy."""
3276,And it seemed to Paul D that it was--a little mercy--something given to them on purpose to mark what they were feeling so they would remember it later on when they needed to.
3277,"Down came the dry flakes, fat enough and heavy enough to crash like nickels on stone."
3278,"It always surprised him, how quiet it was."
3279,"Not like rain, but like a secret."
3280,"""Run!"" he said."
3281,"""You run,"" said Sethe."
3282,"""I been on my feet all day."""
3283,"""Where I been? Sitting down?"" and he pulled her along."
3284,"""Stop! Stop!"" she said."
3285,"""I don't have the legs for this."""
3286,"""Then give em to me,"" he said and before she knew it he had backed into her, hoisted her on his back and was running down the road past brown fields turning white."
3287,"Breathless at last, he stopped and she slid back down on her own two feet, weak from laughter."
3288,"""You need some babies, somebody to play with in the snow."""
3289,Sethe secured her headcloth.
3290,Paul D smiled and warmed his hands with his breath.
3291,"""I sure would like to give it a try. Need a willing partner though."""
3292,"""I'll say,"" she answered."
3293,"""Very, very willing."""
3294,It was nearly four o'clock now and was half a mile ahead.

3295,"Floating toward them, barely visible in the drifting snow, was a figure, and although it was the same figure that had been meeting Sethe for four months, so complete was the attention she and Paul D were paying to themselves they both felt a jolt when they saw her close in."
3296,Beloved did not look at Paul D; her scrutiny was for Sethe.
3297,"She had no coat, no wrap, nothing on her head, but she held in her hand a long shawl."
3298,Stretching out her arms she tried to circle it around Sethe.
3299,"""Crazy girl,"" said Sethe."
3300,"""You the one out here with nothing on."""
3301,"And stepping away and in front of Paul D, Sethe took the shawl and wrapped it around Beloved's head and shoulders."
3302,"Saying, ""You got to learn more sense than that,"" she enclosed her in her left arm."
3303,Snowflakes stuck now.
3304,Paul D felt icy cold in the place Sethe had been before Beloved came.
3305,"Trailing a yard or so behind the women, he fought the anger that shot through his stomach all the way home."
3306,"When he saw Denver silhouetted in the lamplight at the window, he could not help thinking, ""And whose ally you?"""
3307,It was Sethe who did it.
3308,"Unsuspecting, surely, she solved everything with one blow."
3309,"""Now I know you not sleeping out there tonight, are you, Paul D?"""
3311,"smiled at him, and like a friend in need, the chimney coughed against the rush of cold shooting into it from the sky."
3312,Window sashes shuddered in a blast of winter air.
3313,Paul D looked up from the stew meat.
3314,"""You come upstairs. Where you belong,"" she said, ""... and stay there."""
3315,The threads of malice creeping toward him from Beloved's side of the table were held harmless in the warmth of Sethe's smile.
3316,Once before (and only once) Paul D had been grateful to a woman.
3317,"Crawling out of the woods, cross-eyed with hunger and loneliness, he knocked at the first back door he came to in the colored section of Wilmington."
3318,"He told the woman who opened it that he'd appreciate doing her woodpile, if she could spare him something to eat."
3319,She looked him up and down.
3320,"""A little later on,"" she said and opened the door wider."
3321,"She fed him pork sausage, the worst thing in the world for a starving man, but neither he nor his stomach objected."
3322,"Later, when he saw pale cotton sheets and two pillows in her bedroom, he had to wipe his eyes quickly, quickly so she would not see the thankful tears of a man's first time."
3323,"Soil, grass, mud, shucking, leaves, hay, cobs, sea shells---all that he'd slept on."
3324,White cotton sheets had never crossed his mind.
3325,He fell in with a groan and the woman helped him pretend he was making love to her and not her bed linen.
3326,"He vowed that night, full of pork, deep in luxury, that he would never leave her."
3327,She would have to kill him to get him out of that bed.
3328,"Eighteen months later, when he had been purchased by Northpoint Bank and Railroad Company, he was still thankful for that introduction to sheets."
3329,Now he was grateful a second time.
3330,He felt as though he had been plucked from the face of a cliff and put down on sure ground.
3331,In Sethe's bed he knew he could put up with two crazy girls---as long as
3332,Sethe made her wishes known.

3333,"Stretched out to his full length, watching snowflakes stream past the window over his feet, it was easy to dismiss the doubts that took him to the alley behind the restaurant: his expectations for himself were high, too high."
3334,What he might call cowardice other people called common sense.
3335,"Tucked into the well of his arm, Sethe recalled Paul D's face in the street when he asked her to have a baby for him."
3336,"Although she laughed and took his hand, it had frightened her."
3337,"She thought quickly of how good the sex would be if that is what he wanted, but mostly she was frightened by the thought of having a baby once more."
3338,"Needing to be good enough, alert enough, strong enough, that caring--again."
3339,Having to stay alive just that much longer.
3340,"O Lord, she thought, deliver me."
3341,"Unless carefree, motherlove was a killer."
3342,What did he want her pregnant for?
3343,To hold on to her?
3344,have a sign that he passed this way?
3345,He probably had children everywhere anyway.
3346,"Eighteen years of roaming, he would have to have dropped a few."
3347,"He resented the children she had, that's what."
3348,"Child, she corrected herself."
3349,"Child plus Beloved whom she thought of as her own, and that is what he resented."
3350,Sharing her with the girls.
3351,Hearing the three of them laughing at something he wasn't in on.
3352,The code they used among themselves that he could not break.
3353,Maybe even the time spent on their needs and not his.
3354,They were a family somehow and he was not the head of it.
3355,"Can you stitch this up for me, baby?"
3356,Um hm.
3357,Soon's I finish this petticoat.
3358,She just got the one she came here in and everybody needs a change.
3359,Any pie left?
3360,I think Denver got the last of it.
3361,"And not complaining, not even minding that he slept all over and around the house now, which she put a stop to this night out of courtesy."
3362,Sethe sighed and placed her hand on his chest.
3363,"She knew she was building a case against him in order to build a case against getting pregnant, and it shamed her a little."
3364,But she had all the children she needed.

3366,Right after she saw the shadows holding hands at the side of the road hadn't the picture altered?
3367,"And the minute she saw the dress and shoes sitting in the front yard, she broke water."
3368,Didn't even have to see the face burning in the sunlight.
3369,She had been dreaming it for years.
3370,"Paul D's chest rose and fell, rose and fell under her hand."
3371,DENVER FINISHED washing the dishes and sat down at the table.
3372,"Beloved, who had not moved since Sethe and Paul D left the room, sat sucking her forefinger."
3373,"Denver watched her face awhile and then said, ""She likes him here."""
3374,Beloved went on probing her mouth with her finger.
3375,"""Make him go away,"" she said."
3376,"""She might be mad at you if he leaves."""
3377,"Beloved, inserting a thumb in her mouth along with the forefinger, pulled out a back tooth."
3378,"There was hardly any blood, but Denver said, ""Ooooh, didn't that hurt you?"""
3379,"Beloved looked at the tooth and thought, This is it."
3380,"Next would be her arm, her hand, a toe."
3381,"Pieces of her would drop maybe one at a time, maybe all at once."
3382,Or on one of those mornings before Denver woke and after Sethe left she would fly apart.
3383,"It is difficult keeping her head on her neck, her legs"
3384,attached to her hips when she is by herself.
3385,Among the things she could not remember was when she first knew that she could wake up any day and find herself in pieces.
3386,"She had two dreams: exploding, and being swallowed."
3387,"When her tooth came out--an odd fragment, last in the row--she thought it was starting."
3388,"""Must be a wisdom,"" said Denver."
3389,"""Don't it hurt?"""
3392,"""Then why don't you cry?"""
3393,"""If it hurts, why don't you cry?"""
3394,And she did.
3395,Sitting there holding a small white tooth in the palm of her smooth smooth hand.
3396,"Cried the way she wanted to when turtles came out of the water, one behind the other, right after the blood-red bird disappeared back into the leaves."
3397,The way she wanted to when Sethe went to him standing in the tub under the stairs.

3399,"The couple upstairs, united, didn't hear a sound, but below them, outside, all around the snow went on and on and on."
3400,"Piling itself, burying itself."
3401,Higher.
3402,Deeper.
3403,"AT THE BACK of Baby Suggs' mind may have been the thought that if Halle made it, God do what He would, it would be a cause for celebration."
3404,If only this final son could do for himself what he had done for her and for the
3405,three children John and Ella delivered to her door one summer night.
3406,"When the children arrived and no Sethe, she was afraid and grateful."
3407,Grateful that the part of the family that survived was her own grandchildren--the first and only she would know: two boys and a little girl who was crawling already.
3408,"But she held her heart still, afraid to form questions: What about Sethe and Halle; why the delay?"
3409,Why didn't Sethe get on board too?
3410,Nobody could make it alone.
3411,"Not only because trappers picked them off like buzzards or netted them like rabbits, but also because you couldn't run if you didn't know how to go."
3412,"You could be lost forever, if there wasn't nobody to show you the way."
3413,"So when Sethe arrived--all mashed up and split open, but with another grandchild in her arms--the idea of a whoop moved closer to the front of her brain."
