5555,IT WAS a tiny church no bigger than a rich man's parlor.
5556,"The pews had no backs, and since the congregation was also the choir, it didn't need a stall."

5557,"Certain members had been assigned the construction of a platform to raise the preacher a few inches above his congregation, but it was a less than urgent task, since the major elevation, a white oak cross, had already taken place."
5558,"Before it was the Church of the Holy Redeemer, it was a dry-goods shop that had no use for side windows, just front ones for display."
5559,These were papered over while members considered whether to paint or curtain them--how to have privacy without losing the little light that might want to shine on them.
5560,In the summer the doors were left open for ventilation.
5561,In winter an iron stove in the aisle did what it could.
5562,"At the front of the church was a sturdy porch where customers used to sit, and children laughed at the boy who got his head stuck between the railings."
5563,"On a sunny and windless day in January it was actually warmer out there than inside, if the iron stove was cold."
5564,"The damp cellar was fairly warm, but there was no light lighting the pallet or the washbasin or the nail from which a man's clothes could be hung."
5565,"And a oil lamp in a cellar was sad, so Paul D sat on the porch steps and got additional warmth from a bottle of liquor jammed in his coat pocket."
5566,Warmth and red eyes.
5567,"He held his wrist between his knees, not to keep his hands still but because he had nothing else to hold on to."
5568,"His tobacco tin, blown open, spilled contents that floated freely and made him their play and prey."
5569,He couldn't figure out why it took so long.
5570,He may as well have jumped in the fire with Sixo and they both could have had a good laugh.
5571,"Surrender was bound to come anyway, why not meet it with a laugh, shouting Seven-O!"
5572,Why not?
5573,Why the delay?
5574,"He had already seen his brother wave goodbye from the back of a dray, fried chicken in his pocket, tears in his eyes."
5575,Mother.
5576,Father.
5577,Didn't remember the one.
5578,Never saw the other.
5579,"He was the youngest of three half-brothers (same mother--different fathers) sold to Garner and kept there, forbidden to leave the farm, for twenty years."
5580,"Once, in Maryland, he met four families of slaves who had all been together for a hundred years: great-grands, grands, mothers, fathers, aunts, uncles, cousins, children."
5581,"Half white, part white, all black, mixed with Indian."
5582,"He watched them with awe and envy, and each time he discovered large families of black people he made them identify over and over who each was, what relation, who, in fact, belonged to who."
5583,"""That there's my auntie. This here's her boy. Yonder is my pap's cousin. My ma'am was married twice--this my half-sister and these her two children. Now, my wife..."""
5584,Nothing like that had ever been his and growing up at Sweet Home he didn't miss it.
5585,"He had his brothers, two friends, Baby Suggs in the kitchen, a boss who showed them how to shoot and listened to what they had to say."
5586,A mistress who made their soap and never raised her voice.
5587,"For twenty years they had all lived in that cradle, until Baby left, Sethe came, and Halle took her."
5588,"He made a family with her, and Sixo was hell-bent to make one with the Thirty-Mile Woman."
5589,"When Paul D waved goodbye to his oldest brother, the boss was dead, the mistress nervous and the cradle already split."
5590,Sixo said the doctor made Mrs. Garner sick.
5591,"Said he was giving her to drink what stallions got when they broke a leg and no gunpowder could be spared, and had it not been for schoolteacher's new rules, he would have told her so."
5592,They laughed at him.
5593,Sixo had a knowing tale about everything.
5594,"Including Mr. Garner's stroke, which he said was a shot in his ear put there by a jealous neighbor."
5595,"""where's the blood?"" they asked him."
5596,There was no blood.
5597,"Mr. Garner came home bent over his mare's neck, sweating and blue-white."
5598,Not a drop of blood.
5599,"Sixo grunted, the only one of them not sorry to see him go."
5600,"Later, however, he was mighty sorry; they all were."
5601,"""Why she call on him?"""
5602,Paul D asked.
5603,"""Why she need the schoolteacher?"""
5604,"""She need somebody can figure,"" said Halle."
5605,"""You can do figures."""
5606,"""Not like that."""
5607,"""No, man,"" said Sixo."
5608,"""She need another white on the place."""
5610,"""What you think? What you think?"""
5611,"Well, that's the way it was."
5612,Nobody counted on Garner dying.
5613,Nobody thought he could.
5614,How 'bout that?
5615,Everything rested on Garner being alive.
5616,Without his life each of theirs fell to pieces.
5617,Now ain't that slavery or what is it?
5618,"At the peak of his strength, taller than tall men, and stronger than most, they clipped him, Paul D."
5619,"First his shotgun, then his thoughts, for schoolteacher didn't take advice from Negroes."
5620,The information they offered he called backtalk and developed a variety of corrections (which he recorded in his notebook) to reeducate them.
5621,"He complained they ate too much, rested too much, talked too much, which was certainly true compared to him, because schoolteacher ate little, spoke less and rested not at all."
5622,Once he saw them playing--a pitching game--and his look of deeply felt hurt was enough to make Paul D blink.
5623,He was as hard on his pupils as he was on them--except for the corrections.
5624,For years Paul D believed schoolteacher broke into children what Garner had raised into men.
5625,And it was that that made them run off.
5626,"Now, plagued by the contents of his tobacco tin, he wondered how much difference there really was between before schoolteacher and after."

5627,"Garner called and announced them men--but only on Sweet Home, and by his leave. Was he naming what he saw or creating what he did not? That was the wonder of Sixo, and even Halle; it was always clear to Paul D that those two were men whether Garner said so or not. It troubled him that, concerning his own manhood, he could not satisfy himself on that point. Oh, he did manly things, but was that Garner's gift or his own will? What would he have been anyway--before"
5628,Sweet Home--without Garner?
5629,"In Sixo's country, or his mother's?"
5630,"Or, God help him, on the boat?"
5631,Did a whiteman saying it make it so?
5632,Suppose Garner woke up one morning and changed his mind?
5633,Took the word away.
5634,Would they have run then?
5635,"And if he didn't, would the Pauls have stayed there all their lives?"
5636,Why did the brothers need the one whole night to decide?
5637,To discuss whether they would join Sixo and Halle.
5638,"Because they had been isolated in a wonderful lie, dismissing Halle's and Baby Suggs' life before Sweet Home as bad luck."
5639,Ignorant of or amused by Sixo's dark stories.
5640,Protected and convinced they were special.

5641,"Never suspecting the problem of Alfred, Georgia; being so in love with the look of the world, putting up with anything and everything, just to stay alive in a place where a moon he had no right to was nevertheless there."
5642,Loving small and in secret.
5643,"His little love was a tree, of course, but not like Brother-- old, wide and beckoning."
5644,"In Alfred, Georgia, there was an aspen too young to call sapling."
5645,Just a shoot no taller than his waist.
5646,The kind of thing a man would cut to whip his horse.
5647,Song-murder and the aspen.
5648,"He stayed alive to sing songs that murdered life, and watched an aspen that confirmed it, and never for a minute did he believe he could escape."
5649,Until it rained.
5650,"Afterward, after the Cherokee pointed and sent him running toward blossoms, he wanted simply to move, go, pick up one day and be somewhere else the next."
5651,"Resigned to life without aunts, cousins, children."
5652,"Even a woman, until Sethe."
5653,And then she moved him.

5654,"Just when doubt, regret and every single unasked question was packed away, long after he believed he had willed himself into being, at the very time and place he wanted to take root--she moved him."
5655,From room to room.
5656,Like a rag doll.
5657,"Sitting on the porch of a dry-goods church, a little bit drunk and nothing much to do, he could have these thoughts."
5658,"Slow, what-if thoughts that cut deep but struck nothing solid a man could hold on to."
5659,So he held his wrists.
5660,"Passing by that woman's life, getting in it and letting it get in him had set him up for this fall."
5661,"Wanting to live out his life with a whole woman was new, and losing the feeling of it made him want to cry and think deep thoughts that struck nothing solid."
5662,"When he was drifting, thinking only about the next meal"
5663,"and night's sleep, when everything was packed tight in his chest, he had no sense of failure, of things not working out."
5664,Anything that worked at all worked out.
5665,"Now he wondered what-all went wrong, and starting with the Plan, everything had."
5666,"It was a good plan, too."
5667,Worked out in detail with every possibility of error eliminated.
5668,"Sixo, hitching up the horses, is speaking English again and tells Halle what his Thirty-Mile Woman told him."
5669,That seven Negroes on her place were joining two others going North.
5670,That the two others had done it before and knew the way.

5671,"That one of the two, a woman, would wait for them in the corn when it was high--one night and half of the next day she would wait, and if they came she would take them to the caravan, where the others would be hidden."
5672,"That she would rattle, and that would be the sign."
5673,"Sixo was going, his woman was going, and Halle was taking his whole family."
5674,The two Pauls say they need time to think about it.
5675,Time to wonder where they will end up; how they will live.
5676,"What work; who will take them in; should they try to get to Paul F, whose owner, they remember, lived in something called the ""trace""?"
5677,It takes them one evening's conversation to decide.
5678,"Now all they have to do is wait through the spring, till the corn is as high as it ever got and the moon as fat."
5679,And plan.
5680,"Is it better to leave in the dark to get a better start, or go at daybreak to be able to see the way better?"
5681,Sixo spits at the suggestion.
5682,Night gives them more time and the protection of color.
5683,He does not ask them if they are afraid.
5684,"He manages some dry runs to the corn at night, burying blankets and two knives near the creek."
5685,Will Sethe be able to swim the creek?
5686,they ask him.
5687,"It will be dry, he says, when the corn is tall."
5688,"There is no food to put by, but Sethe says she will get a jug of cane syrup or molasses, and some bread when it is near the time to go."
5689,"She only wants to be sure the blankets are where they should be, for they will need them to tie her baby on her back and to cover them during the journey."
5690,There are no clothes other than what they wear.
5691,And of course no shoes.
5693,"knives will help them eat, but they bury rope and a pot as well."
5694,A good plan.
5695,They watch and memorize the comings and goings of schoolteacher and his pupils: what is wanted when and where; how long it takes.
5696,"Mrs. Garner, restless at night, is sunk in sleep all morning."
5697,Some days the pupils and their teacher do lessons until breakfast.
5698,"One day a week they skip breakfast completely and travel ten miles to church, expecting a large dinner upon their return."
5699,"Schoolteacher writes in his notebook after supper; the pupils clean, mend or sharpen tools."
5700,"Sethe's work is the most uncertain because she is on call for Mrs. Garner anytime, including nighttime when the pain or the weakness or the downright loneliness is too much for her."
5701,So: Sixo and the Pauls will go after supper and wait in the creek for the Thirty Mile Woman.

5702,"Halle will bring Sethe and the three children before dawn--before the sun, before the chickens and the milking cow need attention, so by the time smoke should be coming from the cooking stove, they will be in or near the creek with the others."
5703,"That way, if Mrs. Garner needs Sethe in the night and calls her, Sethe will be there to answer."
5704,They only have to wait through the spring.
5706,"Sethe was pregnant in the spring and by August is so heavy with child she may not be able to keep up with the men, who can carry the children but not her."
5708,Neighbors discouraged by Garner when he was alive now feel free to visit Sweet Home and might appear in the right place at the wrong time.
5710,"Sethe's children cannot play in the kitchen anymore, so she is dashing back and forth between house and quarters-fidgety and frustrated trying to watch over them."
5711,They are too young for men's work and the baby girl is nine months old.
5712,Without Mrs. Garner's help her work increases as do schoolteacher's demands.
5714,"After the conversation about the shoat, Sixo is tied up with the stock at night, and locks are put on bins, pens, sheds, coops, the tackroom and the barn door."
5715,There is no place to dart into or congregate.
5716,"Sixo keeps a nail in his mouth now, to help him undo the rope when he has to."
5718,Halle is told to work his extra on Sweet Home and has no call to be anywhere other than where schoolteacher tells him.
5719,"Only Sixo, who has been stealing away to see his woman, and Halle, who has been hired away for years, know what lies outside Sweet Home and how to get there."
5720,It is a good plan.
5721,It can be done right under the watchful pupils and their teacher.
5723,They had to alter it--just a little.
5724,First they change the leaving.
5725,They memorize the directions Halle gives them.
5726,"Sixo, needing time to untie himself, break open the door and not disturb the horses, will leave later, joining them at the creek with the Thirty-Mile Woman."
5727,All four will go straight to the corn.
5728,"Halle, who also needs more time now, because of Sethe, decides to bring her and the children at night; not wait till first light."
5729,They will go straight to the corn and not assemble at the creek.
5730,The corn stretches to their shoulders--it will never be higher.
5731,The moon is swelling.
5732,"They can hardly harvest, or chop, or clear, or pick, or haul for listening for a rattle that is not bird or snake."
5733,"Then one midmorning, they hear it."
5734,"Or Halle does and begins to sing it to the others: ""Hush, hush. Somebody's calling my name. Hush, hush. Somebody's calling my name. O my Lord, O my Lord, what shall I do?"""
5735,On his dinner break he leaves the field.
5736,He has to.
5737,He has to tell Sethe that he has heard the sign.
5738,For two successive nights she has been with Mrs. Garner and he can't chance it that she will not know that this night she cannot be.
5739,The Pauls see him go.
5740,"From underneath Brother's shade where they are chewing corn cake, they see him, swinging along."
5741,The bread tastes good.
5742,They lick sweat from their lips to give it a saltier flavor.
5743,Schoolteacher and his pupils are already at the house eating dinner.
5744,Halle swings along.
5745,He is not singing now.
5746,Nobody knows what happened.
5747,"Except for the churn, that was the last anybody ever saw of Halle."
5748,"What Paul D knew was that Halle disappeared,"
5749,"never told Sethe anything, and was next seen squatting in butter."
5750,"Maybe when he got to the gate and asked to see Sethe, schoolteacher heard a tint of anxiety in his voice--the tint that would make him pick up his ever-ready shotgun."
5751,"Maybe Halle made the mistake of saying ""my wife"" in some way that would put a light in schoolteacher's eye."
5752,"Sethe says now that she heard shots, but did not look out the window of Mrs. Garner's bedroom."
5753,"But Halle was not killed or wounded that day because Paul D saw him later, after she had run off with no one's help; after Sixo laughed and his brother disappeared."
5754,Saw him greased and flat-eyed as a fish.
5755,"Maybe schoolteacher shot after him, shot at his feet, to remind him of the trespass."
5756,"Maybe Halle got in the barn, hid there and got locked in with the rest of schoolteacher's stock."
5757,Maybe anything.
5758,He disappeared and everybody was on his own.
5759,Paul A goes back to moving timber after dinner.
5760,They are to meet at quarters for supper.
5761,He never shows up.
5762,"Paul D leaves for the creek on time, believing, hoping, Paul A has gone on ahead; certain schoolteacher has learned something."
5763,Paul D gets to the creek and it is as dry as Sixo promised.
5764,"He waits there with the Thirty-Mile Woman for Sixo and Paul A. Only Sixo shows up, his wrists bleeding, his tongue licking his lips like a flame."
5765,"""You see Paul A?"""
5768,"""No sign of them?"""
5769,"""No sign. Nobody in quarters but the children."""
5770,"""Her children sleep. She must be there still."""
5771,"""I can't leave without Paul A."""
5772,"""Should I go back and look for them?"""
5773,"""I can't help you."""
5774,"""I can't help you."""
5775,"""What you think?"""
5776,"""I think they go straight to the corn."""
5777,"Sixo turns, then, to the woman and they clutch each other and whisper."
5778,"She is lit now with some glowing, some shining that comes from inside her."
5779,"Before when she knelt on creek pebbles with Paul D, she was nothing, a shape in the dark breathing lightly."
5780,Sixo is about to crawl out to look for the knives he buried.
5781,He hears something.
5782,He hears nothing.
5783,Forget the knives.
5785,"The three of them climb up the bank and schoolteacher, his pupils and four other whitemen move toward them."
5786,With lamps.
5787,Sixo pushes the Thirty-Mile Woman and she runs further on in the creekbed.
5788,Paul D and Sixo run the other way toward the woods.
5789,Both are surrounded and tied.
5790,The air gets sweet then.
5791,Perfumed by the things honeybees love.
5792,"Tied like a mule, Paul D feels how dewy and inviting the grass is."
5793,He is thinking about that and where Paul A might be when Sixo turns and grabs the mouth of the nearest pointing rifle.
5794,He begins to sing.
5795,Two others shove Paul D and tie him to a tree.
5796,"Schoolteacher is saying, ""Alive. Alive. I want him alive."""
5797,"Sixo swings and cracks the ribs of one, but with bound hands cannot get the weapon in position to use it in any other way."
5798,All the whitemen have to do is wait.
5799,"For his song, perhaps, to end?"
5800,Five guns are trained on him while they listen.
5801,Paul D cannot see them when they step away from lamplight.
5802,"Finally one of them hits Sixo in the head with his rifle, and when he comes to, a hickory fire is in front of him and he is tied at the waist to a tree."
5803,"Schoolteacher has changed his mind: ""This one will never be"
5804,suitable.
5805,""" The song must have convinced him."
5806,The fire keeps failing and the whitemen are put out with themselves at not being prepared for this emergency.
5807,"They came to capture, not kill."
5808,What they can manage is only enough for cooking hominy.
5809,Dry faggots are scarce and the grass is slick with dew.
5810,By the light of the hominy fire Sixo straightens.
5811,He is through with his song.
5812,He laughs.
5813,A rippling sound like Sethe's sons make when they tumble in hay or splash in rainwater.
5814,His feet are cooking; the cloth of his trousers smokes.
5815,He laughs.
5816,Something is funny.
5817,"Paul D guesses what it is when Sixo interrupts his laughter to call out, ""Seven-O! Seven-O!"""
5818,"Smoky, stubborn fire."
5819,They shoot him to shut him up.
5820,Have to.
5821,"Shackled, walking through the perfumed things honeybees love, Paul D hears the men talking and for the first time learns his worth."
5822,"He has always known, or believed he did, his value--as a hand, a laborer who could make profit on a farm--but now he discovers his worth, which is to say he learns his price."
5823,"The dollar value of his weight, his strength, his heart, his brain, his penis, and his future."
5824,"As soon as the whitemen get to where they have tied their horses and mount them, they are calmer, talking among themselves about the difficulty they face."
5825,The problems.
5826,Voices remind schoolteacher about the spoiling these particular slaves have had at Garner's hands.
5827,There's laws against what he done: letting niggers hire out their own time to buy themselves.
5828,He even let em have guns!
5829,And you think he mated them niggers to get him some more?
5830,Hell no!
5831,He planned for them to marry! if that don't beat all!
5832,"Schoolteacher sighs, and says doesn't he know it?"
5833,He had come to put the place aright.
5834,"Now it faced greater ruin than what Garner left for it, because of the loss of two niggers, at the least, and maybe three because he is not sure they will find the one called Halle."
5835,The sister-in-law is too weak to help out and doggone if now there ain't a full-scale stampede on his hands.
5836,"He would have to trade this here one for $ if he could get it, and set out to"
5837,"secure the breeding one, her foal and the other one, if he found him."
5838,"With the money from ""this here one"" he could get two young ones, twelve or fifteen years old."

5839,"And maybe with the breeding one, her three pickaninnies and whatever the foal might be, he and his nephews would have seven niggers and Sweet Home would be worth the trouble it was causing him."
5840,"""Look to you like Lillian gonna make it?"""
5841,"""Touch and go. Touch and go."""
5842,"""You was married to her sister-in-law, wasn't you?"""
5844,"""She frail too?"""
5845,"""A bit. Fever took her."""
5846,"""Well, you don't need to stay no widower in these parts."""
5847,"""My cogitation right now is Sweet Home."""
5848,"""Can't say as I blame you. That's some spread."""
5849,They put a three-spoke collar on him so he can't lie down and they chain his ankles together.
5850,The number he heard with his ear is now in his head.
5853,Two niggers lost?
5854,Paul D thinks his heart is jumping.
5855,"They are going to look for Halle, not Paul A. They must have found Paul A and if a whiteman finds you it means you are surely lost."
5856,Schoolteacher looks at him for a long time before he closes the door of the cabin.
5857,"Carefully, he looks."
5858,Paul D does not look back.
5859,It is sprinkling now.
5860,A teasing August rain that raises expectations it cannot fill.
5861,He thinks he should have sung along.
5862,"Loud something loud and rolling to go with Sixo's tune, but the words put him off-- he didn't understand the words."
5863,Although it shouldn't have mattered because he understood the sound: hatred so loose it was juba.
5864,"The warm sprinkle comes and goes, comes and goes."
5865,"He thinks he hears sobbing that seems to come from Mrs. Garner's window, but it could be anything, anyone, even a she-cat making her yearning known."
5866,"Tired of holding his head up, he lets his chin rest on the collar and speculates on how he can hobble over to the grate, boil a little water and throw in a handful of meal."
5867,"That's what he is doing when Sethe comes in, rain-wet and big-bellied, saying she is going to cut."
5868,She has just come back from taking her children to the corn.
5869,The whites were not around.
5870,She couldn't find Halle.
5871,Who was caught?
5872,Did Sixo get away?
5873,Paul A?
5874,"He tells her what he knows: Sixo is dead; the Thirty-Mile Woman ran, and he doesn't know what happened to Paul A or Halle."
5875,"""Where could he be?"" she asks."
5876,Paul D shrugs because he can't shake his head.
5877,"""You saw Sixo die? You sure?"""
5879,"""Was he woke when it happened? Did he see it coming?"""
5880,"""He was woke. Woke and laughing."""
5881,"""Sixo laughed?"""
5882,"""You should have heard him, Sethe."""
5883,Sethe's dress steams before the little fire over which he is boiling water.
5884,It is hard to move about with shackled ankles and the neck jewelry embarrasses him.
5885,"In his shame he avoids her eyes, but when he doesn't he sees only black in them--no whites."
5886,"She says she is going, and he thinks she will never make it to the gate, but he doesn't dissuade her."
5887,"He knows he will never see her again, and right then and there his heart stopped."
5888,"The pupils must have taken her to the barn for sport right afterward, and when she told Mrs. Garner, they took down the cowhide."
5889,Who in hell or on this earth would have thought that she would cut anyway?
5890,"They must have believed, what with her belly and her back, that she wasn't going anywhere."
5891,"He wasn't surprised to learn that they had tracked her down in Cincinnati, because, when he thought about it now, her price was greater than his; property that reproduced itself without cost."
5892,"Remembering his own price, down to the cent, that schoolteacher was able to get for him, he wondered what Sethe's would have been."
5893,What had Baby Suggs' been?
5894,"How much did Halle owe, still, besides his labor?"
5895,What did Mrs. Garner get for Paul F?
5896,More than nine hundred dollars?
5897,How much more?
5898,Ten dollars?
5899,Twenty?
5900,Schoolteacher would know.
5901,He knew the worth of everything.
5902,It accounted for the real sorrow in his voice when he pronounced Sixo unsuitable.
5903,Who could be fooled into buying a singing nigger with a gun?
5904,Shouting Seven-O!
5905,Seven-O! because his Thirty-Mile Woman got away with his blossoming seed.
5906,What a laugh.
5907,So rippling and full of glee it put out the fire.
5908,"And it was Sixo's laughter that was on his mind, not the bit in his mouth, when they hitched him to the buckboard."
5909,"Then he saw Halle, then the rooster, smiling as if to say, You ain't seen nothing yet."
5910,"How could a rooster know about Alfred, Georgia?"
5912,Stamp Paid was still fingering the ribbon and it made a little motion in his pants pocket.
5913,"Paul D looked up, noticed the side pocket agitation and snorted."
5914,"""I can't read. You got any more newspaper for me, just a waste of time."""
5915,Stamp withdrew the ribbon and sat down on the steps.
5916,"""No. This here's something else."""
5917,He stroked the red cloth between forefinger and thumb.
5918,"""Something else."""
5919,Paul D didn't say anything so the two men sat in silence for a few moments.
5920,"""This is hard for me,"" said Stamp."
5921,"""But I got to do it. Two things I got to say to you. I'm a take the easy one first."""
5922,Paul D chuckled.
5923,"""If it's hard for you, might kill me dead."""
5924,"""No, no. Nothing like that. I come looking for you to ask your pardon. Apologize."""
5926,Paul D reached in his coat pocket for his bottle.

5927,"""You pick any house, any house where colored live. In all of Cincinnati. Pick any one and you welcome to stay there. I'm apologizing because they didn't offer or tell you. But you welcome anywhere you want to be. My house is your house too. John and Ella, Miss Lady, Able Woodruff, Willie Pike-- anybody. You choose. You ain't got to sleep in no cellar, and I apologize for each and every night you did. I don't know how that preacher let you do it. I knowed him since he was a boy."""
5928,"""Whoa, Stamp. He offered."""
5930,"""Well. I wanted, I didn't want to, I just wanted to be off by myself a spell. He offered. Every time I see him he offers again."""
5931,"""That's a load off. I thought everybody gone crazy."""
5932,Paul D shook his head.
5934,"""You planning to do anything about it?"""
5935,"""Oh, yeah. I got big plans."""
5936,He swallowed twice from the bottle.
5937,"Any planning in a bottle is short, thought Stamp, but he knew from personal experience the pointlessness of telling a drinking man not to."
5938,He cleared his sinuses and began to think how to get to the second thing he had come to say.
5939,Very few people were out today.
5940,The canal was frozen so that traffic too had stopped.
5941,They heard the dop of a horse approaching.
5942,Its rider sat a high Eastern saddle but everything else about him was Ohio Valley.
5943,"As he rode by he looked at them and suddenly reined his horse, and came up to the path leading to the church."
5944,He leaned forward.
5945,"""Hey,"" he said."
5946,Stamp put his ribbon in his pocket.
5948,"""I'm looking for a gal name of Judy. Works over by the slaughterhouse."""
5949,"""Don't believe I know her. No, sir."""
5950,"""Said she lived on Plank Road."""
5951,"""Plank Road. Yes, sir. That's up a ways. Mile, maybe."""
5952,"""You don't know her? Judy. Works in the slaughterhouse."""
5953,"""No, sir, but I know Plank Road. 'Bout a mile up thataway."""
5954,Paul D lifted his bottle and swallowed.
5955,The rider looked at him and then back at Stamp Paid.
5956,"Loosening the right rein, he turned his horse toward the road, then changed his mind and came back."
5957,"""Look here,"" he said to Paul D. ""There's a cross up there, so I guess this here's a church or used to be. Seems to me like you ought to show it some respect, you follow me?"""
5958,"""Yes, sir,"" said Stamp."
5959,"""You right about that. That's just what I come over to talk to him about. Just that."""
5960,The rider clicked his tongue and trotted off.
5961,Stamp made small circles in the
5962,palm of his left hand with two fingers of his right.
5963,"""You got to choose,"" he said."

5964,"""Choose anyone. They let you be if you want em to. My house. Ella. Willie Pike. None of us got much, but all of us got room for one more. Pay a little something when you can, don't when you can't. Think about it. You grown. I can't make you do what you won't, but think about it."""
5965,Paul D said nothing.
5966,"""If I did you harm, I'm here to rectify it."""
5967,"""No need for that. No need at all."""
5968,A woman with four children walked by on the other side of the road.
5969,"She waved, smiling."
5970,"""Hoo-oo. I can't stop. See you at meeting."""
5971,"""I be there,"" Stamp returned her greeting."

5972,"""There's another one,"" he said to Paul D. ""Scripture Woodruff, Able's sister. Works at the brush and tallow factory. You'll see. Stay around here long enough, you'll see ain't a sweeter bunch of colored anywhere than what's right here. Pride, well, that bothers em a bit. They can get messy when they think somebody's too proud, but when it comes right down to it, they good people and anyone will take you in."""
5973,"""What about Judy? She take me in?"""
5974,"""Depends. What you got in mind?"""
5975,"""You know Judy?"""
5976,"""Judith. I know everybody."""
5977,"""Out on Plank Road?"""
5978,"""Everybody."""
5979,"""Well? She take me in?"""
5980,Stamp leaned down and untied his shoe.
5981,"Twelve black buttonhooks, six on each side at the bottom, led to four pairs of eyes at the top."
5982,He loosened the
5983,"laces all the way down, adjusted the tongue carefully and wound them back again."
5984,When he got to the eyes he rolled the lace tips with his fingers before inserting them.
5985,"""Let me tell you how I got my name."""
5986,The knot was tight and so was the bow.
5987,"""They called me Joshua,"" he said."
5988,"""I renamed myself,"" he said, ""and I'm going to tell you why I did it,"" and he told him about Vashti."
5989,"""I never touched her all that time."
5990,Not once.
5991,Almost a year.
5992,We was planting when it started and picking when it stopped.
5993,Seemed longer.
5994,I should have killed him.
5995,"She said no, but I should have."
5996,"I didn't have the patience I got now, but I figured maybe somebody else didn't have much patience either--his own wife."
5997,Took it in my head to see if she was taking it any better than I was.
5998,Vashti and me was in the fields together in the day and every now and then she be gone all night.
5999,I never touched her and damn me if I spoke three words to her a day.
6000,"I took any chance I had to get near the great house to see her, the young master's wife."
6001,Nothing but a boy.
6002,"Seventeen, twenty maybe."
6003,"I caught sight of her finally, standing in the backyard by the fence with a glass of water."
6004,She was drinking out of it and just gazing out over the yard.
6005,I went over.
6006,Stood back a ways and took off my hat.
6007,"I said, 'Scuse me, miss. Scuse me?'"
6008,She turned to look.
6009,I'm smiling.
6010,'Scuse me.
6011,You seen Vashti?
6012,My wife Vashti?'
6013,"A little bitty thing, she was."
6014,Black hair.
6015,Face no bigger than my hand.
6016,"She said, ""What?"
6017,Vashti?'
6018,"I say, 'Yes'm, Vashti."
6019,My wife.
6020,She say she owe you all some eggs.
6021,You know if she brung em?
6022,You know her if you see her.
6023,Wear a black ribbon on her neck.
6024,She got rosy then and I knowed she knowed.
6025,He give Vashti that to wear.
6026,A cameo on a black ribbon.
6027,She used to put it on every time she went to him.
6028,I put my hat back on.
6029,"'You see her tell her I need her. Thank you. Thank you, ma'am.'"
6030,I backed off before she could say something.
6031,I didn't dare look back till I got behind some trees.
6032,"She was standing just as I left her, looking in her water glass."
6033,I thought it would give me more satisfaction than it did.
6034,"I also thought she might stop it,"
6035,but it went right on.
6036,Till one morning Vashti came in and sat by the window.
6037,A Sunday.
6038,We worked our own patches on Sunday.
6039,She sat by the window looking out of it.
6040,"'I'm back,' she said."
6041,"'I'm back, Josh."
6042,' I looked at the back of her neck.
6043,She had a real small neck.
6044,I decided to break it.
6045,"You know, like a twig--just snap it."
6046,I been low but that was as low as I ever got.
6047,"""Did you? Snap it?"""
6048,"""Uh uh. I changed my name."""
6049,"""How you get out of there? How you get up here?"""
6050,"""Boat. On up the Mississippi to Memphis. Walked from Memphis to Cumberland."""
6051,"""Aw, man. Tie your other shoe!"""
6052,"""Vashti too?"""
6053,"""No. She died."""
6056,"""Tie your goddamn shoe!"
6057,It's sitting right in front of you!
6058,"""That make you feel better?"""
6059,Paul D tossed the bottle on the ground and stared at the golden chariot on its label.
6060,No horses.
6061,Just a golden coach draped in blue cloth.
6062,"""I said I had two things to say to you. I only told you one. I have to tell you the other."""
6063,"""I don't want to know it. I don't want to know nothing. Just if Judy will take me in or won't she."""
6064,"""I was there, Paul D."""
6065,"""You was where?"""
6066,"""There in the yard. When she did it."""
6070,"""It ain't what you think."""
6071,"""You don't know what I think."""
6072,"""Leave off."""
6073,"""And spread it."""
6074,"""She ain't crazy. She love those children. She was trying to out hurt the hurter."""
6075,"""Stamp, let me off. I knew her when she was a girl. She scares me and I knew her when she was a girl."""
6076,"""You ain't scared of Sethe. I don't believe you."""
6077,"""Sethe scares me. I scare me. And that girl in her house scares me the most."""
6078,"""Who is that girl? Where she come from?"""
6079,"""I don't know. Just shot up one day sitting on a stump."""
6080,"""Huh. Look like you and me the only ones outside lay eyes on her."""
6081,"""She don't go nowhere. Where'd you see her?"""
6082,"""Sleeping on the kitchen floor. I peeped in."""
6083,"""First minute I saw her I didn't want to be nowhere around her."
6084,Something funny about her.
6085,Talks funny.
6086,Acts funny.
6087,""" Paul D dug his fingers underneath his cap and rubbed the scalp over his temple."
6088,"""She reminds me of something. Something, look like, I'm supposed to remember."""
6089,"""She never say where she was from? Where's her people?"""
6090,"""She don't know, or says she don't. All I ever heard her say was something about stealing her clothes and living on a bridge."""
6091,"""What kind of bridge?"""
6092,"""Who you asking?"""
6093,"""No bridges around here I don't know about. But don't nobody live on em. Under em neither. How long she been over there with Sethe?"""
6094,"""Last August. Day of the carnival."""
6095,"""That's a bad sign. Was she at the carnival?"""
6096,"""No. When we got back, there she was--'sleep on a stump. Silk dress. Brand- new shoes. Black as oil."""

6097,"""You don't say? Huh. Was a girl locked up in the house with a whiteman over by Deer Creek. Found him dead last summer and the girl gone. Maybe that's her. Folks say he had her in there since she was a pup."""
6098,"""Well, now she's a bitch."""
6099,"""Is she what run you off? Not what I told you 'bout Sethe?"""
6100,A shudder ran through Paul D. A bone-cold spasm that made him clutch his knees.

6101,"He didn't know if it was bad whiskey, nights in the cellar, pig fever, iron bits, smiling roosters, fired feet, laughing dead men, hissing grass, rain, apple blossoms, neck jewelry, Judy in the slaughterhouse, Halle in the butter,"
6102,"ghost-white stairs, chokecherry trees, cameo pins, aspens, Paul A's face, sausage or the loss of a red, red heart."
6103,"""Tell me something, Stamp."""
6104,Paul D's eyes were rheumy.
6105,"""Tell me this one thing."
6106,How much is a nigger supposed to take?
6107,Tell me.
6108,"How much?"""
6109,"""All he can,"" said Stamp Paid."
6110,"""All he can."""
6111,"""why? Why? Why? Why? Why?"""
6112,WAS QUIET.
6113,"Denver, who thought she knew all about silence, was surprised to learn hunger could do that: quiet you down and wear you out."
6114,Neither Sethe nor Beloved knew or cared about it one way or another.
6115,They were too busy rationing their strength to fight each other.
6116,"So it was she who had to step off the edge of the world and die because if she didn't, they all would."
6117,The flesh between her mother's forefinger and thumb was thin as china silk and there wasn't a piece of clothing in the house that didn't sag on her.
6118,"Beloved held her head up with the palms of her hands, slept wherever she happened to be, and whined for sweets although she was getting bigger, plumper by the day."
6119,"Everything was gone except two laying hens, and somebody would soon have to decide whether an egg every now and then was worth more than two fried chickens."

6120,"The hungrier they got, the weaker; the weaker they got, the quieter they were--which was better than the furious arguments, the poker slammed up against the wall, all the shouting and crying that followed that one happy January when they played."
6121,"Denver had joined in the play, holding back a bit out of habit, even though it was the most fun she had ever known."

6122,"But once Sethe had seen the scar, the tip of which Denver had been looking at whenever Beloved undressed--the little curved shadow of a smile in the kootchy-kootchy-coo place under her chin--once Sethe saw it, fingered it and closed her eyes for a long time, the two of them cut Denver out of the games."
6123,"The cooking games, the sewing games, the hair and dressing-up games."
6124,Games her mother loved so well she took to going to work later and later each day until the predictable happened: Sawyer told her not to come back.
6125,"And instead of looking for another job, Sethe played all the harder with Beloved, who never got enough of anything: lullabies, new stitches, the bottom of the cake bowl, the top of the milk."
6126,"If the hen had only two eggs, she got both."
6127,"It was as though her mother had lost her mind, like Grandma Baby calling for pink and not doing the things she used to."
6128,"But different because, unlike Baby Suggs, she cut Denver out completely."
6129,"Even the song that she used to sing to Denver she sang for Beloved alone: ""High Johnny, wide Johnny, don't you leave my side, Johnny."""
6130,At first they played together.
6131,A whole month and Denver loved it.
6132,"From the night they ice-skated under a star-loaded sky and drank sweet milk by the stove, to the string puzzles Sethe did for them in afternoon light, and shadow pictures in the gloaming."
6133,"In the very teeth of winter and Sethe, her eyes fever bright, was plotting a garden of vegetables and flowers--talking, talking about what colors it would have."
6134,"She played with Beloved's hair, braiding, puffing, tying, oiling it until it made Denver nervous to watch her They changed beds and exchanged clothes."
6135,Walked arm in arm and smiled all the time.
6136,"When the weather broke, they were on their knees in the backyard designing a garden in dirt too hard to chop."

6137,"The thirty-eight dollars of life savings went to feed themselves with fancy food and decorate themselves with ribbon and dress goods, which Sethe cut and sewed like they were going somewhere in a hurry."

6138,"Bright clothes--with blue stripes and sassy prints. She walked the four miles to John Shillito's to buy yellow ribbon, shiny buttons and bits of black lace. By the end of March the three of them looked like carnival women with nothing to do. When it became clear that they were only interested in each other, Denver began to drift from the play, but she watched it, alert for any sign that Beloved was in danger. Finally convinced there was none, and seeing her mother that happy, that smiling--how could it go wrong?--she let down her guard and it did."
6139,Her problem at first was trying to find out who was to blame.
6140,"Her eye was on her mother, for a signal that the thing that was in her was out, and she would kill again."
6141,But it was Beloved who made demands.
6142,"Anything she wanted she got, and when Sethe ran out of things to give her, Beloved invented desire."

6143,"She wanted Sethe's company for hours to watch the layer of brown leaves waving at them from the bottom of the creek, in the same place where, as a little girl, Denver played in the silence with her."
6144,Now the players were altered.
6145,"As soon as the thaw was complete Beloved gazed at her gazing face, rippling, folding, spreading, disappearing into the leaves below."
6146,"She flattened herself on the ground, dirtying her bold stripes, and touched the rocking faces with her own."

6147,"She filled basket after basket with the first things warmer weather let loose in the ground--dandelions, violets, forsythia--presenting them to Sethe, who arranged them, stuck them, wound them all over the house."
6148,"Dressed in Sethe's dresses, she stroked her skin with the palm of her hand."
6149,"She imitated Sethe, talked the way she did, laughed her"
6150,"laugh and used her body the same way down to the walk, the way Sethe moved her hands, sighed through her nose, held her head."
6151,"Sometimes coming upon them making men and women cookies or tacking scraps of cloth on Baby Suggs' old quilt, it was difficult for Denver to tell who was who."
6152,Then the mood changed and the arguments began.
6153,Slowly at first.
6154,"A complaint from Beloved, an apology from Sethe."
6155,A reduction of pleasure at some special effort the older woman made.
6156,Wasn't it too cold to stay outside?
6157,"Beloved gave a look that said, So what?"
6158,"Was it past bedtime, the light no good for sewing?"
6159,"Beloved didn't move; said, ""Do it,"" and Sethe complied."
6160,She took the best of everything--first.

6161,"The best chair, the biggest piece, the prettiest plate, the brightest ribbon for her hair, and the more she took, the more Sethe began to talk, explain, describe how much she had suffered, been through, for her children, waving away flies in grape arbors, crawling on her knees to a lean-to."
6162,None of which made the impression it was supposed to.
6163,Beloved accused her of leaving her behind.
6164,"Of not being nice to her, not smiling at her."
6165,"She said they were the same, had the same face, how could she have left her?"
6166,"And Sethe cried, saying she never did, or meant to--- that she had to get them out, away, that she had the milk all the time and had the money too for the stone but not enough."
6167,"That her plan was always that they would all be together on the other side, forever."
6168,Beloved wasn't interested.
6169,She said when she cried there was no one.
6170,That dead men lay on top of her.
6171,That she had nothing to eat.
6172,Ghosts without skin stuck their fingers in her and said beloved in the dark and bitch in the light.
6173,"Sethe pleaded for forgiveness, counting, listing again and again her reasons: that Beloved was more important, meant more to her than her own life."
6174,That she would trade places any day.
6175,"Give up her life, every minute and hour of it, to take back just one of Beloved's tears."
6176,Did she know it hurt her when mosquitoes bit her baby?
6177,That to leave her on the ground to run into the big house drove her crazy?
6178,That before leaving Sweet Home Beloved slept every night on her chest or curled on her back?
6179,Beloved denied it.
6180,"Sethe never came to her, never said a word to her, never smiled and worst of all never waved goodbye or even looked her way before running away from her."
6181,"When once or twice Sethe tried to assert herself--be the unquestioned mother whose word was law and who knew what was best--Beloved slammed things,"
6182,"wiped the table clean of plates, threw salt on the floor, broke a windowpane."
6183,She was not like them.
6184,"She was wild game, and nobody said, Get on out of here, girl, and come back when you get some sense."
6185,"Nobody said, You raise your hand to me and I will knock you into the middle of next week."
6186,"Ax the trunk, the limb will die."
6187,Honor thy mother and father that thy days may be long upon the land which the Lord thy God giveth thee.
6188,"I will wrap you round that doorknob, don't nobody work for you and God don't love ugly ways."
6190,"They mended the plates, swept the salt, and little by little it dawned on Denver that if Sethe didn't wake up one morning and pick up a knife, Beloved might."
6191,"Frightened as she was by the thing in Sethe that could come out, it shamed her to see her mother serving a girl not much older than herself."
6192,"When she saw her carrying out Beloved's night bucket, Denver raced to relieve her of it."

6193,"But the pain was unbearable when they ran low on food, and Denver watched her mother go without--pick-eating around the edges of the table and stove: the hominy that stuck on the bottom; the crusts and rinds and peelings of things."
6194,Once she saw her run her longest finger deep in an empty jam jar before rinsing and putting it away.
6195,"They grew tired, and even Beloved, who was getting bigger, seemed nevertheless as exhausted as they were."
6196,In any case she substituted a snarl or a tooth-suck for waving a poker around and was quiet.
6197,Listless and sleepy with hunger Denver saw the flesh between her mother's forefinger and thumb fade.

6198,"Saw Sethe's eyes bright but dead, alert but vacant, paying attention to everything about Beloved--her lineless palms, her forehead, the smile under her jaw, crooked and much too long--everything except her basket-fat stomach."
6199,She also saw the sleeves of her own carnival shirtwaist cover her fingers; hems that once showed her ankles now swept the floor.
6200,"She saw themselves beribboned, decked-out, limp and starving but locked in a love that wore everybody out."
6201,Then Sethe spit up something she had not eaten and it rocked Denver like gunshot.
6202,"The job she started out with, protecting Beloved from Sethe, changed to protecting her mother from Beloved."
6203,Now it was obvious that her mother could die and leave them both and what would Beloved do then?
6204,"Whatever was happening, it only worked with three--not two--and since neither Beloved nor Sethe seemed to care what"
6205,"the next day might bring (Sethe happy when Beloved was; Beloved lapping devotion like cream), Denver knew it was on her."
6206,"She would have to leave the yard; step off the edge of the world, leave the two behind and go ask somebody for help."
6207,Who would it be?
6208,"Who could she stand in front of who wouldn't shame her on learning that her mother sat around like a rag doll, broke down, finally, from trying to take care of and make up for."
6209,"Denver knew about several people, from hearing her mother and grandmother talk."
6210,"But she knew, personally, only two: an old man with white hair called Stamp and Lady Jones."
6211,"Well, Paul D, of course."
6212,And that boy who told her about Sethe.
6213,But they wouldn't do at all.
6214,Her heart kicked and an itchy burning in her throat made her swallow all her saliva away.
6215,She didn't even know which way to go.
6216,"When Sethe used to work at the restaurant and when she still had money to shop, she turned right."
6217,"Back when Denver went to Lady Jones' school, it was left."
6218,The weather was warm; the day beautiful.
6219,It was April and everything alive was tentative.
6220,Denver wrapped her hair and her shoulders.
6221,"In the brightest of the carnival dresses and wearing a stranger's shoes, she stood on the porch of ready to be swallowed up in the world beyond the edge of the porch."
6222,Out there where small things scratched and sometimes touched.
6223,Where words could be spoken that would close your ears shut.
6224,"Where, if you were alone, feeling could overtake you and stick to you like a shadow."
6225,Out there where there were places in which things so bad had happened that when you went near them it would happen again.
6226,"Like Sweet Home where time didn't pass and where, like her mother said, the bad was waiting for her as well."
6227,How would she know these places?
6228,What was more-- much more---out there were whitepeople and how could you tell about them?
6229,Sethe said the mouth and sometimes the hands.
6230,"Grandma Baby said there was no defense--they could prowl at will, change from one mind to another, and even when they thought they were behaving, it was a far cry from what real humans did."
6231,"""They got me out of jail,"" Sethe once told Baby Suggs."
6232,"""They also put you in it,"" she answered."
6233,"""They drove you 'cross the river."""
6234,"""On my son's back."""
6235,"""They gave you this house."""
6236,"""Nobody gave me nothing."""
6237,"""I got a job from them."""
6238,"""He got a cook from them, girl."""
6239,"""Oh, some of them do all right by us."""
6240,"""And every time it's a surprise, ain't it?"""
6241,"""You didn't used to talk this way."""
6242,"""Don't box with me."
6243,There's more of us they drowned than there is all of them ever lived from the start of time.
6244,Lay down your sword.
6245,This ain't a battle; it's a rout.
6246,"Remembering those conversations and her grandmother's last and final words, Denver stood on the porch in the sun and couldn't leave it."
6247,"Her throat itched; her heart kicked--and then Baby Suggs laughed, clear as anything."
6248,"""You mean I never told you nothing about Carolina?"
6249,About your daddy?
6250,"You don't remember nothing about how come I walk the way I do and about your mother's feet, not to speak of her back?"
6251,I never told you all that?
6252,Is that why you can't walk down the steps?
6253,My Jesus my.
6254,But you said there was no defense.
6255,"""There ain't."""
6256,Then what do I do?
6257,"""Know it, and go on out the yard. Go on."""
6258,It came back.
6259,A dozen years had passed and the way came back.
6260,"Four houses on the right, sitting close together in a line like wrens."
6261,"The first house had two steps and a rocking chair on the porch; the second had three steps, a broom propped on the porch beam, two broken chairs and a clump of forsythia at the side."
6262,No window at the front.
6263,A little boy sat on the ground chewing a stick.
6264,The third house had yellow shutters on its two front windows and pot after pot of green leaves with white hearts or red.
6265,Denver could hear chickens and the knock of a badly hinged gate.
6266,At the fourth house the buds of a sycamore tree had rained down on the roof and made the yard look as though grass grew there.
6267,"A woman, standing at the open door, lifted her hand halfway in greeting, then froze it near her shoulder as she leaned forward to see whom she waved to."
6268,Denver lowered her head.
6269,Next was a tiny fenced plot with a cow in it.
6270,She remembered the plot but not the cow.
6271,Under her headcloth her scalp was wet with tension.
6272,"Beyond her, voices, male voices, floated, coming closer with each step she took."
6273,Denver kept her eyes on the road in case they were whitemen; in case she was walking where they wanted to; in case they said something and she would have to answer them.
6274,"Suppose they flung out at her, grabbed her, tied her."
6275,They were getting closer.

6276,"Maybe she should cross the road--now. Was the woman who half waved at her still there in the open door? Would she come to her rescue, or, angry at Denver for not waving back, would she withhold her help? Maybe she should turn around, get closer to the waving woman's house. Before she could make up her mind, it was too late--they were right in front of her."
6277,"Two men, Negro."
6278,Denver breathed.
6279,"Both men touched their caps and murmured, ""Morning. Morning."""
6280,Denver believed her eyes spoke gratitude but she never got her mouth open in time to reply.
6281,They moved left of her and passed on.
6282,"Braced and heartened by that easy encounter, she picked up speed and began to look deliberately at the neighborhood surrounding her."
6283,She was shocked to see how small the big things were: the boulder by the edge of the road she once couldn't see over was a sitting-on rock.
6284,Paths leading to houses weren't miles long.
6285,Dogs didn't even reach her knees.
6286,Letters cut into beeches and oaks by giants were eye level now.
6287,She would have known it anywhere.
6288,"The post and scrap-lumber fence was gray now, not white, but she would have known it anywhere."

6289,"The stone porch sitting in a skirt of ivy, pale yellow curtains at the windows; the laid brick path to the front door and wood planks leading around to the back, passing under the windows where she had stood on tiptoe to see above the sill."
6290,"Denver was about to do it again, when she realized how silly it would be to be found once more staring into the parlor of Mrs. Lady Jones."
6291,"The pleasure she felt at having found the house dissolved, suddenly, in doubt."
6292,Suppose she didn't live there anymore?
6293,Or remember her former student after all this time?
6294,What would she say?
6295,"Denver shivered inside, wiped the perspiration from her forehead and knocked."
6296,Lady Jones went to the door expecting raisins.
6297,"A child, probably, from the softness of the knock, sent by its mother with the raisins she needed if her contribution to the supper was to be worth the trouble."
6298,"There would be any number of plain cakes, potato pies."

6299,"She had reluctantly volunteered her own special creation, but said she didn't have raisins, so raisins is what the president said would be provided--early enough so there would be no excuses. Mrs. Jones, dreading the fatigue of beating batter, had been hoping she had forgotten. Her bake oven had been cold all week--getting it to the right temperature would be awful."
6300,"Since her husband died and her eyes grew dim, she had let up-to-snuff housekeeping fall away."
6301,She was of two minds about baking something for the church.
6302,"On the one hand, she wanted to remind everybody of what she was able to do in the cooking line; on the other, she didn't want to have to."
6303,"When she heard the tapping at the door, she sighed and went to it hoping the raisins had at least been cleaned."
6304,"She was older, of course, and dressed like a chippy, but the girl was immediately recognizable to Lady Jones."
6305,"Everybody's child was in that face: the nickel-round eyes, bold yet mistrustful; the large powerful teeth between"
6306,dark sculptured lips that did not cover them.
6307,"Some vulnerability lay across the bridge of the nose, above the cheeks."
6308,And then the skin.
6309,"Flawless, economical--just enough of it to cover the bone and not a bit more."
6310,"She must be eighteen or nineteen by now, thought Lady Jones, looking at the face young enough to be twelve."
6311,"Heavy eyebrows, thick baby lashes and the unmistakable love call that shimmered around children until they learned better."
6312,"""Why, Denver,"" she said."
6313,"""Look at you."""
6314,"Lady Jones had to take her by the hand and pull her in, because the smile seemed all the girl could manage."
6315,"Other people said this child was simple, but Lady Jones never believed it."
6316,"Having taught her, watched her eat up a page, a rule, a figure, she knew better."
6317,"When suddenly she had stopped coming, Lady Jones thought it was the nickel."
6318,"She approached the ignorant grandmother one day on the road, a woods preacher who mended shoes, to tell her it was all right if the money was owed."
6319,"The woman said that wasn't it; the child was deaf, and deaf Lady Jones thought she still was until she offered her a seat and Denver heard that."
6320,"""It's nice of you to come see me. What brings you?"""
6321,Denver didn't answer.
6322,"""Well, nobody needs a reason to visit. Let me make us some tea."""
6323,Lady Jones was mixed.
6324,"Gray eyes and yellow woolly hair, every strand of which she hated--though whether it was the color or the texture even she didn't know."

6325,"She had married the blackest man she could find, had five rainbow-colored children and sent them all to Wilberforce, after teaching them all she knew right along with the others who sat in her parlor."
6326,"Her light skin got her picked for a coloredgirls', normal school in Pennsylvania and she paid it back by teaching the unpicked."
6327,"The children who played in dirt until they were old enough for chores, these she taught."
6328,"The colored population of Cincinnati had two graveyards and six churches, but since no school or"
6329,"hospital was obliged to serve them, they learned and died at home."
6330,"She believed in her heart that, except for her husband, the whole world (including her children) despised her and her hair."

6331,"She had been listening to ""all that yellow gone to waste"" and ""white nigger"" since she was a girl in a houseful of silt-black children, so she disliked everybody a little bit because she believed they hated her hair as much as she did."

6332,"With that education pat and firmly set, she dispensed with rancor, was indiscriminately polite, saving her real affection for the unpicked children of Cincinnati, one of whom sat before her in a dress so loud it embarrassed the needlepoint chair seat."
6333,"""Yes. Thank you."""
6334,Denver drank it all down.
6338,"""Here. Go ahead."""
6340,"""I want work, Miss Lady."""
6342,"""Yes, ma'am. Anything."""
6343,Lady Jones smiled.
6344,"""What can you do?"""
6345,"""How's your family, honey?"""
6346,Denver stopped in the middle of a swallow.
6347,"There was no way to tell her how her family was, so she said what was at the top of her mind."
6348,"""I can't do anything, but I would learn it for you if you have a little extra."""
6350,"""Food. My ma'am, she doesn't feel good."""
6351,"""Oh, baby,"" said Mrs. Jones."
6353,Denver looked up at her.
6354,"She did not know it then, but it was the word ""baby,"" said softly and with such kindness, that inaugurated her life in the world as a woman."
6355,The trail she followed to get to that sweet thorny place was made up of paper scraps containing the handwritten names of others.
6356,"Lady Jones gave her some rice, four eggs and some tea."
6357,Denver said she couldn't be away from home long because of her mother's condition.
6358,Could she do chores in the morning?
6359,"Lady Jones told her that no one, not herself, not anyone she knew, could pay anybody anything for work they did themselves."
6360,"""But if you all need to eat until your mother is well, all you have to do is say so."""
6361,She mentioned her church's committee invented so nobody had to go hungry.
6362,"That agitated her guest who said, ""No, no,"" as though asking for help from strangers was worse than hunger."
6363,Lady Jones said goodbye to her and asked her to come back anytime.
6364,"""Anytime at all."""
6365,Two days later Denver stood on the porch and noticed something lying on the tree stump at the edge of the yard.
6366,She went to look and found a sack of white beans.
6367,Another time a plate of cold rabbit meat.
6368,One morning a basket of eggs sat there.
6369,"As she lifted it, a slip of paper fluttered down."
6370,She picked it up and looked at it.
6371,"""M. Lucille Williams"" was written in big crooked letters."
6372,On the back was a blob of flour-water paste.
6373,"So Denver paid a second visit to the world outside the porch, although all she said when she returned the basket was ""Thank you."""
6374,"""Welcome,"" said M. Lucille Williams."
6375,"Every now and then, all through the spring, names appeared near or in gifts of food."
6376,Obviously for the return of the pan or plate or basket; but also to let
6377,"the girl know, if she cared to, who the donor was, because some of the parcels were wrapped in paper, and though there was nothing to return, the name was nevertheless there."
6378,"Many had X's with designs about them, and Lady Jones tried to identify the plate or pan or the covering towel."
6379,"When she could only guess, Denver followed her directions and went to say thank you anywaym whether she had the right benefactor or not."
6380,"When she was wrong, when the person said, ""No, darling. That's not my bowl. Mine's got a blue ring on it,"" a small conversation took place."
6381,All of them knew her grandmother and some had even danced with her in the Clearing.
6382,"Others remembered the days when was a way station, the place they assembled to catch news, taste oxtail soup, leave their children, cut out a skirt."
6383,One remembered the tonic mixed there that cured a relative.
6384,"One showed her the border of a pillowslip, the stamens of its pale blue flowers French-knotted in Baby Suggs' kitchen by the light of an oil lamp while arguing the Settlement Fee."
6385,They remembered the party with twelve turkeys and tubs of strawberry smash.
6386,One said she wrapped Denver when she was a single day old and cut shoes to fit her mother's blasted feet.
6387,Maybe they were sorry for her.
6388,Or for Sethe.
6389,Maybe they were sorry for the years of their own disdain.

6390,"Maybe they were simply nice people who could hold meanness toward each other for just so long and when trouble rode bareback among them, quickly, easily they did what they could to trip him up."
6391,"In any case, the personal pride, the arrogant claim staked out at seemed to them to have run its course."
6392,"They whispered, naturally, wondered, shook their heads."
6393,"Some even laughed outright at Denver's clothes of a hussy, but it didn't stop them caring whether she ate and it didn't stop the pleasure they took in her soft ""Thank you."""
6394,"At least once a week, she visited Lady Jones, who perked up enough to do a raisin loaf especially for her, since Denver was set on sweet things."
6395,She gave her a book of Bible verse and listened while she mumbled words or fairly shouted them.
6396,By June Denver had read and memorized all fifty-two pages-- one for each week of the year.
6397,"As Denver's outside life improved, her home life deteriorated."
6398,If the whitepeople of Cincinnati had allowed Negroes into their lunatic asylum they could have found candidates in .
6399,"Strengthened by the gifts of food, the"
6400,"source of which neither Sethe nor Beloved questioned, the women had arrived at a doomsday truce designed by the devil."
6401,"Beloved sat around, ate, went from bed to bed."
6402,"Sometimes she screamed, ""Rain! Rain!"" and clawed her throat until rubies of blood opened there, made brighter by her midnight skin."
6403,"Then Sethe shouted, ""No!"" and knocked over chairs to get to her and wipe the jewels away."
6404,"Other times Beloved curled up on the floor, her wrists between her knees, and stayed there for hours."
6405,"Or she would go to the creek, stick her feet in the water and whoosh it up her legs."
6406,"Afrerward she would go to Sethe, run her fingers over the woman's teeth while tears slid from her wide black eyes."

6407,"Then it seemed to Denver the thing was done: Beloved bending over Sethe looked the mother, Sethe the teething child, for other than those times when Beloved needed her, Sethe confined herself to a corner chair."
6408,"The bigger Beloved got, the smaller Sethe became; the brighter Beloved's eyes, the more those eyes that used never to look away became slits of sleeplessness."
6409,Sethe no longer combed her hair or splashed her face with water.
6410,"She sat in the chair licking her lips like a chastised child while Beloved ate up her life, took it, swelled up with it, grew taller on it."
6411,And the older woman yielded it up without a murmur.
6412,Denver served them both.
6413,"Washing, cooking, forcing, cajoling her mother to eat a little now and then, providing sweet things for Beloved as often as she could to calm her down."
6414,It was hard to know what she would do from minute to minute.
6415,"When the heat got hot, she might walk around the house naked or wrapped in a sheet, her belly protruding like a winning watermelon."
6416,Denver thought she understood the connection between her mother and Beloved: Sethe was trying to make up for the handsaw; Beloved was making her pay for it.
6417,"But there would never be an end to that, and seeing her mother diminished shamed and infuriated her."

6418,"Yet she knew Sethe's greatest fear was the same one Denver had in the beginning--that Beloved might leave. That before Sethe could make her understand what it meant--what it took to drag the teeth of that saw under the little chin; to feel the baby blood pump like oil in her hands; to hold her face so her head would stay on; to squeeze her so she could absorb, still, the death spasms that shot through that adored body, plump and sweet with life--Beloved might leave. Leave before Sethe could make her realize that worse than that--far worse-- was what Baby Suggs died"
6419,"of, what Ella knew, what Stamp saw and what made Paul D tremble."
6420,That anybody white could take your whole self for anything that came to mind.
6421,"Not just work, kill, or maim you, but dirty you."
6422,Dirty you so bad you couldn't like yourself anymore.
6423,Dirty you so bad you forgot who you were and couldn't think it up.
6424,"And though she and others lived through and got over it, she could never let it happen to her own."
6425,"The best thing she was, was her children."
6426,"Whites might dirty bet all right, but not her best thing, her beautiful, magical best thing--the part of her that was cl ean."

6427,"No undreamable dreams about whether the headless, feetless torso hanging in the tree with a sign on it was her husband or Paul A; whether the bubbling-hot girls in the colored- school fire set by patriots included her daughter; whether a gang of whites invaded her daughter's private parts, soiled her daughter's thighs and threw her daughter out of the wagon."
6428,"She might have to work the slaughterhouse yard, but not her daughter."
6429,"And no one, nobody on this earth, would list her daughter's characteristics on the animal side of the paper."
6430,Oh no.
6431,"Maybe Baby Suggs could worry about it, live with the likelihood of it; Sethe had refused--and refused still."

6432,"This and much more Denver heard her say from her corner chair, trying to persuade Beloved, the one and only person she felt she had to convince, that what she had done was right because it came from true love."
6433,"Beloved, her fat new feet propped on the seat of a chair in front of the one she sat in, her unlined hands resting on her stomach, looked at her."
6434,"Uncomprehending everything except that Sethe was the woman who took her face away, leaving her crouching in a dark, dark place, forgetting to smile."
6435,"Her father's daughter after all, Denver decided to do the necessary."
6436,Decided to stop relying on kindness to leave something on the stump.

6437,"She would hire herself out somewhere, and although she was afraid to leave Sethe and Beloved alone all day not knowing what calamity either one of them would create, she came to realize that her presence in that house had no influence on what either woman did."
6438,She kept them alive and they ignored her.
6439,"Growled when they chose; sulked, explained, demanded, strutted, cowered, cried and provoked each other to the edge of violence, then over."
6440,"She had begun to notice that even when Beloved was quiet, dreamy, minding"
6441,"her own business, Sethe got her going again."
6442,"Whispering, muttering some justification, some bit of clarifying information to Beloved to explain what it had been like, and why, and how come."
6443,It was as though Sethe didn't really want forgiveness given; she wanted it refused.
6444,And Beloved helped her out.
6445,"Somebody had to be saved, but unless Denver got work, there would be no one to save, no one to come home to, and no Denver either."
6446,"It was a new thought, having a self to look out for and preserve."
6447,And it might not have occurred to her if she hadn't met Nelson Lord leaving his grandmother's house as Denver entered it to pay a thank you for half a pie.
6448,"All he did was smile and say, ""Take care of yourself, Denver,"" but she heard it as though it were what language was made for."
6449,The last time he spoke to her his words blocked up her ears.
6450,Now they opened her mind.
6451,"Weeding the garden, pulling vegetables, cooking, washing, she plotted what to do and how."
6452,The Bodwins were most likely to help since they had done it twice.
6453,Once for Baby Suggs and once for her mother.
6454,Why not the third generation as well?
6455,"She got lost so many times in the streets of Cincinnati it was noon before she arrived, though she started out at sunrise."
6456,"The house sat back from the sidewalk with large windows looking out on a noisy, busy street."
6457,"The Negro woman who answered the front door said, ""Yes?"""
6458,"""May I come in?"""
6459,"""What you want?"""
6460,"""I want to see Mr. and Mrs. Bodwin."""
6461,"""Miss Bodwin. They brother and sister."""
6462,"""What you want em for?"""
6463,"""I'm looking for work. I was thinking they might know of some."""
6464,"""You Baby Suggs' kin, ain't you?"""
6466,"""Come on in. You letting in flies."""
6467,"She led Denver toward the kitchen, saying, ""First thing you have to know is what door to knock on."""
6468,But Denver only half heard her because she was stepping on something soft and blue.
6469,"All around her was thick, soft and blue."
6470,Glass cases crammed full of glistening things.
6471,Books on tables and shelves.
6472,Pearl-white lamps with shiny metal bottoms.
6473,"And a smell like the cologne she poured in the emerald house, only better."
6474,"""Sit down,"" the woman said."
6475,"""You know my name?"""
6477,"""Janey. Janey Wagon."""
6478,"""How do you do?"""
6479,"""Fairly. I heard your mother took sick, that so?"""
6481,"""Who's looking after her?"""
6482,"""I am. But I have to find work."""
6483,Janey laughed.

6484,"""You know what? I've been here since I was fourteen, and I remember like yesterday when Baby Suggs, holy, came here and sat right there where you are. Whiteman brought her. That's how she got that house you all live in. Other things, too."""
6486,"""What's the trouble with Sethe?"""
6487,Janey leaned against an indoor sink and folded her arms.
6488,"It was a little thing to pay, but it seemed big to Denver."
6489,Nobody was going to help her unless she told it--told all of it.
6490,It was clear Janey wouldn't and wouldn't let her see the Bodwins otherwise.
6491,"So Denver told this stranger what she hadn't told Lady Jones, in return for which Janey admitted the Bodwins needed help, although they didn't know it."
6492,"She was alone there, and now that her employers were getting older, she couldn't take care of them like she used to."
6493,More and more she was required to sleep the night there.
6494,"Maybe she could talk them into letting Denver do the night shift, come right after supper, say, maybe get the breakfast."
6495,"That way Denver could care for Sethe in the day and earn a little something at night, how's that?"
6496,"Denver had explained the girl in her house who plagued her mother as a cousin come to visit, who got sick too and bothered them both."
6497,"Janey seemed more interested in Sethe's condition, and from what Denver told her it seemed the woman had lost her mind."
6498,That wasn't the Sethe she remembered.
6499,"This Sethe had lost her wits, finally, as Janey knew she would--trying to do it all alone with her nose in the air."
6500,"Denver squirmed under the criticism of her mother, shifting in the chair and keeping her eyes on the inside sink."
6501,"Janey Wagon went on about pride until she got to Baby Suggs, for whom she had nothing but sweet words."
6502,"""I never went to those woodland services she had, but she was always nice to me. Always. Never be another like her."""
6503,"""I miss her too,"" said Denver."
6504,"""Bet you do. Everybody miss her. That was a good woman."""
6505,Denver didn't say anything else and Janey looked at her face for a while.
6506,"""Neither one of your brothers ever come back to see how you all was?"""
6508,"""Ever hear from them?"""
6509,"""No, ma'am. Nothing."""
6510,"""Guess they had a rough time in that house. Tell me, this here woman in your house. The cousin. She got any lines in her hands?"""
6511,"""No,"" said Denver."
6512,"""Well,"" said Janey."
6513,"""I guess there's a God after all."""
6514,The interview ended with Janey telling her to come back in a few days.
6515,She needed time to convince her employers what they needed: night help because Janey's own family needed her.
6516,"""I don't want to quit these people, but they can't have all my days and nights too."""
6517,What did Denver have to do at night?
6518,"""Be here. In case."""
6519,In case what?
6520,Janey shrugged.
6521,"""In case the house burn down."""
6522,She smiled then.
6523,"""Or bad weather slop the roads so bad I can't get here early enough for them."
6524,Case late guests need serving or cleaning up after.
6525,Anything.
6526,Don't ask me what whitefolks need at night.
6527,"""They used to be good whitefolks."""
6528,"""Oh, yeah. They good. Can't say they ain't good. I wouldn't trade them for another pair, tell you that."""
6529,"With those assurances, Denver left, but not before she had seen, sitting on a shelf by the back door, a blackboy's mouth full of money."
6530,"His head was thrown back farther than a head could go, his hands were shoved in his pockets."
6531,"Bulging like moons, two eyes were all the face he had above the gaping red mouth."
6532,"His hair was a cluster of raised, widely spaced dots made of nail heads."
6533,And he was on his knees.
6534,"His mouth, wide as a cup, held the coins needed to pay for a delivery or some other small service, but could just as well have held buttons, pins or crab-apple jelly."
6535,Painted across
6536,"the pedestal he knelt on were the words ""At Yo Service."""
6537,The news that Janey got hold of she spread among the other coloredwomen.
6538,"Sethe's dead daughter, the one whose throat she cut, had come back to fix her."
6539,"Sethe was worn down, speckled, dying, spinning, changing shapes and generally bedeviled."
6540,"That this daughter beat her, tied her to the bed and pulled out all her hair."
6541,It took them days to get the story properly blown up and themselves agitated and then to calm down and assess the situation.

6543,"""Ella. What's all this I'm hearing about Sethe?"""
6544,"""Tell me it's in there with her. That's all I know."""
6545,"""The daughter? The killed one?"""
6546,"""That's what they tell me."""
6547,"""How they know that's her?"""
6548,"""It's sitting there. Sleeps, eats and raises hell. Whipping Sethe every day."""
6549,"""No. Grown. The age it would have been had it lived."""
6550,"""I'll be. A baby?"""
6551,"""You talking about flesh?"""
6552,"""I'm talking about flesh."""

6554,"""Like she was batter."""
6555,"""Guess she had it coming."""
6556,"""Nobody got that coming."""
6558,"""But nothing. What's fair ain't necessarily right."""
6559,"""You can't just up and kill your children."""
6560,"""No, and the children can't just up and kill the mama."""
6561,It was Ella more than anyone who convinced the others that rescue was in order.
6562,She was a practical woman who believed there was a root either to chew or avoid for every ailment.
6563,"Cogitation, as she called it, clouded things and prevented action."
6564,"Nobody loved her and she wouldn't have liked it if they had, for she considered love a serious disability."
6565,"Her puberty was spent in a house where she was shared by father and son, whom she called ""the lowest yet."""
6566,"It was ""the lowest yet"" who gave her a disgust for sex and against whom she measured all atrocities."
6567,"A killing, a kidnap, a rape--whatever, she listened and nodded."
6568,"Nothing compared to ""the lowest yet."""
6569,"She understood Sethe's rage in the shed twenty years ago, but not her reaction to it, which Ella thought was prideful, misdirected, and Sethe herself too complicated."
6570,"When she got out of jail and made no gesture toward anybody, and lived as though she were alone, Ella junked her and wouldn't give her the time of day."
6571,"The daughter, however, appeared to have some sense after all."

6573,"When Ella heard was occupied by something or-other beating up on Sethe, it infuriated her and gave her another opportunity to measure what could very well be the devil himself against ""the lowest yet."""
6574,There was also something very personal in her fury.
6575,"Whatever Sethe had done, Ella didn't like the idea of past errors taking possession of the present."
6576,"Sethe's crime was staggering and her pride outstripped even that; but she could not countenance the possibility of sin moving on in the house, unleashed and sassy."
6577,Daily life took as much as she had.
6578,The future was sunset; the past something to leave behind.
6579,"And if it didn't stay behind, well, you might have to stomp it out."
6580,Slave life; freed life--every day was a test and a trial.
6581,Nothing could be counted on in a world where even when you were a solution you were a
6582,problem.
6583,"""Sufficient unto the day is the evil thereof,"" and nobody needed more; nobody needed a grown-up evil sitting at the table with a grudge."

6585,"But if it took flesh and came in her world, well, the shoe was on the other foot."
6586,"She didn't mind a little communication between the two worlds, but this was an invasion."
6587,"""Shall we pray?"" asked the women."
6588,"""Uh huh,"" said Ella."

6590,"The day Denver was to spend her first night at the Bodwins', Mr."
6591,Bodwin had some business on the edge of the city and told Janey he would pick the new girl up before supper.
6592,"Denver sat on the porch steps with a bundle in her lap, her carnival dress sun-faded to a quieter rainbow."

6594,Bodwin would be coming from.

6596,Denver was looking to the right.
